I said he would get nothing at all, whereupon he remarked that that was not very encouraging for a man who had been trying to save for the last 30 years. Hon. Members opposite say that it is all going very smoothly but we will see after tonight whether that is the case or not.
I want the Minister to take special notice of this next point. What about the man with a wife and one child who is on part-time work. If he has had 156 statutory benefits during any financial year, comes on to unemployment assistance and then plays for three days in any six days, instead of getting 29s. he gets 26s. Another man who has earned the same amount of money but who has not drawn any of his statutory benefit gets 14s. 6d. How do I know that this is the case? It is not something read out of a book; it is here in a pit book which has been handed to me. It says that the man earned £1 6s. 3d.; there were some deductions for the three days, and the Board gave him 4s. 10d. I want to ask the Minister a question on this point because I find that one provision has been dropped from the old Regulations, paragraph 108, which said: In the colliery industry the wages for a full week will be regarded as the normal wage even if the colliery has been on short time for a long period. That does not appear in the new Regulations. In paragraph 41 it says: This paragraph corresponds with proviso (1) of existing Regulation (4), and requires that no applicant shall be assessed at a sum which is equal to or greater than the amount which would normally be available for the support of the household out of earnings. Many miners have been on slack time for four and five years, and now that the previous provision has been deleted it will mean that if he is entitled to 40s. as a week's wage he will not get more than he would normally earn, and his normal earnings for the past four years
have not been more than three days a week. I hope we shall be told that if a man's normal earning is 8s. a day this amount will be multiplied by six.
We are opposed root and branch to the means test. I am tired of hearing hon. Members opposite talk about it. Not far from this House there fell sick the other day a man who in 12 years has received £6,000 a year in wages. He addressed a note to the Government and said that he could not go on, and the Government said that they would have to consider this poor fellow because he could not have very much to spare, and without any means test they gave him £73 a week. They did not ask whether he had any money in the Post Office or in the Co-operative Society, or whether his sons were working on the Stock Exchange. Nothing of the kind. If you want to apply a personal means test you must start at the top, and when you have started at the top we will begin to think about starting at the bottom afterwards. You begin to apply the means test on people who are starving. We mean what we say, and the fight will not finish tonight at Eleven o'Clock. It will go on all over the country until the Government come back and say that they are not going to apply the means test any more.

The hon. Member for the Sutton Division of Plymouth (Viscountess Astor) made certain challenges to which I shall be happy to make some sort of reply. She started on a very high note; a note of a confession of faith and a note of a confession of ignorance. Her confession of faith was that she was a sincere and devout Christian. Her confession of ignorance was that she could not understand why two people who presumably were believers in the same faith should come to diametrically opposite conclusions. The answer is that Christianity can be applied with sincerity starting from the assumption that we are all human beings; there is no justification in the teachings of the Scriptures why there should be any colossal difference in the way in which we treat one another. We are brothers and sisters forming one community, which involves us on this side of the House in a solid identity with those who are the victims of poverty. But so far as hon. Members opposite are concerned and as
far as they are represented by the Noble Lady the picture is blurred by the recognition of class; that there are those who are rich and privileged, and you have the amusing assumption of the Noble Lady that not only have they the money but they have the brains. The Noble Lady is the only Member of the House who is under that delusion.
You have the assumption that there are two different orders of humanity, that one section of the community is entitled to privilege and wealth, and all the advantages they can bring, and that the other sections have to thank God for a National Government, for an income which just manages to keep them alive, and that this is in the Divine order of things and cannot be altered, certainly not by a National Government. The Noble Lady instead of proving to us that she understands and appreciates in any human way the implication of these Regulations, instead of doing that, her speech from beginning to end was an abuse of her political opponents. The most we can say about her speech is that it was an amusing and brightening interlude for those who have been sitting up all night. I did appreciate the peace and quiet which fell on the House when she concluded her speech and we listened to a young Member of the Liberal party who at least has some glimmering of the truth and expressed an uneasy conscience, torn between loyalty to his pledged word to his constituents and loyalty to the party that he is here to support.
The Noble Lady said that under the capitalist system, which is to her the best system in the world, she believes that these Regulations, allowances and conditions are the best that can possibly be. I do not know how many Members opposite really accept that interpretation of the present system. We have no clear, consistent economic system of society. There are elements in our society that go back for centuries. There are elements which have been introduced through the modifications of modern finance and concentration. There are elements that have been introduced through changes of transport, production and distribution. There are also elements which have nothing in common at all with the capitalist system but are introduced into
it because we are human beings and are not prepared to allow economic law to work with a 100 per cent. ruthlessness. Thank God that something, whatever it may be, education, fair play or religion, has awakened the human heart and we are not prepared to look on at the sight of fellow human beings in every sense as good as ourselves suffering the degradation which is inevitable to unemployment and the poverty consequent upon it. Because of that, you have to bring in legislation to help out and humanise to some miscroscopic extent the competitive or capitalist system. Our objection to these Regulations is that this is not the maximum that can be done. It is the bare minimum, a very bare minimum indeed. We are prepared to demonstrate that it would be possible for this wealthy country, by putting a greater proportion of its money into circulation and into the homes of the people, substantially to increase this.
Another point that interested me was that the Noble Lady and the Minister both made Scriptural quotations. The Noble Lady's quotation was the one about casting the beam out of our eye before we start tinkering with the mote in our neighbour's eye. She was mainly concerned with the beam that she imagines she sees in our eyes, which has blinded or paralysed us or made us incapable of thinking. At the same time she claimed that, by some means, she knew us better than we knew ourselves, and knew what we believe, what our ideas are and who does our thinking for us—everything except who has done our laundry, and probably she is prepared even to speculate on that. The Minister wound up his speech with a Scriptural quotation which was about as appropriate as the Noble Lady's. It was, "Having put our hand to the plough, we will not look back." I was interested in the agricultural allusion. I was thinking of the effect of unemployment and the time that the unemployed have been having and, instead of the plough, I thought harrowing would be the most appropriate term, in view of the harrowing time that they have had for many years. Those who are dealt with under the Regulations are those who have suffered longest and endured the most. The Minister is not going to look back. That is a confession that he is not expecting to see very much result from his
ploughing. He is ploughing the desert sands or wilderness, but he is not going to make the wilderness blossom as a rose. He may get a few scrubby weeds but that is all. He will not brighten the lives of those who are born into the world.
The first thing to be ploughed up is the stand-still agreement. We are not particularly in love with the stand-still agreement. When it is destroyed, as presumably it will be after this Debate, there will be hundreds and thousands of men and women who are the victims of unemployment for whom the standstill agreement has been some slight amelioration and has held up a little while the falling of the axe or the cutting of the plough It has been claimed by the Minister that these Regulations make some improvement in the present conditions. Those improvements, such as they are, will apply more largely in areas where the administration of the Poor Law and the means test and Unemployment Assistance has been harsher than in those areas which will suffer from the removal of the stand-still agreement. So on balance, when you have taken those who will lose and those who will gain, the figure of £750,000 is very much of an estimate, and only time will tell. It largely depends on the way in which the new conditions are administered. We only have promises without any actual guarantee on that score. To the people who have been in this condition of malnutrition, with depleted incomes on which it is impossible to maintain a home wth normal decency, this crumb is so small that it does not justify the boastful spirit in which the Minister introduced the Regulations.
I feel convinced that the right hon. Gentleman is not nearly so happy about this as he appears to be. He has no security of tenure. I do not know what provision there is for him if he falls out of work, but his position is so precarious that it is much easier for him than for his fellow Members of the Government to sympathise with the victims of unemployment. After he has done his ploughing he will not look back upon this Debate and these Regulations with pride, but with shame, and he will feel that he has had to participate in the damnable business of making the poverty of the poor who are unemployed worse than it need be
even under the Capitalist system of society. I hope he will have time to reflect on the Christian or human view of the problem. I wonder whether hon. Members opposite or the Government really believe that the unemployed have any reason to be grateful to them. I suggest that they make a serious effort to imagine themselves as actually unemployed with dependants. There are Members on these benches who have been the victims of it and have spoken their experience, but it is only a matter of circumstances and chance, over which we have very little or no control, which has decided the issue. I see an hon. Member is rather amused at the suggestion that he should be unemployed.
I was not smiling at that. I have the greatest sympathy with what the hon. Member is talking about.

Smiles have been so continuous that it is very difficult to tell what Members are smiling at. If they could picture themselves as unemployed, where would their sympathies be in this Debate? Would their sympathies and support be with the utterances that have come from those benches, except for one or two mild protests, or would they be with the victims of unemployment? I think they would be much stronger, because they are not disciplined to the restraints of poverty. I do feel inclined to discuss the actual conditions and modifications and fluctuations since 1931, when the cuts were inflicted. We can concede, for the sake of argument, that they would be more or less where they were in 1931, with his difference, that the conditions are much harsher for a great percentage than they were at an earlier point in their period of unemployment. That is to say, these Regulations will apply to a larger percentage of the unemployed than they did in 1931. Even supposing that the wage is the same, I suggest that of all the people who have suffered from the legislation passed by the Government, those affected by these Regulations have suffered most.
The hon. Member for West Salford (Mr. Emery) sometime just before the dawn delivered a maiden speech. I did not hear anybody refer subsequently to that very excellent maiden speech. On this side of the House we were ignorant
of the fact that it was a maiden speech, and apparently hon. Members opposite were so unhappy about its tone, that they did not refer to it either. At any rate it was a very interesting speech and in the course of it the hon. Member referred to the fact that the cost of living under this Government is rising. I should imagine that it would be easy to score debating points on this question as to whether the cost of living has gone up or down by one point or two points. But whatever may be the fluctuations in the figure, which is supposed to be an index to the cost of living, one thing is certain, and it is that these people whose incomes are pitiably low and who are affected by this legislation have suffered out of all proportion compared with the rest of the community.
Let me take four examples. I take first the way in which the Tea Duty has affected that section of the community. There has been an all-round increase of 2d. per pound on tea. The person who has only a few shillings to spend—if he is able to indulge at all in the luxury of tea—has to buy the cheapest brand that will provide him with something which is of the colour of tea and has some faint reminder of what the flavour of tea should be like. Let us say that such a person pays 1s. 4d. a pound for his tea. The 2d. represents a 12½ per cent. increase on his tea bill. But that is not the whole of the story. There is a practice of adding on to the 2d. a margin to cover the cost of collection and 12½ per cent. is a moderate estimate of the actual increase, which would probably be nearer 20 per cent. Now the person who has not to look at every shilling he spends, who is fairly comfortably off, rarely pays less than about 3s. 6d. or 3s. 4d. a lb. for his tea. An hon. Member suggests that 2s 8d. is the ordinary price paid by people in comfortable circumstances, but I think the figure which I have given is right.
I do not wish to contradict the hon. Member but for every ounce of tea that he has seen sold I have sold hundredweights.

That is the sort of claim that we are used to hearing. I happen to be a member of an organisation which
is the biggest dealer in tea in this country and for every hundredweight of tea that the hon. Member has sold, they probably sell tons. I refer to the English and Scottish General Wholesale Society which handles more tea than any other organisation in this country. In that organisation we know all about prices, and part of our system is to send round and make purchases in cities where we have shops in order to get some indication of the prices. I repeat that 3s. 4d. and 3s. 6d are not uncommon prices for the best quality tea. The point is that on the sort of tea bought by wealthier members of the community the 2d. increase only represents 5 per cent., whereas the poor person who buys the cheapest tea has to bear an interest of 12½ per cent. That sort of thing runs through the whole range of commodities.
I take a second illustration to show how the action of the Government has definitely affected the cost of living particularly of those people who come under these Regulations. I refer to common things such as bread, potatoes and milk. We all know that in the case of people whose incomes are very small, those items form a far greater proportion of the household budget than they do in the case of normally well-to-do members of the community. Again, on that score, there is an abnormal rise in the cost of living of the people affected by these Regulations. My third illustration brings us back to the subject of discussion last Friday, namely, beef. The main argument in that discussion was that the British producer could not compete with imported chilled and frozen beef, which could be sold cheaply in this country. Why do the poor people of this country buy the cheapest joints? For the same reason that the National Government buy the same stuff for the Army and Navy. Simply because it is the cheapest. The poor people do not buy this beef because it is better or because they like it more, but because it is all that their small incomes can cover.
I hope that hon. Members opposite are sufficiently fair-minded to recognise that in their theory of reconstruction, as far as they have one, they are trying to restrict the quantity of these cheaper commodities coming on to the British market. By restrictions quotas and social they are raising the cost to the consumer of these
cheaper commodities in an effort to compel a larger section of people to buy the best British beef. Who is to suffer most from that kind of legislation? Not the people who have always had the best joints but the people who, if they are to have meat at all, must put up with the cheapest scrag-ends. The fourth illustration which I give has been rendered familiar by the Debates which we have had from time to time, late at night, on various Import Duty Orders. On those occasions we are always assured that a certain commodity is cheap and flashy, is produced under conditions which make it impossible for our manufacturers to compete against it, and that it is necessary to impose a duty of anything from 10 to 50 per cent. upon it. Who is buying these cheap and flashy foreign produced goods?
The co-operatives.

I can tell the hon. Member that people who have learned from bitter experience how to exist on the mere income provided under such Regulations as these, have discovered that the co-operative society is a greater help to them in their day of trouble than the National Government. If the hon. Member is interested in this subject I shall be glad to contribute to his education by taking him round some modern co-operative stores and also factories where British goods are produced by British labour from British materials. I would add that those goods are very often sold at prices which compare with the prices of imported commodities, out of which certain people who profess patriotism make their fortunes. Who are those most affected by this artificial increase of prices? They are the people who, in order to make ends meet, have to perform every week the miracle which the Chancellor of the Exchequer performs once a year. Those people are hard hit in all the various ways I have mentioned. I could enumerate other ways in which they are adversely affected by the Government's legislation and have their cost of living increased out of all proportion to that figure which is circulated as the index figure. I suggest that the unemployed have nothing to thank the Government for but much cause to regret the Government's existence.
Now I turn to the question of the means test and here again we have an illustration of a popular adage that "it is the poor who help the poor." Evidently the National Government are quite satisfied that that should be the case. I am prepared to admit that even certain Members who have sat on these benches never realised, until it was actually in operation, the implications of this means test. We have been challenged to say whether we are prepared to give public funds to people who do not need them. Those Members who have served on boards of guardians and relief committees are familiar with the stories told by the people who come before these committees. It is not a question of any "sob-stuff" such as the Noble Lady opposite referred to. Those who have acted on relief committees are acquainted with the kind of working-class people, often aged men and women, who come before those bodies. They have a right to come and ask for help, and our job is to encourage them and to make them see that they are entitled to it. Their shame is not in receiving public money. I have yet to hear of any Member or Cabinet Minister returning his cheque and saying that he is well off and does not need public money. That is because it is recognised that there is service to the community.
Our view is that any man or woman who does honest service while the work is available, whether they are working for a private employer or not, are contributing to the wealth of the country. They are producing the wealth that makes possible the distribution of surpluses, which make possible affluence and comfort and the unearned income which so many enjoy. We do not get bitter about this; we recognise it as a fact. There is in almost every section of the community, down to those who are recipients of poor relief, those who receive unearned income. This is a problem that the Noble Lady found it difficult to understand. Whereas we on these benches want to control wealth and give the maximum of liberty to individuals, we do not want to make their possession or non-possession of wealth a fetter on their liberty. The shame is in making investigations and proving that they are poor. Nobody is really ashamed of unemployment. There is something wrong if they are. Most of us look forward to the end of next week
at being unemployed for a month or two. The only difference is that the people who are compulsorily unemployed from January to December would enjoy themselves if they had the money. While they are denied the right to serve the community, either through public bodies or through private employers, they are cut out from any income until they prove that they are exceedingly poor.
The curse of poverty is poverty, and we oppose the means test because there is sufficient wealth, if the production of it is organised and equitably distributed, for everybody. On the question of public money going to people without any means test, I do not want to go over the list and the records of noble people who held high posts in the Army and Navy, some of whom have seen very little active service and have strutted about in their uniforms very pleased with themselves. We have some in this House who are excellent illustrations of that type. They do not grumble about taking from public funds which the law has made possible for them. There is no shame in it, and by this time we should recognise that every child born is entitled to the necessaries of life and that it is a primary obligation of the State to use its power to secure them that elementary right. Some people are old-fashioned, and the Noble Lady, who all her life has been receiving apparently a satisfactory unearned income, is prepared to go to the women and tell them that these poor people should not have 30s., but less. The whole thing is so pitiful that I am amazed that anybody should at this time of day ask us why we are opposed to the means test. It is the badge of poverty.
Through the centuries we have developed a mentality and attitude to poverty as if it were in some strange, vague way something that appertains to the majority of the common people. Some of us who take a modern outlook and realise the world's potentialities say that poverty is not a vice to be published, but a disease to be cured. We say that it is infectious, and that those who are living in immediate contact with it are made to share the disease and its results. If we recognise that poverty is a disease inherent in the present system, those who are victims of it should be
dealt with individually and their disease healed. When we educate people to the fact that poverty is one of the diseases of competitive civilisation and that it is not their fault, we shall get that fine British spirit of independence about which we boast so much, which will demand something far better than these Regulations. My main objection to them is their lack of imagination and their acceptance of the fact that there will be always a certain percentage of unemployed. There is, too, a recognition by the advisers of the Government that not only is there a fluctuating figure of unemployed, but what is known as the hard core of chronic victims of this disease.
I would suggest to hon. Members opposite the even if they are not capable of going the whole way with us for the organisation of production and distribution on a rational basis, they should deal with this problem as we have dealt with others, by little bits of Socialism, as, for instance, the public highways. We cannot make a profit out of keeping them clean. It is nobody's job, which means that it becomes everybody's job, and the local authorities under legislation do the scavenging. It is about time we began to realise that there is some scavenging to be done here in the disease, poverty and degradation which is attendant on unemployment. In village schools I know, where coal mines have been closed in Yorkshire, the very lamps are illuminated with oil. There are textile mills which have been closed down, and it should be possible to organise their capacity for production and to distribute the products among the victims of unemployment. If it is objected that that would interfere with the standard and the quantities of goods produced for the ordinary market, that objection can be shown to be erroneous. By raising the standard and by distributing a commodity produced co-operatively, it will be possible to increase the wealth of the unemployed and the standards of those on small wages.
On several occasions during this Debate there has been laughter. When the hon. Member for Caerphilly (Mr. Morgan Jones) was speaking he complained of the laughter, and Mr. Speaker had to intervene. To-day we have had the same complaint. Why is it that hon. Members opposite, whom we know to be normal
decent, kindly men, have, when Members on these benches have feelingly expressed the claims of the unemployed, indulged in laughter? Those who study psychology know that there is a kind of laughter which is a defence laughter, which saves the individual from trying to understand and answer an unpleasant question. No hon. Member ought to adopt the primitive laugh of the jackass in face of difficult issues. I am not going to say that all the laughter has been on the other side of the House. A few weeks ago an hon. Member opposite got so hot and bothered and worked up so that both sides of the House laughed at him, when he was appealing for the amenities and the aesthetic associations of Chelsea.
Last Friday we had an illustration of an hon. Member on the opposite benches getting very hot about oats. I do not blame him. I remember when an hon. Lady got very heated and went into the Division Lobby against the Government because she disapproved of arrangements for air mails going to one firm. On all these occasions I have been sorry when there has been laughter, because I am only too happy to see anybody feeling strongly about anything. It is different, however, when Members on these benches have feelingly put the case of the victims of unemployment, and have appealed to hon. Members opposite to modify these harsh Regulations, that they should be met with laughter. I hope that that attitude to this problem will cease. If this is the most that can be done under capitalism for the victims of unemployment, which is the direct result of capitalism, the time has come to change that system in the interests of the victims of it as well as in the interests of those whose education is not inclined to be more than laughter at the appeal of human pity and the request that the sores of mankind should be healed.

On a point of Order. May I ask your ruling in regard to a matter of procedure? I would like to know whether this Debate should finish at the normal time of 11 o'clock to-night or whether, having suspended the 11 o'clock Rule yesterday, the Debate can be continued after 11 o'clock if hon. Members so desire?
The Regulations are Exempted Business owing to their being pursuant to an Act of Parliament.
On a point of Order. I should be glad if you would inform me whether the Closure can be moved at 11 o'clock.
The Closure can be moved at any time.

I would like to take up the argument of the hon. Member for Finsbury (Mr. Woods) and then refer to the speech made yesterday evening by the hon. Member for Caerphilly (Mr. Morgan Jones). I would assure the hon. Member for Finsbury that I and most other hon. Members on these Benches listened to and appreciated both his plea and the arguments he advanced. I think it is not presumptious of me to say that, because I wish to commence my argument from a point of view which fits in with the argument advanced by him. The hon. Member drew a distinction in envisaging his organisation of society, between normal payments that are made from the State and abnormal payments. We on this side commence from the position that abnormal payments, among which are classed the payments we are discussing in this Debate, depend on need. There may be a distinction as to what is the meaning of need. Hon. Members below the Gangway opposite say that need includes the case where there are parents with considerable means who have a son out of work. But in deciding what constitutes need for the purpose of these Regulations, one has at the same time to decide what are to be the criteria for judging need and the methods we are to apply in making that judgment. That is where I find it difficult to appreciate the positive argument which is made by hon. Members on the other side. They have explained their objection to the means test as being based largely on the way it works, but I have yet fully to appreciate—and I listened with the greatest possible care to the speech of the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury)—their substitute for the means test for the purpose of estimating what is need.
I have tried to approach the matter in this way. If you have not a means test, you must have certain definite standards of payment. If one imagines those standards in process of being constituted,
they would inevitably be such as would remove hardship from the top-line cases, and then one would be driven to the position of having decided the standards and deprived oneself of discretion and flexibility in fixing the standards. One would then be forced into the position that the standards set by the top-line cases would leave other cases lower down the line where there would not be need. Again, there is a sharp division of opinion between hon. Members below the Gangway opposite and ourselves. They will say that need should contain those cases and that we should include those cases that are correlated and similar to the main need. We say that these payments from the State, not for services but as payments for need, require examination, and if standards without flexibility are to be adjusted on the top scale, we say that one will inevitably be driven into the position where there must essentially be extravagance and waste.
What is the alternative? The only alternative is to take a standard which meets the middle case, and add to it flexibility and discretion which will allow for some movement up and movement down. That, in my submission, is the principle which underlies the Regulations by which we stand. Let me take the matter one stage further. Assuming that I am right in my submission, one then comes to the position that there are other cases where there is admittedly no need. How are these to be dealt with? They can be dealt with only by making conditions, and one of the conditions that must be made, if one is to change the state of things in which payment is made where there is no need, is that the payments shall be adjusted according to need—in other words, that there shall be some test. I venture to put that forward not simply as an argument, but as a real difficulty, and I am sure hon. Members will appreciate that it is a really logical difficulty in which many of us find ourselves, starting from the premise which I hope I have stated clearly and frankly.
There is another personal difficulty to which I would like to refer, and it may be that some hon. Members opposite will be able to solve that difficulty. One hon. Member below the Gangway said that he would have felt less unhappy about his chances in fighting a possible by-election
if he had to deal with the question of an individual means test. With regard to that argument, there seems to be the difficulty that the vast majority of cases are going to be cases of man and wife. Are the earnings of the wife to be included, or are they not? If they are, it ceases to be an individual means test, and one comes back step by step, forced each inch of the route, to the position of a family means test. If the earnings of the wife are not to be included, one is putting in the way of people those little subterfuges to which, with the best will in the world, people are driven when they are put in that difficult position.

While dealing with that point, would the hon. Member be good enough to explain how these difficulties are overcome in the similar cases of assessment and collection of Income Tax when the wife's income is taken into account, but the incomes of the rest of the household are not taken into account?

I do not think the hon. Member for North Aberdeen (Mr. Garro Jones) has quite appreciated the position I am stating. I was saying that if one includes the wife's income, as in the case of Income Tax, then it ceases to be an individual means test. If the wife's income is not included you are allowing an opportunity for those subterfuges which are met, in the case of Income Tax, by the wife's, income being grouped with the husband's. I think that answers the point which the hon. Member has put to me. There is one other matter with which I would like to deal, and again I think I can give an answer to the point that has been raised by several hon. Members who have spoken with great feeling—feeling which everyone respects—concerning the allegation of the penalisation of thrift. Again, that must be related to the principle on which the money is given. If it is given for need, it may be a very fortunate thing for many people—as indeed it is very fortunate with regard to other payments that are made to people in all sections of society—that their moral achievements and their moral faculties are not taken into account when their needs are assessed. One is approaching the matter not from the principle as to whether a person is a good, sound, thrifty citizen, but from the aspect—a kindlier aspect it may well be—
of whether he needs the money. From that aspect it is irrelevant—and in many cases fortunately irrelevant—what his moral character may be.
I pass now to one other aspect which hon. Members have raised with great force, and that is the comparison of the payments under these Regulations with the payments made in connection with derating, which the hon. Member for Caerphilly instanced, and the various subsidies referred to by other hon. Members. I will deal with derating because that was the comparison made by the hon. Member for Caerphilly. There you had an allowance of three-quarters of the rates, conditioned by the fact that the factory or workshop receiving the allowance had to be a producing factory or workshop within the Factories and Workshops Acts. Therefore, there is the vital distinction that in that case one is dealing with a factory producing something, making some article or another, at the same time as it is giving employment.
I accept that point, but the hon. Member must understand that the derating benefit was given both to firms that were not paying their way and those that were getting handsome returns.

I am entirely accept the hon. Member's point, and I am dealing with the matter on that basis. I am drawing attention to the fact that the factories which are actually in production and giving employment are receiving the assistance because they are in production and giving employment. They are not receiving it on the basis of need. Take the case of the subsidies, in connection with which hon. Members opposite have made a very strong case. It will be remembered that the hon. and learned Gentleman the Member for East Bristol (Sir Stafford Cripps) intervened at the end of the Third Reading Debate on the tramp shipping subsidy on the question of the Bank Line and made the point as to why the Bank Line was receiving a subsidy when their returns were so on and so forth. Again, the subsidy was given on the basis that tramp shipping was carrying its trade into the ports of the world and giving employment at the same time. It was not given on the basis of whether these companies needed the money or not. First and foremost they
had to show that the industry as a whole needed the money, and they did so.
Do not the unemployed as a whole need the money?
If hon. Members will look at the figures given in that Debate, they will find that the majority of the companies that did need the money were not making their 5 per cent. depreciation.
Is not that true of the unemployed as a whole?

I do not think that my hon. Friend has quite appreciated the difference that I am pointing out. It is that, in order to qualify for that subsidy, they had to show, first and foremost, that the tramp shipping section of the industry was as a whole affected; and, secondly, they had to show that each particular ship which qualified for the subsidy was engaged in sailing and was carrying out its work. I suggest that there is a fundamental distinction such as I have pointed out. It applies to a less direct extent in regard to armaments and work for armaments at the present time. I quite agree, and every Member of the House will agree, that it is a misfortune that work should be directed to that end, that the conditions of the world should necessisate that being done. That is the basis from which we start. But what cannot be questioned is that there is not the difference between paying to people under these Regulations money for which they give nothing, and paying money for armaments. One must recognise that at least 75 per cent. of the total expenditure on armaments will go in wages in one way or another.
I do not want to occupy too much of the time of the House, but simply to indicate the points as they appear to me, and with great trepidation I want to follow the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury), who, I am sorry to say, is not in his place at the moment. [HON. MEMBERS: "He has been here all night!"] When I say I am sorry, I really mean that I am sorry, because I also have been here all night. [HON. MEMBERS: "So have we!"] Yes; we are dealing with it on that basis; we have all been here; and that is why I am sorry that the right hon. Gentleman is not in his place. I should like to deal with the
three points on the procedure side with which the right hon. Gentleman dealt. First, as regards the officer of the Board, I think it will be agreed that the right hon. Gentleman did not find much to criticise as far as the officer of the Board is concerned. He definitely dissociated himself from such criticism. He then dealt with the advisory committees, and said that he had not great hopes from their activities. I should like to remind the House that on page 12 of the Board's Memorandum it is clearly stated that: Although the questions affecting rent, the adjustment of allowances in rural areas, and the progressive adjustment of Standstill allowances, are the only matters in the Regulations upon which the advice of the committees is specifically sought, the Board expect to receive advice and assistance from the committee over a wider field. If that is the spirit in which the Board envisage the co-operation of the committees, I respectfully suggest to hon. Members opposite that one need not despair of their making a sound contribution to the problem which we have to decide.
The other point is with regard to the appeal procedure. As hon. Members opposite know, there have been difficulties in the past with regard to the appeal procedure, as to its being narrowed to points of law. It rests on the chairman of the tribunal, and hon. Members will recollect what is said on pages 28 and 29 of the Board's Memorandum, namely, that the Board have drawn the attention of chairmen to the point that special circumstances under Regulation IV (2, a)—and I need not stress to hon. Members the importance of special circumstances in this regard—are to be considered a matter at which the chairman can look and on which the right to appeal can be based.
Taking these points in order, they seem to deal with some of the criticisms which were made as to procedure, but may I remind hon. Members of one thing? Hon. Members opposite are always ready, and quite fairly ready, to remind us of the position which we have taken up in Debate. A short time ago we debated at considerable length, on, if I may say so, a most enjoyable Friday, the question of the Workmen's Compensation Bill which was brought in by hon. Members opposite. Hon. Members then stressed the
advisability of substituting, for the present procedure of the county court and its ancillaries, their own scheme, which comprised a board, a workmen's compensation officer, and an appeal to other committees. On this side of the House we submitted that that scheme was not sufficient, that it was not as good as the present arrangement; and hon. Members asked us whether we have not considered how the system of unemployment allowances had worked, how the Board's scheme had worked, and they adduced that as an argument. I suggest that, while it might be for us to extend our criticisms, it does not lie in the mouths of hon. Members opposite, when they have advocated that scheme in a more complex surrounding, to say that it is not a suitable scheme here. I hope I have not taken up too much of the time of the House in developing these points, but I wanted to show hon. Members opposite that we have endeavoured to appreciate the points which they have pressed upon us, and that we also, in approaching the problem, from our postulates if you like, have tried logically and sincerely to work to the conclusion which we think is right.

I should like first to answer the point put by the hon. and learned Member for the West Derby Division of Liverpool (Mr. Maxwell Fyfe) with regard to de-rating. I do not want to go into the whole question of de-rating, but I would like to point out that, while it is true that de-rating was based on the theory that the factory continued its production, there was no test of any kind as to how much employment a factory receiving the benefit of de-rating should continue to give. For example, it might be possible for a factory giving employment to 1,000 people—and here I am quoting a case that I know—to use the benefits of de-rating to put in fresh machinery and actually reduce the amount of labour employed. I suggest that that £29,000,000 of de-rating money was a very handsome subsidy to industry, and that it did not involve any test of means in cases like that, for example, of the Columbia Graphophone Company, which I believe, in the very year of de-rating, 1929, paid 65 per cent. on its ordinary shares. If there is no test of means, at least there ought to be a test of use—of how the money received has been used: but as
a matter of fact that £29,000,000 of largesse was handed out to industry without any test of use. While it was intended to help such areas as I and my colleagues represent—depressed areas in this country—it is well known that the precise opposite has been the effect, because it did not induce factories to settle in the distressed areas, it did not stop that great trek to London which has made London the great, overgrown, unplanned factory area that it is. It really is a scandal that hon. Members opposite should come here and talk about public money not being handed out without any test at all, and imagine at the same time that they can get away with a swindle such as the De-rating Act has proved to be from the point of view of employment.
I can point out a worse case. During my second Parliament, that of 1929–1931, there was an agricultural subsidy, and I remember the hon. and gallant Gentleman who is now Forestry Commissioner quoting that subsidy which had been given to him as a landowner by previous Governments, and pointing out that it was not only possible, but that in fact he had not used that money for the purpose for which it had been given to him, namely, the development of his own land, but had invested it in railway companies. These are cases in which public money has been handed out without any question of a means test. But when it is a question of giving the Board power to grant what is merely sufficient to keep life together and to keep skilled workers from completely rusting, that power is denied. The Minister for the Co-ordination of Defence recently bewailed the fact that skilled opticians were not available for optical instrument making, but when I asked him whether power was going to be given to take skilled men off the means test, he dismissed the question. He was, however, very anxious to take the employers off the means test. I think we might have a little less of this cant, from the present Government of all others, as to public money being handed out without any test.
I had not intended to be drawn into that side of the question, except that I wanted to answer the statement of the hon. and learned Member for the West Derby Division of Liverpool, but I wanted to raise certain questions with regard to Jarrow. I feel that those of
us who have sat here through the night will, by the time we reach 11 o'clock this evening—which I believe will then be the longest sitting of the House since 1881—have taken part in a very historic Debate, and I am very glad indeed that that historic Debate should have taken place on a subject of such vital moment to the people whom we represent. I want to ask the Minister certain questions relating to other parts of the Regulations, and I want to be quite brief, because I know how many others desire to speak. I think it can be said that every one of the speakers on both sides of the House has really tried to tackle the problem and the Debate has reached a very high standard.
The Minister, in the course of his speech, made a great point of the flexibility of the Regulations and the discretionary powers that were to be given to officials. He also said that this was an experiment in technique. Heaven knows, one wants to encourage any Government in these days to experiment, but one also wants to be fairly sure of the lines on which the experiments are to be conducted. I wonder if it is really in conformity with the spirit of our English institutions that so very much power should be given to officials, and whether it is really fair to the officials themselves. I sat as a member of the Lord Chancellor's Committee on the Delegation of Powers, where this matter was very prominently brought before the public, but I see the same sort of principle coming in now in another way. I should be the last to attack any civil servant. Civil servants are human beings. Therefore, I want to call the attention of the Minister to the position in which he is placing the men who will have to carry out the Regulations and who will have these enormous discretionary powers in their hands. If I quote Jarrow I hope it will be understood that I am not making any invidious references to officials there. Let me say that Mr. A. is going to have these enormous powers and that he has to live in this town. The Income Tax Department meets the situation by moving their officials about and not allowing them to remain too long in one place, but the Minister of Labour, for good reasons, thinks that it is best that his officials should obtain all the local knowledge they can and come into touch with the people.
The official has in his hands these discretionary powers, affecting the lives of a large number of people. In that town there are the usual personalities, the priest, the local industrialists, the Methodist parson, the local Member of Parliament and the other big wigs. There are a certain number of cases brought to their attention and they are very often the cases that can put their points well and will not sit quietly under what they consider a grievance. There is this type of person who goes to the Member of Parliament, the priest, or the local employer, and one or other of those persons goes to the official and says: "I think this is a deserving case. You know John Smith or John Brown. I am very interested in him. Cannot something be done under the 'Pots and Pans Clause,' or cannot something be done for this sick man?" I am not suggesting that it is not a deserving case and that the people who present the case are not able to justify it, but the official is living in the town, he has to dine out with these people and his social life has to depend upon it. Therefore, it is only human that in these circumstances, and it is happening now, he tends to use greater discretion and to give extra allowances to the people brought specifically to his notice, and then when he is faced with the fact that as an official his amount must not be too big, he tends to economise on the people who have no one to speak for them. Every hon. Member knows that that is happening. We say that the extension of these discretionary powers places too much temptation for the use of those powers in the hands of the individual official.
The present Government and their predecessors of the same party have always maintained a rigid attitude about officials taking part in politics. What they really object to is officials taking part in Labour politics. They turn a blind eye to the official who takes part in Tory politics, so long as it is done with a sufficient amount of tact. But there are politics and politics. Politics are not only party politics. I should like to read a very short extract from my local paper at Jarrow, which gives an illustration of how the power to which I have referred is being used. The question has arisen as to the Jarrow unemployed having a march to London.
Before the matter had been passed by the town council the local Press approached the local Unemployment Assistance Board authority, and the result is that we get a statement such as the one which I am about to read. I would ask the Minister to take particular note of it, because this is the sort of thing that can go on when these discretionary powers are given to officials under the Regulations: Meanwhile the officials are waiting for the first sign of the hunger march it is not a hunger march— so that arrangements can be made to obstruct it. As soon as we know definitely we shall ask headquarters for instructions. It is certain that the men who join the march will lose their benefit, and other penalties may follow. Somehow I do not think many people will join the march. I suggest that when an official who uses his power over individuals—and such power is given under the Regulations—can take a side like that in a great controversy, it is most undesirable. The Members of the Government party on the Town Council are supporting this idea, and therefore probably the official's mind may alter. At any rate, that is what he said: The officials are waiting for the first sign, so that arrangements can be made to obstruct them. Even if you had super men they would have a very hard time in using these vast powers fairly. It is a great pity that in these Regulations the Minister has not done more to protect his own officials than merely by the advisory committees. When we had rota committees they had some power, but the Minister did not like it; I do not mean the present Minister. Now, we are to have advisory committees under the Regulations. I suggest that the advisory committees have no real power. The result will be that busy people will not waste much time on such committees and the local officials will maintain the power vested in them. Of course, you will get committees with the names of big people on them and it will look very well, but as a means of protection it will mean little or nothing, because either the people will not attend after the Mayor has been down and greeted them, or a photograph has been taken by the local Press. When it comes down to protecting the unemployed or protecting the officials these committees under the Regu-
lations will have no power and little effect.
Let me come to another point, and that is the effect of these means test Regulations on a place like Jarrow. I do not want it to be thought that I consider Jarrow as the only place on the map, but it is such a special and extraordinary case that we have to keep pressing that something should be done in regard to it, otherwise it will be forgotten. In this Debate hon. Members opposite seem to desire that the old Poor Law principle of deterrent should operate. They seem to suggest that there is something wrong if a man is unemployed or if members of his family are unemployed. There is a suggestion that it is his fault that he has not found work, and therefore nothing should be done that might induce him not to take work. Let us see how that works out logically in the case of Jarrow. It is said that the means test allowances must be lower than the aggregate wage. Here we have a town where either through deliberately depriving it of work or as a result of the Government neglecting to deal with the problem, there is no work to be had. How then can the deterrent rule logically apply to a town like Jarrow? If the Minister says that his official would be acting under the Regulations if he said that the men would not be available for work if they joined the march to London, I should say that if they were marching to London they would have more chance of getting work as they passed through towns and we appealed for work for them, than they would have by staying in the town where there is no work for them. Therefore, the officials cannot have it that way.
With regard to the household means test hon. Members may ask why should not a man's relatives help to keep him. No doubt hon. Members opposite have their own aged relatives whom they are keeping at considerable expense. Here we are dealing with a limited set of people who are the relatives of men who live in this unfortunate town which has been deliberately deprived of work. These relatives are to be taxed up to 30 per cent. of their income to bear something which ought to be a national burden. The Minister said that an employed son earning 40s. a week would have to pay 12s. That is an Income Tax of 30 per cent.
as a contribution towards the national burden of unemployment. If that man is in a rated house he is paying rates at 19s. 6d. in the £ in Jarrow, in order to bear a national burden. We have here a problem that goes beyond family affairs. When a man is living with his family and he is in work there are all sorts of little things that he will try to do in order to help and to express his family affection, but I suggest that it is not right or just that an Income Tax of 30 per cent. should be paid out of the wages of employed men in areas that have been deprived of work, in order to lessen by a fraction a burden that we ought to regard as national.
It is about time that we got away from, sentimental nonsense about family affection. That has nothing to do with it. It is a matter of hard cash. A town like Jarrow has been deprived of industry, and the policies of the Minister of Agriculture have raised the prices that have to be paid for food out of these meagre amounts. Take an ordinary working-class family in Jarrow and put on a piece of paper figures showing the extra burden that that family has to bear because of the policies advocated in this House by the Government. One of my hon. Friends quoted the price that a woman would have to pay for a pound of bacon—1s. 3d. Before this Government started she would have had to pay 6d. for that amount of bacon. Therefore, she is paying 9d. per lb. extra for her bacon in order to pay for the policies of this Government. Hon. Members have been talking as though working-class families were trying to shirk their just burdens. It is not possible to make the Minister understand the depths of indignation which exist. We have been taunted with the statement that there does not seem to be much indignation; I think Ministers are optimistic a little early.
I suggest to the Minister that there is a psychological problem which is much deeper than that. The awful thing is that the men who kick are those who have recently been well fed, as would be the case if anything happened to hon. Members opposite or to us, who are fed and who have the vitality which reasonable food, sleep and rest give. The stage which we have reached under the means test is that the men who have been unemployed for such long periods as have
the men of Jarrow, cannot face these officials who have such great power over their lives. Their reaction is not to fight, but to auction their misery. It is, when the man says that a shilling has to come off, to plead for nine shillings for fear of having to accept eight. Those of us who are working in the great distressed areas know that that is true. I shall be among my unemployed men to-morrow morning. I know the awful fear that they have, and which they did not have before when they were dealing with officials at the Employment Exchanges. The Unemployment Assistance Board, with its vast undefined powers, its control and its discretion which can depress as well as uplift, has added terror to the depression in these areas. That is the problem with which we have to deal. I am not surprised that there is not more fight, when I go to the women and see the sense of hopelessness which this Government has put upon a town like Jarrow. If men are not fed and have no hope, there comes a time when they have no confidence left in themselves. I believe the Minister meant every word he expressed about the depression, but I ask him to understand that it can be used in two ways, and that it is in one of those ways that we shall be coming to him.

The hon. Lady represents, I suppose, the most hard-pressed Division in the whole country; I represent rather a prosperous division at the present time, and I have no qualms, so far as my people are concerned, about these Regulations. I believe the House will sympathise with her in much of what she said. Equally, I believe that most of her fears are groundless. May I first take up a point which she made in the beginning of her speech, when she attacked the whole subsidy policy of the Government, shipping subsidies, agricultural subsidies, de-rating and so on? It is surely worth remembering that those subsidies are keeping large numbers of people employed in industry and on the land who otherwise would not be so employed. The people on the land would be going into the towns to make conditions worse there. Hon. Members, particularly on the Liberal benches, should remember that, because the Liberal benches—and on that point I have a great deal of sym-
pathy with them—have always been pressing for a more advanced policy of land settlement.
The hon. Lady then went on to say a great deal about the attitude of area officers and the advisory committees of the Unemployment Assistance Board. She expressed no faith in the advisory committees. I cannot help thinking that she is wrong there. I take it that the advisory committees will at least hold their sessions in public. They work in public. They will inquire, where they are asked to make inquiries, but they will surely be a liaison between the hon. Lady's town and the Unemployment Assistance Board. Many of the duties with which they are charged, particularly the duty concerning rent, are of extraordinarily practical importance to the effect of these Regulations.
Will the Minister endorse the hon. Member's statement?
Will the hon. Member say what authority he has for saying that the advisory committees will hold their sittings in public?
I have no authority whatsoever. I will put it in the form of a query, if the hon. Member likes. Presumably the advisory committees will sit in public.
No.
They have never sat in public.

The hon. Member has interrupted from the beginning of this Debate. If he will listen to the Debate and listen to the reply we shall both know whether I am right or wrong. I do not know.
I want to go into a brief study of some of the effects of the Regulations, in particular, in relation to two speeches, one by the hon. Member for Withington (Mr. Fleming) last night, and the other by the hon. Member for West Salford (Mr. Emery) early this morning. Both those hon. Members have objected to the Regulations. The hon. Member for Leigh (Mr. Tinker) objected to the means test, but I hope that he and the hon. Member for Farnworth (Mr. Rowson) will recognise that these scales are going to be a great deal better for their people, and for my people, than the present scales. [An
HON. MEMBER: "That is only because the means test has been rigorously applied."] Most of my people are on the Unemployment Assistance Board's scale and not upon transitional payment. They will, therefore, benefit considerably under the new scale. Hon. Members opposite surely might recollect that the scales which we are discussing now are, in the no-resource cases, a very great deal higher, in all instances but two, than the transitional benefit scales between 1929 and 1931. The two cases, which are equal, are those of a man and a wife and a man with two children both under five years old. They have the same amount in the no-resource case. I think that the hon. Lady is wrong about the cost of living. She is certainly right about bacon, but wrong in saying that there has been a rise in the cost of living. The cost of living index figure is almost exactly the same as it was in 1931.
We know the basis upon which that was fixed.

It is a pretty general basis. The hon. Member for Withington objected to the Regulations. I have been into the Manchester scales very closely. In the no-resource class, in practically every case there will be a rise, under the present scale. Although the Manchester people have been very generous in their allowance for rent, even under the upward provision for rent a man and wife, with rent at 10s. per week, will be able, under the new scales, to get 30s. Even the Manchester public assistance committees on whose assessment most applicants are, only gives 28s. in that case.
When it comes to the family means test, to which those hon. Members objected, on the grounds upon which they are voting against the Regulations, if they do so, the regulation which the Manchester Public Assistance Committee chose to put into practice was to disregard a quarter of the earnings of all sons and daughters, and then to make an allowance of 7s. on top of that. Upon a 50s. wage, 12s. 6d. would be allowed, and 7s. on top of that, that is 19s. 6d. Under the present Regulations 33s. would be disregarded. That is very much higher, and I am satisfied that both those hon. Members are voting against what is in the great interest of their constituents and is generally in the great interests of the people of the
North-western area. There is a desirability for some measure of greater uniformity. I find that Manchester people who are now on the transitional payments scale in Hulme, across the road from my constituency, are getting more than the people in my constituency, who are on the present Unemployment Assistance Board scale.
This statutory task which is imposed upon us of getting a basis of uniformity with discretion is surely one of which we need not be ashamed. We are not taking anything away from people, but we are providing them with relief. We disagree on this side of the House with the whole principle of giving relief whether it is needed or not. We believe that there should be some family contribution. I am glad that it is not such a great family contribution as it used to be. Suppose you take that case of the 50s. wage-earner, the father and mother being unemployed; their scale allowance is 26s. The worker gets 33s. allowed to himself. Suppose you say that if he were unemployed his scale in the household would be 10s.; that would raise the three of them to 36s. [An HON. MEMBER: "Why?"] It is 26s. plus 10s. [An HON. MEMBER: "Marvellous."] Hon. Members might listen to the argument. We have listened to a great many. We listened to the hon. Member for Finsbury (Mr. Woods) for a very long time just now without interrupting him. The scale payment for those three people would presumably be 36s. The man is earning 50s. of which 33s. are disregarded. Suppose you subtract the 10s. from the 33s.; you come to 23s. Would a man not, in fact, provide half his 50s. wage towards the household of his mother and father in which he is living? In the normal case that man is contributing half his earnings to the family income. Would that not be his normal practice in any district in the country?
May I ask the hon. Member—

Not for a moment. I want to finish my sentence, and at the end of my sentence the hon. Gentleman may do so. Is it not reasonable, therefore, that we should take it as normal that an earner, son or daughter, contributes towards the income of the household?
Sixteen shillings is for his keep. The difference between 16s. and 50s. according to the scale is divided. Out of the 34s. he has contributed 17s.

In that household there is 59s. coming in—a very great deal more than was ever coming in before the Unemployment Assistance Board was set up. There cannot be said to be any hardship of any kind in that household.
Will the hon. Gentleman tell the House on what basis of justice does society expect a young lad to keep his father as the result of a social evil?

There are numbers of young people in this country who keep their fathers to a certain extent, if their fathers have not enough money. I should not complain, nor in practice would the hon. Member. He would do exactly the same thing. If he was earning a good wage and his father was earning nothing, he would be proud to contribute to his father's keep.
It was my pride to do it, until both my parents left this world; but I would never admit the right of society to expect me to keep them if they were idle as a result of social conditions.

We always come back to this main underlying but very vague contention—that social conditions are responsible for all the evil. They are a great deal less responsible now than they were five years ago. I do not mind making that one party point, which I think is the only one I have ever made in this speech. The amount paid to individuals in relief is a great deal higher now than then. The amount paid in benefits is higher now than then, in addition to which I believe that the Board has the function of service—service to the community. I also believe that the area officers perform a most useful function in the neighbourhood. I know that my particular area officer does. In fact, if I may make the comparison, my particular area officer is like a district officer in India. People come to him who are not even under his jurisdiction at all and ask him his advice on all kinds of social problems. He is performing a most important function in the neighbourhood, and
it is an education to see him at work. I do not wish to detain the House for very much longer, but I would desire to deal with one or two particular points—first of all, as regards discretion in three particular types of cases. I would like to refer to discretion in regard to rents. The proportion of a quarter is, I am sure, too high a proportion in most parts of the north of England. I am sure that a fifth or a sixth will be necessary there. I will not dwell on that, because I know the Minister recognises that point.
Then I want to say one word on behalf of those black-coated unemployed, most of whom are now receiving public assistance, and who on the appointed day will come in charge of the Board. They are people many of them living in houses which are more expensive than they can afford. Many of them have had to spend their savings. They have been prosperous people in the past, but the collapse of the cotton trade has brought them into penury, and now at a not very youthful age they are going to find themselves on the hands of the Board, who are, I think, much better entitled to look after them than a public assistance committee. I do hope that the Board will see that very special discretion is exercised in regard to these people. In particular, they have for a long time been putting on their backs what should have gone into their stomachs. It is particularly desirable that what has been referred to, I think by the hon. Lady opposite, as the "pots and pans Clause" should be most generously used on behalf of these particular people.
Then I want to say one word about the level of wages in relation to the low-wage earner. There are two classes of unemployed, who, I think, should receive special treatment. They are, first, the non-trade-union workers in some factories both round London and in the north earning very low wages. I hope that the very low wages which some of them are earning now will not be taken as their normal wage, even if they have worked there for as long as a year. I am going to mention names. The Great Universal Stores pays scandalous wages, and people who are in the employment of firms like that should not be penalised by the very low wage scale. There is another class of worker—this time a trade union worker—which equally, I believe, demands special
treatment. It is the class of the big piecer in the cotton spinning industry. It may be that the remedy is a different basis of wages in the whole of that industry, but when the industry was more prosperous the big piecer could expect to be a spinner by the time he was 30, at any rate. It was like a kind of long-drawn-out apprenticeship. When he became a spinner he earned a very good wage. Now there are many big piecers who are over 40 years old, with wives and even large families, and they are not going to throw up their jobs, because they still hope to become spinners, when they will earn very good wages; and if they do fall out of work it is going to be extraordinarily bad luck in the present depressed state of the cotton industries if they are not said to be in "special circumstances." I would like the Minister, or whoever replies, to say something about that case. It is, I believe, an industry which has a wage rate on a very special basis which does demand some special attention.
I will not detain the House any longer. I believe the Minister of Labour and the Board have done their work well. The time they have taken is indicative of the care which has been spent on a long and arduous task. The discretion appears to be a real discretion. The advisory committees have a function, and I believe they will carry out that function with a real regard to its great responsibility in our social life. Finally, I believe that at the same time as we are spending public money with care—and care should be taken that it will not be spent regardless of the need—yet it can be said that we are, in these Regulations, perfecting a system under which there will be less actual hardship in this country than there has ever been before.

We have now been in session for 24 hours, and perhaps I may be permitted to say that the continuous attendance, the good temper which prevails here this afternoon, and what is admitted on all sides to be the highest standard of Debate that perhaps has ever been known during any all-night sitting, are a proof to the enemies of Parliament in this country, and to the enemies of Parliaments outside this country, that whatever happens in any other land Parliament will stand against all the
forces that assail it in this land. I think that if the Government were under any illusion before, they cannot be, after this night's proceedings, under any illusion now about what is going to happen in this country. My friends behind me have this afternoon demonstrated to the Government and to the country that an issue has been raised which really not only affects the unemployed directly but which affects the whole working class of this country; and the Government can be under no illusion now that, as a result of these Regulations, there is a first-class battle coming throughout the country which will settle the destiny of the Government, and which will have, I believe, a very profound effect on our political life generally.
This is no minor issue. From the very first those of us who have been in direct touch with the recipients of allowances and with the unfortunate people who were subject to the means test have been under no illusion as to what was going to be the result of the beginning of the application of this principle. The means test still stands unaltered. The right hon. Gentleman who is going to follow me is well known to be one of the ablest lawyers in the world to-day. One of the things I am going to ask him to face up to is the fact that if these Regulations pass, it is not the memoranda or the Ministers or Board which will administer the law; it is the Regulations, which become the effective part of the law. I suppose that it has been read many times, but I think that it is necessary to repeat often not only for the benefit of Members of this House, but also for the understanding of people outside, the words in the Second Schedule: All the resources of the applicant and of all the other members of the household of which he is a member shall be aggregated. There is no qualification about those words at all, and when hon. Members go into the Division Lobby to-night they will be voting for the naked permanent principle in reference to the unemployed of this country which will have to stand as far as they are concerned for many years to come. There is no reason why we should be debating Regulations here this afternoon. They are not the real reason why we are here. The Government had their Regulations. They passed
them by a big majority in the country and by a big majority in the House, and hon. Members who were present in the House will remember that there was an altogether different approach on the benches opposite on that occasion than there has been on this occasion. There was an air of assurance and certainty that a great system was to be put into operation of which the Regulations were to be the effective legal form.
But that is not the case on this occasion. Something happened to change the country. We left here in December, 1934, with the Government and the Members behind them sure, but we came back in February of 1935 when the House witnessed a demoralisation such as had never before been witnessed. The Regulations broke down. It is significant that we have not had a word from the Minister or from anyone else explaining why the Regulations broke down. If there was one thing necessary to an understanding of the situation it was knowledge of the reasons why the last Regulations broke down. The Government made a searching investigation. It is not necessary for me to find what the right hon. Gentleman said about it. I assure him that I have read it patiently and know something about it. There was a searching investigation into the causes of the breakdown of those Regulations, and we have asked questions as to what was the result of the investigation, and we have had no answer. The Minister made no explanation at all during his speech, and I assert that there was very good reason.
I suggest to the right hon. Gentleman that there are very strong reasons for keeping the report of the investigation into the causes of the breakdown of the last Regulations secret. The right hon. Gentleman has told the House that they are confidential. I suggest that there was evidence in that report of such grave mismanagement, and that there were such serious statements made by representative people as to the effect of the means test that, if the Government had published the report, it would have blown the whole system sky-high. The standstill arrangement cut down the operation of the means test. There are no two opinions about that matter. The means test has not fully operated except during that month. The Government know what
occurred during that month, but the House does not know. Hon. Members on the opposite side of the House are taking a leap in the dark. I am not overstating the case when I say that not only are we discontented with the situation, but there are considerable forces behind the Government who are very deeply disturbed as to what is likely to be the effect of these Regulations. I ask the right hon. Gentleman who is to reply to give us an idea of what occurred and to tell the House that the Government will do what they should have done before, namely, publish the report of the result of the investigations.
Before I begin to take a general view of the Regulations, I want to deal with a speech which has had considerable influence upon the Debate generally, namely, the speech of the right hon. Gentleman the Minister of Health. He made a speech at the end of the first day's Debate in which he made a series of statements. His whole case was built upon the statement that the Government's payments under the Board to the people who came under the Regulations at the present time—the average payment per person per week—is 23s. 7d. or 3s. more than was paid by the Labour Government in 1931. I gave notice to the right hon. Gentleman that I intended to raise this matter, and he has informed me that he has had to go to a very important meeting in another part of the country. His speech seemed to have such an influence upon the Debate, that I felt that it was a thing that ought to be faced. The right hon. Gentleman said that in 1931 the average payment per head to the unemployed was 20s. 7d. under the Labour Government, and that to-day the payment to the unemployed under the Board is 23s. 7d. I think that the right hon. Gentleman opposite will see the flaw in that argument at once. It is so obvious to men who have been trained in the same way as the Minister of Labour. It is that the right hon. Gentleman the Minister of Health, when speaking about the unemployed, was only dealing with one-half of the number of the unemployed, and when he was dealing with the unemployed during the Labour Government of 1931 he was dealing with the average of the whole of the unemployed. The right hon. Gentleman knows very well that if you take the transitional section in 1931,
which is equal to the Unemployment Assistance Board section, the wholly unemployed section is of such a nature as to be weighted for cost to a greater extent than it is over that average.
Per applicant, not per head.

If the right hon. Gentleman had taken the proper average, it would have been the average cost of those under the Board as well as those under Part I of the Act.
