The cost of those under Part I of the Act is 17s. 7d., and the cost of those under the Board is 23s. 7d., and when this is averaged out it works out to exactly the same cost as the average of the payment made in 1931. This is an extremely important matter. I wonder if the right hon. Gentleman is aware that the applicants who receive payments under the Board are actually receiving 6s. per head more than those who come under Part I. Is the House aware of that fact? I am going to make a suggestion to the Government, and I will take the authority for making it. Applicants under the Board cost 6s. per head more, they say—that is the figure which was given—than the people who are on standard benefit under Part I. We will give the Government the 6s., and we will let them keep their Board. We will agree to their waiving their generosity and allowing the people who are under the Board to go back under Part I on standard benefit. There is an offer for you now! I am extremely sorry that the right hon. Gentleman the Minister of Health is not here—he has apologised I know—but I wanted to say one or two things to him. That is an offer, but I will inform the House of this fact before the Government accept the offer. If the Government will put the 620,000 who are under the Board under Part I of the Act and give them standard benefit, these people will receive £1,000,000 more per year in actual payments.
Everyone must admit that that speech had a considerable effect upon the minds of Members. It is rather unfortunate that the right hon. Gentleman was not here to express his regret for the statement, because he built upon it another argument. He began to compare the payments under the scales of public assistance of some local
authorities, and I venture to say that if those authorities had the opportunity of examining his statements, as I have had, they would find that he was just as far wrong in all those statements by which he has misled hon. Members on the other side of the House, as he was when dealing with the other aspect of the matter. It shows a strange attitude of mind on the other side that we should be chided for being parsimonious in Durham and in Glamorgan. Is it not a fact that since Labour took hold in Glamorgan, in Durham, in Monmouthshire and other places, facing a century of arrears which had left a state of things which the sanest persons in every party felt were a disgrace to our civilisation, that we have been more than stigmatised, blackguarded, as wastrels? Now we are told from the other side that we have been niggardly. In 1931 we were assailed for extravagance in the payment of unemployment benefits. Is it not a fact that throughout the country and, indeed, throughout the world, Labour was stigmatised as lacking in ability and as behaving as wastrels, on account of the excessive sums paid to the unemployed? Now the Government boast that they exceed us in extravagance.
It would be interesting to have the finance of this system investigated. What have the Government done? It is true that for some centuries there has been a Poor Law system in operation and a household test in connection with the Poor Law, but it can be said that the people, at any rate in the last century, had the opportunity of selecting their neighbours who would be sitting in judgment on them. At one time they did not have the vote, but in the early part of this century they got the vote. In this new system, under which the recipient is a workman, he is made something less than a Poor Law case. Under the Poor Law the applicant at least had a vote and had his neighbour to sit in judgment on him, but under the present system those who are subjected to it, good workmen, now have to submit to an interrogation, a kind of third degree, by the "G-men" of the Board without having any say at all in the election of those men. That is a very serious principle in the life of this country, and it will have very serious effects as it comes to be more widely understood.
I will say this for the Government and for hon. Members opposite, that I do not think they know what they are doing, I do not think they know the full implications of this system. I am going to assume that there is a social spirit abroad to-day which has developed considerably beyond the view that existed a quarter of a century ago. In this more enlightened day young men who are the product of universities, with their more modern ideas, are taking part in these Debates, and they are going to take part in sitting in judgment on humble working men. Who are these people? I wish all hon. Members could have heard my friend the hon. Member for Llanelly (Mr. J. Griffiths). I have heard many speeches in the 17 years during which I have been in this House, and have read some of the great speeches of the past, but I venture to say that when in the application of a principle or in expressing the country's feelings and sentiments neither Burke nor Bright nor anybody else was superior to my hon. Friend.
It is a pity that all hon. Members could not have heard my hon. Friend the Member for Jarrow (Miss Wilkinson). The hon. Member opposite who said that Jarrow was one of the most lamentable places in the country was right. I remember Jarrow so well because when I was a workman I sometimes walked along the road there in my spare time, and used to delight in looking at the spire of a church in which that great scholar the Venerable Bede lived in ancient times. I used to feel inspired by the thought that I might be walking over the very ground on which he had trod. There can be no inspiration in walking through the streets of Jarrow to-day. It is the people from such areas as Jarrow who are mainly the subject of the means test. Hon. Members opposite say, "But, you see, there is discretion." I have noticed in this Debate that hon. Members opposite have not followed the method which prevailed in the Debates of 1934. We were then given model cases to show how the Regulations would work. All sorts of sums were done so that Members should know exactly just how the Regulations would affect their constituents. Those arithmetical tables were sent out to the country and they influenced the Press. As for the unemployed, I do not sup-
pose that any of them sat up all night to consider how much they were going to get. But through the Press and broadcasting all these pretty little sums were made public. There has been nothing of that sort this time. The right hon. Gentleman himself came nearest of anyone, perhaps, to showing how the new Regulations will apply to certain families. Well, perhaps the nearest approach was made in the very able speech of the hon. Member for Dundee (Mr. Foot), but he was careful to say that in view of the wide discretions he would not guarantee to say accurately what the allowances would be. Yet the discretions are a very important factor—at least we have been told so by the Government, although they are not in the law.
I have a list of these discretions which I propose to read to the House. I took these Regulations and I totalled up all that could be said for the Government in regard to the increase in the scales and the benefits which are supposed to be given. I put that on one side and the debit on the other side. Then I made a list of the discretions. So far as I can see, there are only two things in reference to the discretions which we can be sure about, and that is that the means test stands and that there are going to be wholesale reductions. The Government hesitate about naming a figure for reductions. I will name one. I say that 400,000 people will get their allowances reduced. That is a certainty.

That is more certain than the Board's figure in the Memorandum, because we know that there are some 400,000 people who are under the stand-still arrangement, and that they are to be dealt with. Indeed, the new Regulations have been introduced to deal with them. So the 400,000 under the stand-still arrangement are certain. As for the Minister's estimate of 200,000, he has not a single inch of ground upon which to base it. Let me read some of the discretions. There is a discretion about elderly men living alone; women living alone; men transferred and temporarily out of work; younger men living as lodgers in industrial areas; men living in common lodgings; men living in caravans—I shall have to say something about
those later. I know some of these discretions are intended to work up, but I think some of them are intended to work down—I say "intended" definitely. Then there is a discretion in the case of subletting, and of other members of the household, and the country has been given to understand that though there is no change in the Regulations there is supposed to be a change of heart in the Board. Then there is a discretion as regards the earnings of a person and voluntary payments; about elderly men with long industrial records; about the wage stop; about rural areas and rents in rural areas.
I think the right hon. Gentleman will get into considerable trouble over one of the instances about which the House cheered, the case of a man and wife where there are no available resources. He is going to get into trouble about that. If he reads his first answer given to me when the House cheered he will find that he made a general answer in which he did not make it apply with exceptions, but he has since stated that there are exceptions. There is a discretion in the case of rent, and in special circumstances, and the country generally has jumped to the conclusion that everyone is going to get 6s. allowance. You have all these discretions. What does it mean? Are we legislating for discretion? we passing Regulations to give discretion to certain officers? It must be remembered that discretion can work in another way. If there is a twist in the fortunes of industrial trade these discretions can be used the other way, and what it means is that you are putting great masses of people into the hands of officials for inquiry and investigation.
May I run the risk of being termed sentimental? Everyone knows the instance given in the Memorandum, that a man earning £2 will contribute 12s. to his parents. Almost the same day that I received the Memorandum I went home and found an old workmate there. He is a man of 57 years of age, a type of man who is known as a good pit man, who is proud of his craft, a man of muscle, and who, if it were possible to find work, would be one of the first to be taken on. I had not seen my friend for some time because he has been working in a distant colliery. He has a son 37 years of age, who is a coal hewer. The officer came to investigate the amount
of wages the young man was getting. I want hon. Members to put themselves in the position of this man. He was asked "What are your son's earnings?", and he said "I do not know." Of course, he would not know. Hon. Members on this side of the House who are of an older generation used to give most of their money to their parents. That was the regular system; we regarded it as our duty. I wonder what would have happened to that man, although he was carrying out a public duty, if he had come to the colliery and asked what wages we were earning and what we were giving to our parents. There would have been a great deal of indignation about prying into our concerns. Both father and son were indignant. That young man, under the Regulations, is allowed 28s. of his wages, and he has to work in a three-foot seam, very hot, with sweat pouring off him as though water had been poured over him, perspiration squelching through his boots. He has to work on his belly, and you allow him to keep for food and clothes 28s. The boy is made of the same temper as his father.
I have never asked for sympathy for pit men, but I do ask for decent treatment. We have pride in our work. I wonder whether any hon. Member who supports the Government can in his heart justify that state of things. Here is a young man who looks at his father, a veritable Samson in the district, and is proud of his father's achievements as a workman. He is conscious that his father has to depend upon him and is ashamed of it, and the father feels that he is dependent on the son. They sit down in the house and confer. What would any hon. Member do in those circumstances? I know what I should do. Much as I love home I should leave home, and I should give my parents on the quiet just as much as I could spare. If that man had two sons in the house they would get 28s. each, but the father and mother would get nothing from the Board. That is what these Regulations mean.
I have always said that it is not merely a question of scales and standards, but that the great tragedy is that the manhood of our working men is being affected. This man who sat in my home marched with the troops in 1914, as did his sons
also. They became some of the finest soldiers the world has ever seen, and they faced the best drilled soldiers of Europe. You are not merely cutting down standards of life; you are assailing their manhood. I will say this for the Home Secretary, that much as I differ with him on many things when it comes to dealing with some human things he is very human. One of the best speeches I ever heard on the miner and his work was made by the right hon. Gentleman. I want him to put himself in the position of these men. It is not only the miners but the unemployed throughout the country who are affected.
I want to call the right hon. Gentleman's attention to something which I really do think is scandalous in the Unemployed Assistance Board's report. I ask London Members to look at some of the reports about London. The general impression on the mind of a stranger is that the unemployed are semi-criminals. The officers of the Board are in the main men of fine temper and understanding, and I cannot see how some of them can have associated themselves with some of these reports. There is a report dealing with Durham. Will the House listen to what the area officer says about the kind of people to whom these Regulations will apply: Nearly one-third of the workers of the district are unemployed, and the majority have but little prospect of an early return to work in their own localities. The Board's permanent officers, who came to Durham from all parts of England and Scotland, have acquired a respect for the Durham miner in his trying circumstances. Whilst he may criticise the Board's Regulations he rarely shows any personal animosity towards the Board's officers, and unfortunate incidents are practically unknown. To the layman, although of course his observations can only be superficial, there is little to indicate from the appearance of the children that so many of them have fathers on the dole. They appear well cared for and reasonably well clothed and shod. The children in the smaller towns and villages have a better appearance than those in Sunderland. This applies also to the adults and adolescents, and is due no doubt to the healthier conditions under which they live. The Durham housewife, from sheer necessity, appears to have acquired a technique in household management which enables her to do wonders on a small income. She is helped by the fact that outside Sunderland rents are low and that her husband, if he wishes, can work on an allotment. Many of the wives, however, show signs of the stress and strain of this continual fight against odds.
I want hon. Members to pay particular attention to the next passage: Although with the level of wages in some parts of Durham many hundreds of men, particularly those with large families, can only earn by a week's work a few shillings more than they would receive on the dole yet, even if it adds little to the household income, the men prefer work. That is true of all the people with whom we are dealing in these Regulations. We are putting them under a kind of Poor Law which is worse than the old Poor Law. You put them under what Regulations and scales you like, and they have less power to affect their lot than the people who were under the old Poor Law.
I am very sorry I have taken longer than I expected to do, but I really ought to mention one or two other points. My hon. Friend the Member for Llanelly (Mr. J. Griffiths) gave a very striking instance last night of how compensation works. Half only is excluded. He gave us the picture of a man who had his back broken, and I am sorry to say that they are not isolated cases. I once thought that if a man had his back broken, he could not live, but I have lived to see lots of people living for the rest of their days lying on their backs in that condition. This man had compensation of 25s., and out of that sum, 12s. 6d. goes to maintain the home—out of compensation for a man's life being ruined. There is the case of the trouble of the Secretary of State for War about getting recruits for the Army. How can he expect to get recruits when in our towns and villages our young men come along and tell us how they have got their Reserve pay and that one-half of it has been collared? The British people rise to the miner's case, they so deeply sympathise with him. With an expression of public spirit that has scarcely any parallel in the life of this nation, the people in the most remote places and in all the different ranks of society rise to the miners' case and say that at any rate these men shall get their wages increased, and when, through sheer force of public opinion, men get their wages increased by 6d. a day, at once some of it is taken in order to maintain the household. In my own family I know of a case where the whole amount was taken for that purpose. Service pensions, all kinds of little bits of income affecting the lives of the people come into the home, and they are expecting to do something with the money, and
the net effect is that it is collared by Government representatives.
How can a Government which stands for thrift, which is supposed to stand for the maintenance of the integrity of the family and for those things which will best enable them to get soldiers to defend the country, expect to maintain thrift, to maintain the integrity of family life, to maintain the forces of defence at their proper standard, if it is well known that both civilians and soldiers receive treatment of the kind reflected in these Regulations? We will finish this to-night, as far as the House of Commons is concerned. There will be a division, and we shall be defeated, but the House can take this for granted, that this is not merely an ordinary decision; it is the beginning of the biggest political struggle for many years. This country is going to be riven in two, not because the scales are low, but because the Government, by a new structure in our social services, as we call them, have lowered the old standard, so far as parish relief is concerned, by a system which attacks the very integrity and manhood of the people of this country. I venture to say that if there is one thing more certain than the Vote to-night, it is that the people of this country will destroy this system and those who are responsible for it.

speech.speakername: The SECRETARY of STATE for the HOME DEPARTMENT (Sir John Simon)
speech.p:
The hon. Member for Chester-le-Street (Mr. Lawson), after a speech the sincerity and power of which everyone who heard it will acknowledge, claimed that, considering that we were in a 24-hour session, we had every right to feel justified in the practice of Parliamentary institutions. I gladly acknowledge that, though of course very strong things have been said, and probably some hon. Members may think unfair things, none the less we have lived through this continuous period—and some hon. Members have been here nearly all the time—[HON. MEMBERS: "All the time."]—with a control upon our tempers in which we may all take some satisfaction. I do not suppose it very often happens, or that hon. Members who have been through all-night sittings can think of an occasion where, at the end of such a sitting, there has not been some
real fraying of tempers. When one considers the tremendous importance of this subject, when one considers how intensely people feel about it, how they feel that they are here speaking for others besides themselves, I think the House is entitled to take some satisfaction in the fact that we have come within sight of the end of such a Debate, in which we have been saying very controversial things, without any loss of temper.
There could not have been a better model than the temper in which the hon. Gentleman opposite has just addressed the House, but he made one mistake. He said that he had been cast for the part of opening to-day's Debate. No, Sir, he was cast for the part of opening to-morrow's Debate. There is one thing I should like to say at once, not because it comes in necessarily at this place, but I would not like by some mischance to forget it. The hon. Gentleman referred to the speech made by the Minister of Health at the end of the first day's Debate, and he referred to the passage, which the House will recall and which is to be found in the OFFICIAL REPORT at the bottom of column 400, in which my right hon. Friend said: I hope that the House realises that since the Unemployment Assistance Board took over this matter, the average payment per head has risen from 21s. 10d. to 23s. 7d., and I must also remind hon. Gentlemen opposite when they make these charges that, compared with that in July, 1931, when Miss Bondfield was Minister of Labour, and when the hon. Gentleman was associated with her and the Labour Government, they were paying 20s. 7d. per head, or 3s. less than the proposed scale which is now being put before the House."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 21st July, 1936; col. 400, Vol. 315.] The first correction, which I think is understood, is that the figures per head quoted by the Minister are not the averages per head but per applicant. The hon. Gentleman just now thought there was a correction that ought to be made of much more importance in the 20s. 7d. I am dealing with rather technical things. I admire the hon. Member's mastery of them, but I think I understand the point, and I am trying to state it as I am informed it really is. The figure of 20s. 7d., which was quoted in this passage by the Minister of Health, was not, as the hon. Gentleman thought just now, the average for all cases. If you put the payments
to applicants under the head of standard benefits together with the payments to other people under the head of transitional benefit and made a general average, you would get a figure, but not the figure of 20s. 7d. which the hon. Gentleman thought might be the case. If I remember it rightly, if you were to add standard benefit to transitional benefit, the two things together would tend to bring the figure down, partly because the average payment of transitional benefit tends to be higher than for standard benefit because transitional benefit was not payable to persons between the ages of 16 and 18 and partly because, on the whole, there would be a smaller proportion of women, who were in general paid at lower rates for transitional benefit. If, therefore, you added together what was paid for standard benefit and what was paid for transitional benefit, and divided it by the total number of applicants, you would get an average, but it would not be the average of 20s. 7d. The average, I am informed, in July, 1931, would be 18s. 4d., and it is not the case, as the hon. Gentleman supposed, that the 20s. 7d. is the average for all cases. The 20s. 7d. is the average for transitional benefit alone in the month of July, 1931, and that of course, was before the later part of that year, when the temporary cuts in payments were introduced. I hope I have stated it intelligibly.
Now I want to make some observations of a rather more general character on this very important subject. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Labour will, I understand, reply to the whole Debate later, and he is more fitted to deal with special points than I am. The first point of a general kind that I want to make is this: It will not be disputed, of course—nobody who has attended the Debate will deny—that in this prolonged discussion, this almost non-stop discussion, the main attack, the centre and heart of the attack, has been on the means test. There is no doubt about that at all, and certainly I make no sort of complaint about it. I am only viewing the Debate as a whole. Indeed, I see that the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Wakefield (Mr. Greenwood) has returned to the House, and I recall how, when he opened the attack on the first
day, he said that as far as he was concerned he did not want to enter into the details of the Regulations themselves, and he was as good as his word. His main speech dealt with the more fundamental issues.
Perhaps the right hon. Gentleman will not mind my saying that there was a phrase near the beginning of his speech which I find it a little difficult to understand. He sought to excuse the terms of the Opposition Amendment on the Paper, which did not contain any reference to the means test, on the ground that the means test could not be mentioned in any Amendment put on the Paper, and indeed he went so far as to say, I do not in any sense mean it in a censorious way, that had they done so, they would never have got it past the Clerk at the Table. It is not for me or any Member of the House to lay down the rules of Order or the limits within which an Amendment may be framed, but I should think the right hon. Gentleman, on reflection, will probably agree that as a matter of fact the Clerks at the Table have nothing whatever to do with the judgment of Amendments put down on the Paper. That is a matter for higher authority but I do not myself understand why it would not be possible to include a reference to the means test in the official Amendment.

It is true that, in the course of the Debate, I referred to the Clerk at the Table. I realised that it was quite improper, it was unfair to Mr. Speaker and to the Clerk, because Mr. Speaker bears the final responsibility. It is unfair to assume that any final responsibility would rest upon the Clerk at the Table. I do not want to argue the merits of the case about the means test, but I should like to make a full apology to Mr. Speaker and to the Clerk at the Table for the statement that I made—which I ought not to have made—under certain provocation, knowing quite fully that Mr. Speaker is the ultimate authority.

I am glad to be the innocent means of so admirable an explanation. We quite understood the right hon. Gentleman. He was merely explaining that he proposed to concentrate his attack on the main question of the means test, which has so much dominated the Debate. It is important for all of us to have this clearly in mind
when we discuss this subject hereafter in our constituencies, or when we deal with it, as we shall have to, in individual cases. After all, the first thing really is to look at the scales themselves and to realise that the majority of applicants who are householders or members of a household are not persons who are regarded, even under the existing Regulations, as having resources available towards their needs. The majority of persons interested in the Regulations are not persons to whom any means test can or does apply. That does not in the least excuse us from looking very carefully to see how the remainder are dealt with. In answer to a question on Tuesday the Parliamentary Secretary said that the households in which resources are available and are brought into account are about a third of the whole. Under the new Regulations they will, in fact, be less than a third, because the operation of the means test has been limited. My hon. and gallant Friend said: It is estimated that under the existing Regulations the resources are regarded as available towards the needs of the applicant in about one-third of the total cases in which the applicant is the householder or is living as a member of the household. This proportion includes cases in which the available resources are possessed by the applicant."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 21st July, 1936; col. 257, Vol. 315.]

There are other figures. The Minister of Labour issued a document showing in three columns the number of persons receiving standard benefit, unemployment assistance and transitional payment. The people on transitional payment are 400,000, therefore 400,000 people are being protected by the stand-still arrangement and come under the means test.

The hon. Member is dealing with quite a different point. The question is what proportion of those who are going to be affected by the new Regulations will be affected because of any means test that is applied. No means test can affect a householder or member of a household if he is not regarded as having any resources. I believe it is correct to say that something like two-thirds are in that position, and less than a third will be found to be people in whose case the application of the means test is relevant. That involves two results. In the first place, if that is the case, we really ought to spend a minute
or two, when we survey the thing as a whole, in considering the scales themselves, apart altogether from any influence upon them of the means test Regulations.
The second result is this: Those people who come for assistance under these Regulations and have no resources at all, or to whom no means test applies, surely are not the people who should be forgotten. They are the people who, unless they get relief by the determination of the Board, cannot look for assistance anywhere else. I quite understood the hon. Member's point just now about the son who wants to help his father but does not like to be made to; but what about the people who have not any one who could help them, who fall within the scheme of the means test? Those are the people we have to think about under the scales. It is no use saying you protest against the whole thing because of the means test unless you first realise that two people out of every three that we have been talking about are people to whom the means test is quite irrelevant, because they have no resources at all.
A number of changes have been made in the scales themselves. The Minister gave a list of them—I think altogether seven. We are entitled, first, to point out that every change that has been made is in the direction of improving the treatment. There is nothing in these new Regulations as far as the arrangements of the scales are concerned, which is a change to the disadvantage of the applicant. We may say that, none the less, the scales are inadequate, but it is well to remember that, as regards two-thirds of the people, the changes in the scales, as compared with the previous scales, are to the advantage of the applicant. I am the more impressed with the fact that the scales themselves have attracted comparatively little attention in the Debate when I consider this circumstance. One of the very important things in the Regulations is the provision that has been made about rent.
Has the right hon. Gentleman seen the figure on page 9 of the Memorandum, from which it appears that the numbers of people with resources and with none are just about 50–50?

I took the precaution of getting very carefully informed about
this, but I will have that examined. We were all very much alive to this question of rent 18 months ago. Everyone had to watch very closely the operation of the rent rule. I am encouraged to think that the real reason why the Debate has concentrated so much upon the means test is because, if it were not for that, I do not think that reasonable and sensible people, realising what is possible to be done, would be prepared to raise a great agitation about the scales themselves.

Is the right hon. Gentleman prepared to deny that the full scale for householders with children to support is totally inadequate to provide the bare minimum necessaries of life as calculated by any scientific authority, even if the family spend not a penny on anything but bare physical necessaries?
I hope the hon. Lady will not make a speech.
I was only wanting to make my question plain.
I hope the hon. Lady will have an opportunity of taking part in the Debate. I really must be allowed, although I gave way, to present what I am going to say in due order.
rose—
rose—
The right hon. Gentleman gave way.
I am not sure that I understood that that was so. If the right hon. Gentleman chooses to do so, the hon. Lady may intervene.

The right hon. Gentleman has suggested that the lack of criticism of the scales themselves in reference to people with no resources implies that the House is satisfied with the scales. I wish to ask him whether he considers the scales adequate for bare physical necessaries in the case of families with three or four children.

I shall, before I sit down, deal with that point, but having twice given way to the hon. Lady I should like first to go on with the case which I was making. I am most anxious not to do anything to cause confusion in the House, and I desire briefly, and I
believe uncontroversially, to make some remarks about the means test. I cannot hope in those remarks to secure the approval of everybody, but at the same time I think anybody who has what he believes to be a good case should not be unwilling to hear another point of view, so long as it is fairly stated. I propose to try to express my view to the House fairly and I shall not mind being corrected if I am found to be stating it unfairly. I think it will be found, on a fair analysis, that the question of the means test is not really one of abstract principle, something between light and darkness or between right and wrong. I think it will be found to be a question of degree and of fair play and of common sense. We shall, no doubt, differ acutely as to what is fair play and as to what is common sense.
There is no such thing as fair play in connection with the means test.

I cannot help feeling that I shall be able to show the House, if the House is kind enough to follow my argument, that the way I have just indicated is the proper way in which to regard this question. I gathered from the speech made earlier in the Debate by the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury) that he did not regard this so much as a question of principle, as a question of examining what is actually done. I will tell the House one reason why I think so. All assistance is given or should be given only to those who are in need. That is not merely what is in the Statute of 1934; it is the groundwork, the basis, upon which relief to persons who cannot otherwise maintain themselves is given. No one would suggest that public money should be distributed without regard to means, and there is no better known Socialist principle—and I do not quote it in any jeering spirit because I think that in its proper application it is a good principle—than the principle of "to each according to his need."
Why not apply that principle?

Let us see whether it is not applied reasonably and let us see what is the class of case which decides this issue. If the need of the applicant
in cases of this sort is not a suitable measure of the relief to be given, there is nothing to be done but to say that you have nothing to do with need in the giving of relief, and then two results follow. One result, of course, is an appalling waste of public money. The second result is this—and I am surprised that hon. Members opposite have not given more attention to this consideration. If you do not, at least, try to apply the relief in accordance with need, grave injustice will be done as between two applicants whose needs vary widely. Many of us who have given careful study to this subject know very well that it is a source of grievance, if it is possible for applicant A to say, "This is all I am getting and yet applicant B, into whose house all sorts of other resources are going which I have not got, is getting the same amount."
That happens with standard benefit.
Why do you not apply that to the Royal Family?

When you are dealing with standard benefit, which is the result of insurance, nobody suggests that this question arises, but when you go beyond that and come to the question of how assistance is to be given to those who are in need, not under the terms of an insurance contract but because they are in need—then I submit to the House it is different. It is not very difficult to see that there is not some abstract principle which either condemns the whole thing or, on the other hand, automatically blesses some particular arrangement in the Regulations. You have to look at the case and see, as a matter of degree, of fair play and of common sense, what is the proper thing to do. The question of need is not simply limited to cases of this kind. My hon. Friends opposite have talked about its possible application in other cases and I quite understand that lists of cases of all sorts might be suggested. [HON. MEMBERS: "De-rating!"] Let us then take two or three cases in which in fact this is done. I am not going to state them other than quite un-provocatively.
Get ready for a "belt" now.

Take the case of the non-contributory old age pensions. I quite agree that there is a difference when you come to pensions which are on a contributory basis. If a man has contributed he is entitled to whatever he has contributed for. But in the case of the non-contributory old age pension I am an old enough Member of this House to remember when the scheme was introduced and it has always been the case, under all Governments, that the pension is paid only where the means of the applicant do not exceed certain limits fixed by Statute. I can remember an occasion when I sat oh the other side of the House and when Mr. Snowden, as he then was, was Chancellor of the Exchequer in a Labour Government, and the question arose of amending the Old Age Pensions Act. This point was raised and very acutely debated, not indeed with the idea that old age pensions should be given to everybody who put in a claim, but with the idea of seeing whether it would not be possible to devise a system by which you could avoid these inquiries which, I agree, are very irritating if not made with tact. The point is, however, that nobody ever suggested that non-contributory old age pensions should be distributed broadcast without any reference to means.
Yes, they did!
The Labour party did so.
They are paid now without any means test. A contributory pensioner gets the pension at 70 and has no means test.

I do not know why the hon. Member should take the trouble to make that interruption. That is part of the scheme of contributory old age pensions and I was dealing with non-contributory pensions.
The second example which I propose to give is one which has been mentioned in the House already, and I do not mention it with any desire to reproach any particular local authority. That is not what is in my mind at all. Take the practice commonly followed by local authorities empowered by the Housing Acts of the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Wakefield (Mr. Greenwood) to grant rebates of rents on municipal houses to
people who are found on investigation to be too poor to pay the proper rent. That is nothing whatever except an illustration, and a common-sense illustration, of the necessity of a test of means in dealing with social legislation of that kind. Take, further, the Midwives Bill which we had before us the other day and which, with the general co-operation of the House, introduces a new and improved system in connection with the midwifery service. That Bill provides that the midwife is entitled to a fee and that that fee is to be collected from the patient, or from her husband, and we included this proviso: Provided that if the authority is satisfied that the persons from whom the fees are recoverable cannot reasonably, having regard to their financial circumstances be required to pay more than a part of the fees or any part of the fees whatsoever it may grant a remission.
A wrong principle.

It may be that in a future form of society which the hon. Member opposite would prefer that will not happen, but that is not the point I am making now. The point which I am making now, and I think the House will see its relevance, is that if we can manage to look at the question apart from its tragedy and apart from the anxieties involved, we ought to be prepared to admit that the application of a test of need or of means, in cases where social legislation is coming to the relief of people who are poor, is really essential if you are to have proper regulation.
I venture to give one other instance which is very much to the point because it is an instance from a Labour Party Bill carried through this House by a Labour Party Minister, in the days of the late Labour Government. I refer to the Labour Government's Bill dealing with the school-leaving age, and I would invite hon. Members who, the moment they hear the words "means test," work themselves into a state of great indignation, to consider the provisions of that Bill carried through the House of Commons by a Labour Government, with the support of the Labour party and with the support of others in the House as well. It provided for the raising of the school
age with maintenance allowances. That Bill—Sir Charles Trevelyan's Bill—made provision, not that those allowances should be given to every parent whose child was kept on at school but that they should be given only to those parents who satisfied a means test, and a Schedule to the Bill gave the form of claim for those allowances. It was not merely the case under that Bill that before the maintenance allowance was granted, it was necessary to be satisfied that the father of the child had not the resources necessary. It was also necessary to be satisfied on the same point as regards the mother of the child. If hon. Members refer to that Bill of 1931 they will find there the plainest example of a means test applying not to one parent only but to both.
Will the right hon. Gentleman not agree that that provision in the Bill was a concession made by the minority Labour Government for the support of others in this House?
I must contradict the hon. Gentleman quite frankly. I was in the House at the time. As a matter of fact, that particular provision was opposed by some of those who sat on the Liberal benches—
We opposed it.
Will the right hon. Gentleman tell us whether in that Bill anything is taken away from anybody and put into the family pool?

The hon. Gentleman does not seem to follow the argument. Perhaps he will have a little patience. All I am saying at the moment, and I claim to have proved it, is that there is not in the idea of a test of means, when you are dealing with social legislation giving relief, something which in its nature requires it to be condemned offhand as an evil thing. It is a question of degree, of method and of reason. There was a reference to this subject in the course of the powerful speech of the hon. Member for Caerphilly (Mr. Morgan Jones). I thought that the illustration he took of the payment of Members of Parliament was not a very well chosen one. He suggested that because in the payment of Members of Parliament a distinction was not made between those who were wealthy and those who were not, our practice was contrary
to the practice of the means test. Whatever else is a good argument, that is not.
A Member of Parliament's £400 a year is classed for the purposes of Income Tax as emoluments of office, and that is what it is. Under the provisions of the Income Tax law the Treasury is empowered to allow deductions from salary or emoluments of office where it can be shown that the amount of deduction that is claimed represents expenses wholly, exclusively and necessarily incurred in the performance of duties. In the days before travelling vouchers were issued, it was the proper thing for Members to set against their £400 a year their expenses for travelling to their constituencies. The sum of £100 was fixed in the first instance as the amount of the deduction, but if any individual Member can show that his expenses connected with being a Member of Parliament amount to more than £100, an increased deduction is allowed. Although there are many cases on the border-line that can be discussed, this is not one of them. When the payment of Members was first discussed the question was seriously considered whether we should leave it to the individual Member to apply for the payment. It was felt, however, and I think that it will be the general feeling of the House, that we should not desire to put our poorer friends in that position and that it would be wrong to have to make application. I have kept the House longer than I meant before I came to the actual point of the means test.

I will not controvert the right hon. Gentleman's argument on that point now, but will he address himself to the other point I put, namely, that the grant of children's allowances under the Income Tax was made to rich and poor regardless of any means test?

I hope that I shall be excused from discussing that now, but I think that there is an argument to be made about it. The question now is about the means test in these Regulations and the first observation I would wish to make is one which I shall be grateful if hon. Members will consider maturely. Take what is called "personal means," the resources which the
applicant himself happens to have. A man who has lost his job may be the owner of cottages which are paying to him a small weekly revenue in the form of rent. Another man may have an investment in some form or another. The first thing I would ask hon. Members to consider is whether they really take the view that, as regards personal resources, it is to be laid down that no means test should be applied? I should have thought that that was an impossible contention.
Why do you keep talking about the wealthy workers?
Why does not the means test apply to the shipping subsidy?
I do not think that I am saying things which ought to cause interruptions.
Talk about your own class, the parasite class, and not the working class.
Why not apply it to beef and everything else? Why should the poor be made to suffer?
Hon. Members who have already had an opportunity of making their views known in long speeches to the House, might at least give the Government spokesman an opportunity to reply.

I am asking the House to take the view that in giving public money to meet the needs of people who have no contractual right to receive a particular sum, it is surely right to take their personal resources into account. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury), in the famous Debate on the means test in November, 1931, drew this distinction quite clearly. He has always been opposed to a means test which brings in the resources of others in the family. I am speaking now of the personal resources of the applicant.
Only 7.1 per cent. of the total have resources.

Then it will not take long to dispose of them. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley said:
As to the means test, the hon. Member knows as well as I do what is our attitude on the subject. I am not prepared to give people money year after year without knowing what is their own personal position; that is to say that if a person has gone out of ordinary benefit and has means of his own to maintain himself, I am not prepared to pay him State money."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 13th November, 1931; col. 446, Vol. 259.] Whoever may be the persons for whom he is pleading, I submit that that is a reasonable view.
Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that that expression of opinion is the private opinion of the right hon. Member for Bow and Bromley only?

I was not doing anything but quote that opinion, and I am saying—and I am appealing to the good sense of the House—that it seems a very sensible opinion. I am perfectly prepared to accept that others may not agree. I quote it because no one will accuse the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley with being a hard-faced man grinding down the poor. He at least pointed out what seems to me extremely good sense, that not only is the means test as such not always objectionable, but that a personal means test in connection with the relief of a person's needs is necessary—[Interruption.] We listened to the speeches of hon. Gentlemen in complete silence, and while I do not mind interjections, I hope that I may be allowed to state my case.
Now I pass to the case of the husband and wife. Take the case of a husband who is in work and who may be earning substantial wages, who has provided a home where he and his wife live; if the wife has lost her employment, say, from a mill, is it really to be said that in determining the need of the wife for purposes of assistance no regard is to be had to the fact that she lives and has always lived since marriage in the home of her husband which the husband had provided? Can a more absurd proposition be imagined? Let us contrast the position of a single woman who has lost her employment at the same time, it may be from the same mill, who is short of the same sum of money, and who applies for a decision as to the relief of her needs. Is the need of such a woman who is living without any assistance, who has no husband, who has not his protection or home, the same
as the need of the married woman? Surely no one can maintain that that is a reasonable view.
It follows, it seems to me, that this question of the means test is not really a question of fundamental principle. It is a question how to frame it, how far you can go, what it is reasonable to include and what it is reasonable to exclude. In my view it is quite right to reduce the range of people—the circle inside the household—who ought to be treated in that way, and these Regulations do that, and do it in a very effective way. What I cannot understand is how it should be thought to be a breach of sound and humane principles to treat certain members of the family who in fact live under the same roof, as persons who in certain circumstances should be regarded as making a contribution to the upkeep of the home. I will give an illustration which, although a small one, shows what I mean. When the head of the household falls out of work and applies for a determination and gets the scale allowance, one of the things he gets is the allowance for the whole of the rent of the house. He does not get some fraction of the rent, but the whole of the rent.
Who says he will get all the rent?

He does not get some fraction suitable for his personal occupation. He gets an allowance in respect of the rent of the whole house, and if we did not turn to those who are in the house and regard them as bearing some part of the burden, then in fact we should be using public money to subsidise everybody else in the house in respect of rent. Consequently, it is clear to me that, when one analyses the position, it is true to say that the means test is something which has not to be dealt with in an abstract way, whether in denunciation or defence, but that the whole thing depends upon the consideration of the schemes, rules and the framework within which, and the extent to which, it is applied. As it is, I claim that these new Regulations apply it fairly. I think it is right to draw a sharp distinction between unmarried sons, daughters, brothers and sisters living in the household as part of it, and others. This is the first time the distinction is drawn in this matter between an unmarried son living
at home and a married son. It is one which I think everyone might recognize as being very fairly made. It makes an enormous difference if one recognises—

I put a very definite question to the right hon. Gentleman on this matter. Are the Regulations or the Memorandum the law? It is very important that he should tell the House where in the Regulations there is any difference made between any members of the household.

I appreciate that the point made by the hon. Member is a very important one. I thought it was more or less one of the main points of his speech, and I assure him that I will deal with it quite separately, and give him an answer. To continue my remarks, I quite understand the arguments which have been made, and I have no doubt sincerely made—but for my part I cannot accept the proposition that, when an unmarried son is earning wages, is bringing those wages into the home, and his father is out of work, it is something monstrous and wrong to regard that son as a person from whom a certain contribution should come. The hon. Gentleman told us his own experience, and let me tell him it is the experience of other people besides himself. Some of us know very well what it is to help one's father, but it is true that it is not nearly so pleasant if it is not done by good will, by mere family feeling and privately. But we must have Regulations which make a proper test of need, and there is no way by which that can be done unless you make an estimate of the resources of the household, make what is thought to be proper provision for their personal requirements, and regard them as to that extent contributing the balance.
For my part, I really do not believe that the country would desire to regard people in that relationship, in the same house, in the same family, living under the same roof, eating at the same table, as though they were strangers to the household. These Regulations are not laying down some artificial, strange, unnatural relationship; they are not trying to make people responsible for others for whom they have no responsibility. There is not a son in the House who would not repudiate the idea that he has not a responsibility for his father when his father is in need. It is necessary to put
these things in the Regulations, otherwise how could the means test be applied at all?
Why do you do it when you say that no son requires it?
Why does the King not support his mother.

The right hon. Gentleman is the head of the Department responsible for Workmen's Compensation. He is responsible for the Act of Parliament which fixes Workmen's Compensation apart from earnings, and without any distinction as to whether the injured man is married or single, has dependants or not. May I ask him how he justifies the taking part of that compensation from a man and adding it to the family pool?

That has been mentioned again and again in the Debate, and I do not intend to be diverted. I maintain that I am showing the House that, as a matter of fact, some test of needs to be applied by reference to resources on the one hand and personal requirements on the other, is necessary and natural, and the only question for debate is whether it is fairly done in the present case. There were two questions of a special kind about lodgers which were asked by several hon. Members, and I will deal with those questions now. First, it was asked why the Board should not, by the Regulations, exclude from contribution to the needs of the applicant some members of the household by description? The answer is that to do that would not be in accordance with the 1934 Act, which requires that the members of the household should be dealt with in the way which I have described, although, of course, the amount of the assessment is entirely to be dealt with by the terms of the Regulations.
One could not, in accordance with the Act, treat members of the household who really are members of the household as though they were excluded from the possibility of contribution. What can be done is to devise the system in such a way as to secure that in certain cases the contribution will, in fact, be not different from the contribution that would be made by a boarder. That leads to the second question which was asked, and to which a wrong answer was given by the hon. Gentleman who put it. He said that
under these Regulations every lodger in a house must be treated as a member of the household. That is not so. I understand that the position is that a lodger is a person who is not a member of the household, whether related or not, and you may very easily have lodgers living under the roof who would not be regarded as members of the household. Let me give an example. A girl going to live with her married sister and agreeing to pay a reasonable sum to her married sister for board and lodging, would not be generally regarded as a member of her brother-in-law's household. If, for example, she were unemployed, she could make an application to the Board on her own behalf, and no part of the resources of her brother-in-law's household would be set off against her needs. She would be a lodger in the house, but not a member of the household. If she were earning wages, no account would be taken of her wages for the needs of the household if her brother-in-law were out of work. I have made that statement because I think there was a little misapprehension on the matter.
As I have said more than once, it is not a sound position to attack these Regulations because they include a means test, or even a means test which brings into account somebody other than the applicant. They could be perfectly well criticised if it could be shown that the net had been drawn too wide, that the personal allowances were too small, that the treatment does not fairly correspond to the facts of life and to the actual relations of the family. It is my submission to the House that if one looks at the Regulations fairly, they cannot be attacked on abstract grounds, but have to be attacked because of the details they contain. In every respect they are an improvement on the earlier Regulations. I am making no point of comparison with the treatment of this or that case, or this or that authority, but on that point I would venture to say to the hon. Gentleman opposite that for once he most seriously misunderstood the way the argument went. He said, "Here is this Government, which has sometimes criticised the lavishness and extravagance in certain areas, now reproaching those areas with stinginess." That is not the point at all. The point is this—
The Minister said that Glasgow was being mean. You have got to deal with that.
I am anxious—

I have no wish to be offensive to you or to anybody, but when a Minister gets up at that Box and states a deliberate untruth, he ought to be told that he is not telling the truth and that he is lying.
The hon. Member is aware that the word he used is absolutely unparliamentary. I must ask him to withdraw it.

If a Minister gets up and says something which is not true, am I not entitled to tell him that? The Minister said deliberately that Glasgow had been guilty of mean conduct. That is what the Minister said in regard to a case. The Home Secretary is saying that the Minister did not say that. Am I not entitled to say that he is not stating the truth?

The hon. Member knows perfectly well that he is entitled to say that something is not in accordance with the facts. To accuse any Member of the House of telling a lie on the Floor of the House is absolutely unparliamentary. I must ask the hon. Member to withdraw it.

I have endeavoured for years to carry out respect for the Chair, but I have no intention of doing other than saying that that man was guilty, and knowingly so, of stating a thing that he knew not to be true.
I must ask the hon. Member to withdraw the statement which he has made that the right hon. Gentleman has told a lie. Otherwise it will be my duty to name him to the House.

Your duty is to name me when you carry out your orders. It will be moved that I be named. Do not get outside your rules. [HON. MEMBERS: "Order!"] You are still the Deputy-Speaker, the custodian of the rights of the House. You should have read your rules, and should know them. Do not be a Tory, a partisan in the Chair. The chairman knows neither this side nor that. You are a partisan now.
Order!

The hon. Member knows perfectly well that there is no question here of party or anything of that kind. It is my duty to see that certain definite rules of the House are observed. The hon. Member, in circumstances which have affected him very much, has been guilty of a breach of a well-known rule and I must ask him to withdraw.
Colfox said 50 times worse things and nothing was ever done to him, and he never withdrew. It is sheer partisanship. Hundreds of them have done it time and again.
I will give the hon. Member one more chance, which I hope he will take, of withdrawing the statement which he has made against the right hon. Gentleman the Home Secretary.

I do not feel that I have had, even from you, Sir, decency in treatment. I feel that what I said is true. If I said anything untrue in this House I would withdraw it—I have done it before—and beg the hon. Member's pardon. On this occasion I think I am saying a thing that is true and unfortunately I cannot withdraw.
I must name the hon. Member for Gorbals (Mr. Buchanan) for defying the authority of the Chair.
I beg to move, "That Mr. Buchanan be suspended from the service of the House."
rose—
Are we going to have robbers and murderers of the working class, and murderers of the unemployed—

[HON MEMBERS: "Sit down."] I am not going to sit down. I have sat here during the night and heard what some people have said on these benches, and never a word was said about it. I heard the Minister of Labour make his statement. I would rather go out of public life than do what he did to the unemployed. I hope Members of the Labour party are going to put an end to this Debate to-day. I hope we are going to have every Member of the Labour party refusing to allow business to go forward in this House. I join with my comrades and say it was a deliberate lie on the right hon. Gentleman's part. I am not going to sit here and allow business to proceed in this House so long as this sort of thing is going on. I want also to say that Members on the other side of the House would none of them defend the means test but they always say that Members above the Gangway are the parents of it. [HON. MEMBERS: "Sit down."] I am not sitting down; I have a few more things to say—[Interruption]—
Owing to grave disorder having arisen, I suspend the Sitting for a quarter of an hour.

p.i: Sitting suspended at Seven Minutes after Six o'Clock.

Mr. DEPUTY-SPEAKER reported that the Secretary of State for the Home Department had moved "That Mr. Buchanan be suspended from the service of the House."
Question put, That Mr. Buchanan be suspended from the service of the House.
The House divided: Ayes, 248; Noes, 53.

May I rise to a point of Order? Who is responsible for summoning an additional force of police in the Inner Lobby, on the assumption, I gather, that the hon. Member for Gorbals (Mr. Buchanan) would not withdraw when ordered by you to do so? Is not such conduct so indiscreet as to undermine your authority with the House?
The police are there only in the ordinary course of their duties.
No, Sir. There are 10 additional policemen in the Lobby.
The authorities of the House have to keep order in the House.
The Home Secretary wants to defend himself.
Mr. DEPUTY-SPEAKER reported that the hon. Member for Camlachie (Mr. Stephen) had persistently obstructed the Business of the House.
I have to name the hon. Member for the Camlachie Division (Mr. Stephen) for persistently obstructing the Business of the House.

speech.p: I must direct the hon. Member to withdraw from the House.

On a point of Order, may I ask, when the sitting is still suspended in your absence, if both statements by the individuals concerned are considered by you, and whether the statement made by the Home Secretary which caused the interruption, was put to you since, in your absence you did not hear the whole of that speech, which was a most insinuating and irritating one. There are few methods whereby you can
raise the ire of a human being, and I know of no one more able to do it than the Home Secretary by putting it in that smuglike way of his. I want to know whether it is the duty of the Speaker to hear what was said leading up to suspension, and also the full verbatim report of what was said, because the Chairman in your absence called for suspension.

Under Standing Order 17, the hon. Member will see that if the House is sitting and I have had to leave the Chair, the Deputy-Speaker
reports to me and I put the Question forthwith. When the House is in Committee the Chairman reports to me and I put the Question forthwith without any Debate whatever.
rose—
The right hon. Gentleman we all know is a liar.
The hon. Member must know that that is unparliamentary language.
I am aware of that, Mr. Speaker, I am sorry.
rose—

On a point of Order, I want to know if you have two rules for different Members of this House. I want to know whether there is a rule for the Independent Labour party and a rule for the Labour party, and that if two Members each call the Home Secretary a liar whether they are not both guilty of the
same offence; and I want to know if you are showing discrimination in the Chair.
Shall we go and ask our colleagues to come back?
The hon. Member for Shettleston (Mr. McGovern) must know that his remark was unparliamentary.
Then I say that the Home Secretary is a damned liar.
I hope the hon. Member will withdraw that remark.
I certainly will not.
Then I must name the hon. Member for disregarding the authority of the Chair.
I beg to move, "That Mr. McGovern be suspended from the service of the House."
Question put.
The House divided: Ayes, 262; Noes, 11.

speech.p: I must ask the hon. Member to withdraw from the House.
Does the hon. Member refuse to withdraw from the House?
Does the hon. Member refuse to withdraw from the House?
Then I must call upon the Sergeant at Arms to remove the hon. Member.
The hon. Member withdrew when summoned by the Sergeant at Arms to obey Mr. SPEAKER'S direction.
Question again proposed, "That the word 'be' stand part of the Question."

I have promised the hon. Gentleman who spoke before me to deal with an important point which he stressed. He said, "After all, when the Debate is over and the Regulations are through, where is the guarantee that the Board's determination will in effect correspond to the amount now given? What is the remedy if it turns out that individuals get harsher treatment from the Board than the House intends?" The answer in part is to be found under the system of appeal, and there is a second answer which I would like to give also before I sit down. Under Section 39 of the Act of 1934 a person has the right to appeal to the appeal tribunal. There is a proviso. [Interruption.] I will refer to it in a moment.
Why not refer to it now? The right hon. Gentleman's statement is absolutely misleading.

If the hon. Gentleman will listen to me he will find, as a matter of fact, that there is a proviso, and that I am just going to read it. The appeal tribunal contains a workman's representative, a Board's representative and an independent chairman. The system of the appeal tribunal is, on the whole, working well. [Interruption.]
It is not true.
The Minister knows nothing about it.

Only this morning I was speaking to the chairman of one of the appeal tribunals, and he gave an account of his tribunal which certainly justified what I have said. [Interruption.] The proviso limits the appeal to cases where the chairman gives leave, but the chairman will give leave where there is reason to doubt whether the determination is in accordance with the Regulations, or if there are other special circumstances. I recall that the hon. Member for Jarrow (Miss Wilkinson) made the point in the speech which she delivered earlier in the day. If the House will look at the Regulations they will see that they have been carefully drawn to secure as far as possible that where a discretionary departure from the strict rule is authorised, the decision thus reached can be appealed against. There is the First Schedule 1 (2, a) which deals with the reduction of basic rent, and the other is regulation IV, 1 (2, b). There is, however, a second security, and that is as important as the first. It is true that a single individual may in some cases not feel prepared or be able to appeal against the officer's determination, but if a practice grew up under which harsher measures were applied in the exercise of discretion than Parliament intended and we have explained, there is an effective remedy in the form of Parliamentary question, debate and challenge.

Will the right hon. Gentleman be good enough to explain if these powers reside in the Regulations, why all the operations of this machinery for revision of determinations made by the Area officers have failed to yield concessions of as much as ½ of one per cent. on the cases submitted to the tribunals?

The White Paper issued by the Board goes so far as to give under the Board's signatures illustrations of what is the extent to which they would be prepared to recognise the discretion. That is a very strong security.
I have an area where there is a large number of men who have been idle for 12 years. Is the whole of that body to be regarded as one possessing special circumstances?
Answer.
I really cannot answer that question.

Surely when an hon. Member puts a serious question he is entitled to a proper answer by the Minister speaking on behalf of the Government? If that is not so, what is the use of any of us attending the Debate?
If I do not know the full answer which should be given to a question suddenly put, I prefer to say so. [Interruption.] The Parliamentary Secretary is going to deal with these special points.
Let him deal with them and you sit down.

The Board's area officers have 18 months of experience, and the situation is different from 18 months ago. The Board's officers are mostly acquainted with their localities. [Interruption.] We must maintain the independent position of the Board, and while shielding the chairman of the appeal tribunal from improper pressure it may be confidently said that the machinery we are now devising provides for a flexible administration.
How do you know that?

The Board has gone so far as to issue a White Paper in which in advance of the Debate they set out what are the sorts of variations from the standard which they would regard as acceptable recommendations. I will not recapitulate my broken argument. I presented it to the House, and I think that there are Members who feel its force. Of all the incidents in this three days' Debate nothing is perhaps more surprising than this: that in the
whole of the three days' Debate I do not believe there has been any reference in any quarter to this point. At the General Election the Government announced what they were prepared to do. Nobody has challenged us by saying that these Regulations do not do what we promised.

I should like to take up, before I forget them, one or two points made by the right hon. Gentleman. I think that he unintentionally misled the outside public when he referred to only one in every two coming under the means test. Surely it should be said that they all come under the means test, but that the test yields different results—positive results in one case and not in another.
I was talking about the proportion of people whose determination would be different because there was a means test.

What is complained of is not only that people get less money than they thought they were entitled to, but the whole system of inquiry spread over all and not only some, is a general grievance wherever it goes, and whatever results may come out of it. If the right hon. Gentleman was seeking to draw a hard and fast line with regard to the means test in cases where there were contractual obligations and where there were not, he must have heard many speakers say that we regard a great many of the wholesale gifts which have been made to classes of people—subsidies and other special advantages—as on the same footing as the money which is given to these people. In these cases no one contends that there was any contractual obligation. There is only a contractual obligation if the Government chooses to undertake that it will do so, and do so for a number of years. Generally when a promise is made in a limited form and the time comes for the benefit to terminate, there is some reason why that is not done. Until some reason is found why the benefit should go on indefinitely, it is almost as hard for industry to get off the dole as it is for private individuals to get on to it.
While I agree with the right hon. Gentleman up to a certain point about
the means test, I think he went wrong at the last stage. I agreed with him while he was talking about the personal test. I have always taken the view set out in the quotation which he made from the speech of the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury). Therefore, I have no quarrel with that part of his argument at all, but when he came to children he said, after setting forth that it was reasonable for children to contribute that you have to have the Regulations in order to see that the children contribute. May I point out to him that the Regulations, if that is their object, do not do that? All they do is to see that an old man does not get what he would otherwise get. They do not secure that the young people shall pay. It remains entirely indefinite. He may get the money, and in some cases I have no doubt that he does not get it. Some young people are perhaps willing to pay, and no doubt in other cases they are not. Those were points arising directly out of the speech of the right hon. Gentleman.
I want to deal with the main case as presented by the Minister of Labour. I am not criticising his speech in any sense with a desire to attack the right hon. Gentleman. I said, when he made his first speech at that Table, that I would rather see him in that Department than any other person on that side of the House, and to-day I still maintain that opinion, for this reason: I think that there is evidence that he is strong enough to make some kind of a fight against his Board, and I believe that there are a good many who would not. [An HON. MEMBER: "What evidence?"] I am asked what evidence. My evidence is necessarily in the nature of conjecture, but it is obtained in this way: I have read with great care the report of the Unemployment Assistance Board and also the Regulations themselves. It is only a matter of opinion, and other people may hold a different view, but there are amendments made in the Regulations which we have before us to-day, actual improvements of which there is no sort of hint in this document which I have studied. From that fact I have formed the conclusion—I may be wrong—that the Minister on these matters has made a valuable contribution of his own.
His speech was described as being provocative, and indeed it would be rather unlike the Minister of Labour if he did not provoke somebody. After all, it does not matter if he provokes hon. Gentlemen above the Gangway or on these benches—[an HON. MEMBER: "Why not?"] Because we are here to be provoked; we are ready to give and take such knocks, but I am sure that the right hon. Gentleman the Minister of Labour would be very sorry to cause any direct provocation to the one class of people who come under his care as Minister of Labour. In one sentence, however—and I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary will be able to deal with it—it appeared to me that he did provoke the unemployed themselves when he said that during the 18 months which have elapsed between the two sets of Regulations there have been no outward signs of trouble.
Upon his own evidence 59 per cent. of the people were on transitional benefit at this time, and only 41 per cent. were on the old scale. Apart from that, the 41 per cent. were living under what they were told was a temporary arrangement and were waiting for the end of it. They were told that it was going to come to an end in the spring, and it was delayed from month to month. Naturally, the full tide of resentment would not arise against a purely temporary arrangement. They were waiting until the end to see what was finally to be settled. Therefore—and this is my main point—is it not rather asking for trouble to say that there have been no outward signs of trouble? Does not that tend to make the unemployed say, "We have not made enough fuss; we must improve on that"? I think that that is a dangerous tendency. Hon. Members who have been sufficiently long in this House will remember that the right hon. Gentleman was the one who put up the strongest fight against the not-genuinely-seeking-work Clause in the old days, and assisted in getting it modified. I should not like to see him in his present position setting up a different test—a not-genuinely-breaking-windows test, without which no grievance would be regarded as having any foundation.
The Minister referred in one part of his speech to the Board being a service with a new technique. I think that he was paying the Board an undeserved com-
pliment. It may be a new service, but its technique is as old as Bumbledom and compares with that in "Oliver Twist," who dared ask for more. The only novelty about this technique, if it be part of it, is the arrangement for spinning out the reductions over a long period. It is very clever politics. It may be justified in other ways, but it secures that all the hard knocks will not come at the same time at the same place. It rather reminds me of a poem which my hon. Friend the Junior Member for Oxford University (Mr. Alan Herbert) wrote when he was very young, in which he described the adventures of a man who caused a herring to be put in a tank of water, and then proceeded to take away a little of the water every day until he had finally trained the herring to live without any water at all. That appears to be a process which is going to be applied with regard to this case. I am afraid that the end of the story was tragic, because the unfortunate fish, not liking its new, dry surroundings, threw itself off Brighton Pier and was drowned. I hope that there will not be a similarly tragic ending in this case.
It is no good, and it would not serve any useful purpose in dealing with Regulations like these, making criticisms without being willing to recognise improvements. I state quite definitely that in several respects these Regulations are a considerable advance upon those which we have had before. Really, it would be a remarkable thing if they were not, after the experience of last time and the amount of time that has been spent upon them. I particularly appreciate the arrangement that is being made enabling, in certain circumstances, an increase to be made in the case of a husband and wife who have no resources at all. That is a very deserving Clause, and I am glad that the Minister has made provision for such a Clause. I am also glad that this time, having learnt caution, precautions have been taken to avoid an immediate and fatal clash on the question of rent such as occurred last time. I would point out, however, that the result of the various precautions with which the rent question has been hedged around is that now we really do not know how they are to work. It is a matter of faith. We have to wait and see how it actually comes out in practice. The Government
have necessarily lost in lack of definition what they have gained in a certain amount of elasticity.
Finally, I welcome very much the new arrangement with regard to the earnings which are to be taken into computation.
