It so happens that I received a letter from Middlesbrough to-day complaining of the present allowances in a particular case of a man and wife, daughter aged 22½, and son aged 18½, the two last-named earning wages approaching, but not amounting to, 20s. a week. If this letter had been one which showed that the new scales were worse, I have no doubt that I should have presented the facts to the House. It is my duty in this case to say, that obviously there will be an improvement for a family of that kind. The first 20s. rule will operate, and there will be more available for that family—and a substantial amount—than under the old rule, and I am glad to welcome that fact.
Having pointed out, I hope fairly, the things which are to be commended, I wish to point out the difficult position in which anyone who feels as I do is placed under the procedure under which we are bound to treat these Regulations. Here are things which I like, and I do not want to be put into the position of having to go into the Division Lobby and vote against them. But I have to take the Regulations as a whole. If I vote for the Regulations, I am voting for a system which I think will be fundamentally wrong in some of its essential principles. The result is that I have either to go into the Lobby to vote against Regulations, part of which I like, or, like a great many hon. Members opposite who on the whole approve of the Regulations, I have to vote for some things which I regard as serious objections. The machinery under which we can move no Amendment not only works badly in practice, but produces an unsatisfactory atmosphere in our Debates and a sense of helplessness and futility in those who take part in them.
I regard the concession with regard to the computation of earnings as a very interesting point. It seems to mark the fact that the Government, and perhaps the Unemployment Assistance Board, are really in full retreat from the household means test. They are going back from it. I am afraid that they will now try and conduct this on a new line.
The only way to prevent them from doing that is to keep up the attack as hotly as possible. They have left Moscow and are disputing the passage of the Beresina, but I want to see them cleared out altogether. I may perhaps reproduce a criticism here, as it applied to the old as much as it does to the new Regulations. I applied it when the old Regulations were first produced. There is no clear idea in the Regulations or in any memorandum explaining them as to what need really is. What is our standard of need? That is a fundamental point, because the first duty laid upon the Board and its officials is to assess need.
When, for instance, a scale is being made fixing the needs of persons of a certain sex and age, how is it worked out? Has someone sat down in the Unemployment Assistance Board, worked out a scale of diet, and computed how much would have to be spent upon repairing clothes and upon getting new household utensils, and perhaps even humanly putting in a little money for perhaps cigarettes, and, since the Noble Lady the Member for the Sutton Division of Plymouth (Viscountess Astor) is not here, I may say, perhaps for a glass of beer even? Was any real attempt made to find out a human standard of need? If that has really been done, I cannot imagine for a moment that the scales which we have here really correspond to any reasonable schedule of needs which could have been got out in that way. I notice that the Home Secretary did not answer the very pertinent question put to him by the hon. Lady the Member for the English Universities (Miss Rathbone). It was the most important challenge that could have been delivered in this Debate, and it is directly raised by the Amendment put down by hon. Members above the gangway. The question is whether these scales are really fulfilling any standard which could be arrived at by a reasonable person. It seems to me that they are not.
The second thought that occurs to me is that these scales might possibly be acceptable to people if they could see any end to the period during which they were to come under the operation of these scales. Treated as insurance claims, when people are out of work for a little while and have reasonable prospects of getting back soon, they are prepared to carry on with the comparatively small sum paid to them. They are prepared for
a limited time, when they have been in work and are probably in full health, to tighten their belts, but if they have before them the prospect of going on indefinitely, and they have already been out of work year after year, and they see in front of them only the prospect of a drab succession of days, they feel inclined to tighten their belts round their necks and not round their waists. That is the difference which I see. These scales are to be applied in so many cases in areas such as I and hon. Members above the Gangway know where unemployment has been going on and on, and where it appears that there is no prospect of being able to get out of it.
With regard to the assessment of need, what is to be the final test of need? Is it in the ultimate discretion of the Board and of the officers of the Board to assess what they regard as being real need, whatever the consequences, whatever the comparison with anything else, because what is laid down in the Regulations is extremely confusing? They start with a mandatory injunction to assess need, go on with another mandate not to get above the standard wage rate of the district, which may be entirely inconsistent with the first condition; and then, as far as I remember from the last Debate, I was told by the then Minister of Labour that there is above all an over-riding discretion to assess the real need. What is the good of having this complicated, elaborate process? You shove the standard up to a certain height, then pull it down again because of some outside consideration, and then push it up again. It strikes me as resembling the childish puzzle in which you first think of a number, add 14, take away eight, and then take away the number you first thought of. It is an unreal process. If the real object is to assess human need, it could have been done regularly and once for all. It seems to me that in this matter the Government are uneasily conscious that if the mandate not to get above the standard wage rate of the occupation in which the applicant would be normally employed were literally compied with, in hundreds of thousands of cases the Board would not be assessing the need of applicants, and therefore they have left a kind of vagueness, in which we can hope for the best and hope that the duty to assess the real need will be complied with.
I am not going to deal in detail with the important issue of the effect of the means test in breaking up the home, because that was so admirably dealt with, particularly on its psychological side, by my hon. Friend the Member for East Birkenhead (Mr. White), but I repeat to the Parliamentary Secretary a question which I put to him before, when we were debating this Report and which he had not then time to answer. I was putting to him the point raised on page 181 of the Report. It happens to be the Middlesbrough section, but I dare say the same circumstances occur elsewhere. There it is definitely stated that the officers of the Board and the appeal tribunals are upholding the system of refusing to make determinations for people who have voluntarily gone out of a household. If they have left the household with the object of getting a determination where the determination is now nil, or of getting a higher determination, the officers of the Board take it upon themselves to say, and the appeal tribunals apparently confirm the decision, that they are disqualified and must be treated as if they were still in the household.
I ask the Government and the Board to make up their minds one way or the other on this point. It seems to me that this is a form of indirect pressure. If this is going on on a wide scale, it means that the officers of the Board are saying, "We have got you into the net, and it is no good your trying to get out of the net, because we shall pretend you are in, and you will be treated accordingly." I want to know by what legal right this is done. Is there any provision in the Act which enables it to be done? It is no good saying that these people are adopting an illegitimate method and trying to get round the Regulations. Of course they are trying to get round the Regulations, and so should I if I were in their place. They are trying to make the best of the Regulations. They are in exactly the same position as people who create trusts in order to avoid Income Tax, and hon. Members opposite say that as long as those people keep within the law it is a legitimate thing, and that if the authorities want to stop the practice, they should change the law. They should apply that same argument to the poor as to the rich. If this practice is used as a form of pressure
to make people stay in the household when they want to leave it, the whole atmosphere of the home will become more and more poisoned when they remain in. There was in the Middle Ages a class of serf—I have forgotten most of my Latin—called escripti glebi, tied to the soil. Are you going to make a new lot, escripti domi, tied to the household? That would be creating conditions akin to serfdom.
In justification of the means test, we have heard a very persuasive speech by the Home Secretary, leading us, step by step, to believe that the whole thing was quite inevitable and that no person could object. I was glad to see that there are rebels in the camp, that my hon. Friend the Member for Paisley (Mr. Maclay), the hon. and learned Member for Withington (Mr. Fleming), the hon. and learned Member for Newcastle, East (Sir R. Aske) and the hon. Member for West Salford (Mr. Emery) all from the Government benches, are thinking in the opposite direction, and that there are among them two King's Counsel, men who realise how technical phrases, regulations, or Acts of Parliament are likely to work out in practice, and I think their opinion ought to carry considerable weight. But I always come back to the point which has appealed to me from the beginning, that there is no moral justification for the household means test at all. All the arguments used by the Home Secretary are not arguments for the household test but for the family test; if they are for anything at all. They are arguments based on the idea that people akin to one another should help one another in their misfortunes; but that is not what we are going to get at the present time. We have a handful of poor people in a small house, and they all have to contribute to one another's needs, but they may have a rich uncle living at Sunningdale or Chislehurst who could maintain all of them out of his own pocket without noticing it, and you do not get at him for help. The whole argument produced by the Home Secretary really falls to the ground on that point. I do not want to be misunderstood. I am not arguing in favour of having the family test or the household test either. My views on that matter have already been expressed in the opening speech from these benches of the hon. Member for East Birkenhead.
We had from the Minister of Health an amazingly adroit Parliamentary performance, such as we have been accustomed to hear from him, but was not his picture a little bit overdrawn? He painted everything in the garden as being absolutely perfect. Somehow, what he said did not ring true in the light of one's own personal experiences. The pretty picture had a sort of oleographic shininess about it. What we see in certain streets in our constituencies or know from individual cases brought to our notice does not fit in with this picture at all. I have heard it implied that during the long course of the all-night sitting hon. Members above the Gangway were indulging in "sob-stuff." But what can they do? If a persuasive picture is painted and it goes out to the world as a picture of a particular method of administering relief, what can they do but get such hard chunks of fact as they can from their personal experience and use them as missiles for the purpose of breaking the mirror of an illusion which would otherwise have become generally accepted?
I do not want to detain the House longer, because I know that other hon. Members want to speak, and speeches have been rather long, but I would put this last point: The hon. Member for Central Sheffield (Mr. Boulton), in an interesting speech, came to the rather surprising conclusion that these Regulations would be welcomed by the great body of the nation. What is the good of great generalisations of that kind? Is it not obviously truer to say that in those areas where the administration of transitional payments by the local authority has been strict or harsh it may well be that the advantages to be obtained under these Regulations will outweigh any disadvantages there may be? Correspondingly, in other areas where the administration was on a more generous scale, and where there is going to be cutting down, these Regulations will be very unpopular. Is it not also tragically true that in a great many parts of the country where unemployment is the exception rather than the rule, in agricultural areas where they have not yet got the second appointed day, there will be a tepid indifference towards this problem?
That is what the reception in the country is likely to be; but it is not for us who come to this House to regard the
matter with tepid indifference, not even if our constituents are not badly hit. We have to come here as in a very real sense protectors of the poor, wherever the poor may be. We have not much power over these Regulations. On the whole we rely to a pathetic extent on the Unemployment Assistance Board doing its job, or on its being corrected by the vigilance of the Minister, but this is an occasion when we can express our views and forming my own judgment, as best I can, I have come to the conclusion that these are Regulations which we ought not to support, and since our own Amendment cannot be moved, I shall support the Amendment of the party above the Gangway.

Having been on one occasion a little provocative I shall on this occasion be at great pains to restrain my natural pugnacity, which is already somewhat exhausted by the all-night sitting, and in any case I have very little, in substance, except with regard to the means test, to quarrel about with my hon. Friend the Member for East Middlesbrough (Mr. K. Griffith). What really seems to be the difference between us is that I am prepared to give these Regulations the benefit of the doubt and vote for them, and that he is not prepared to do so. He has made some interesting detailed criticisms, and I only wish that under our procedure it had been possible to see those criticisms embodied in Amendments. I agree with him entirely when he objects to the fact that we cannot make an alteration of a sub-clause or a semi-colon in these Regulations, and that fact has, I think, produced a dangerous unreality in our debates and may be responsible for some of the heat which has been generated. I know that this procedure is under the Unemployment Act of 1934, and I voted against it, and I do not regret doing so.
I do not believe it is possible to take unemployment out of politics. I do not believe there is any analogy between the Unemployment Assistance Board and the Tariff Advisory Committee. The Tariff Advisory Committee are dealing with abstract questions in industry, and the Unemployment Assistance Board are dealing with flesh and blood. I do not like to feel that the unemployed man who is dissatisfied with the scales of his relief
has not the power to come to his Member of Parliament to present his case to the High Court of Parliament. I am a democrat, and I dislike it intensely if, when one of my constituents wishes me to raise a question, I have to say, "That matter is no longer the immediate concern of Parliament."
I was delighted at the stress laid by my right hon. Friend the Minister of Labour on the opportunities presented by the annual debates on the Board's Estimates and other occasions for raising the grievances of the unemployed, and I hope that my right hon. Friend, if he finds that these opportunities are insufficient, will not hesitate to come to this House and ask for amendment of the Unemployment Act of 1934. The Act of 1934 exists and we have to deal with these Regulations as they are presented to us. I should like to touch upon one aspect of the Board's functions upon which very little stress has been laid during the Debate. The Unemployment Assistance Board exists for something other than to provide unemployment relief. It exists also to enable a man to be placed in a condition that he can get employment. The Preamble of Part II of the Act of 1934 says: The functions of the Board shall be the assistance of persons … who are in need of work and the promotion of their welfare, and in particular the making of provision for the improvement and re-establishment of the condition of such persons with a view to their being in all respects fit for entry into or return to regular employment. I think the Board should direct its efforts to that vital object. How is it discharging this function? We were alarmed on reading in "The Times" that there were 500 vacancies at the Ministry of Labour's training centres. I can well understand the reluctance of a man of 18 or 23 or 24 years of age who has been unemployed. He may lose the incentive for work and may be content to draw the dole and regard himself as a victim of the capitalist system. But surely that is an attitude of mind which we all ought most sincerely to deplore and do our best to correct. As a Liberal I hate compulsion. I hate the idea of compelling men to go to a training centre, and I also think that when they are there under compulsion they probably will not derive a great deal of benefit. I wish it were possible for the
party opposite to help us to put the unemployed young men into the right temper to go to these training centres. The Labour party would be doing an immense public service if they tried to stimulate the determination of young unemployed men to refit themselves and if necessary train themselves for another job, if they cannot get employment in their own industry.
An enormous amount of harm has been done by describing these unemployment training centres as concentration camps. Was that really helpful? Was it helpful to crab these efforts to give these unfortunate fellows an opportunity of raising themselves from the abyss of despair? None of us can look without horror and dismay on the wastage of young life, and we should do everything in our power to ease it as far as we can, even if it risks some temporary political disadvantage. I know it is difficult for us who are well fed and well clothed and who in a few days' time will be having a pleasant and restful holiday, we who are in receipt of £8 a week, a minimum wage of £8 per week—which is a fortune to the great majority of our constituents—it is very difficult for us, I know, to say that the scales are sufficient, but I do suggest that they represent a substantial increase. The Liberal party have always advocated a raising of the basic minimum, and I suggest that the Regulations do raise the basic minimum.
After all, anyone can trace the tremendous change in the industrial situation with regard to the unemployed which has taken place during the last 20 years. I am just old enough to remember the food tickets and the soup kitchens, which were all that was left to the unemployed. Then came the first unemployment pay, 7s. a week, which was only granted as a grant-in-aid, and now we hear that the rate to be paid is 3s. above the general rate per head paid when the Labour party was in office. It illustrates the general upward trend in the standard of life, which I contend is a peculiar characteristic of the capitalist system.
I cannot believe in the armaments argument which is used in regard to these scales. We are told that we are spending many hundreds of millions of pounds on armaments and some tens of millions of pounds on unemployment relief. What
would be the use of diverting some of the millions spent on armaments to unemployment relief, if at the same time it weakened our defences? Do let us have common sense about this matter. What would be the use to a constituent of mine in Bristol, when he heard the whirr of hostile aeroplanes, the crash of falling masonry and felt the filthy poison gas creeping up the Severn, to know that by weakening our defences and our powers of retaliation we had been able to add a shilling or two to the amount he had drawn from the Employment Exchange. The unemployed, I believe, realise themselves that there are other factors in politics than their scales. It is tremendously to their credit that in 1931, when they believed that there was a grave financial crisis, they went in their thousands to the polling booths and voted away a few coppers of their dole.
What is the Labour thesis? As I understand it, it is work or full maintenance; that there should be the same rates for a 48-hour week as for idleness. That removes the incentive which now exists for work in the difference between trade union rates of wages and the dole, and when you have taken that incentive away what do you put in its place? You can only put one thing, and that is compulsion; if a man will not work he will have to be made to work.
Is the hon. Member aware that in some cases they are penalised?

I am fully aware of that. The corollary to work or full maintenance is conscription of labour, and the party opposite have never really faced that issue. Nor do they appear to realise what the making of unemployment a national responsibility really entails? It is something which they have advocated for years, and also the Liberals, but it postulates national control, and now that there is national control they are agitating for more power for local authorities. You cannot have both. Hon. Members opposite are complaining that local authorities have only advisory powers. We have been told that this battle about the means test is only just beginning. It began for some of us many years ago. It is nothing new to us. We stood on the means test at the last election and were elected upon it, and it is absurd to say that the fight
is just beginning now. The means test which we supported, at the General Election was very much more open to Labour objection than the one which we are putting in its place to-day. This is the only point upon which I am in disagreement with the hon. Member for Middlesbrough West—the question of the family means test.
Let me put this case. A man with a wife and child of 13 applies for relief. In the house there are two sons, one of 25 years of age and one of 17 years of age. The son of 25 is earning 52s. per week and the son of 17 is earning 15s. per week. Under these scales the son earning 52s. per week will be expected to contribute 18s. and the son earning 15s. will contribute 1s. 6d. Does my hon. Friend really think that these sons should contribute nothing at all to the maintenance of the family? I think it is perfectly right and fair that there should be a family means test.
If they do not live in the house but are living next door the moral position would be exactly the same.

That is a very ingenious argument, but it will not do. I take my stand on the family means test. I think it is fair and right. I would rather lose my seat and go out of public life than say anything else about it. When you talk about the unity of family life there cannot be very much in the unity if it cannot survive the test of misfortune; it had better break up, it is not worth preserving. The right hon. Member for Wakefield (Mr. Greenwood) said there were elements of revolt in the means test. I believe in all sincerity that there are elements of a revolt without the means test. The great mass of wage-earners will not stand for an indiscriminate pouring out of public funds without any inquiry at all. I put this point. Fascism has come in some foreign countries, and when it has come it has been not a little due to the failure of democracy to stand firm on the question of doles, to refuse to surrender blindly to popular clamour and, above all, to have the courage to tell democracy the truth.

The hon. Member for Bristol, West (Mr. Bernays) always speaks
with clarity and force, and I have listened to him with care this evening because I wanted to hear from one of the younger supporters of the Government what justification they have for the stand they propose to take this evening in support of the Regulations. I am sure the hon. Member when he reads his speech tomorrow will realise that some parts of it were unworthy. His suggestion that the only people in the country who should subscribe towards the rearming of the nation should be the unemployed, was astonishing.

The hon. Member should recollect that the means test was imposed on the unemployed in 1931. He has forgotten that. He now suggests that the only economy which was made in 1931 which should be retained is the economy on the unemployed. He fumes with indignation, and says that he is ready to take his stand, unpopular though it may be, upon the principle that public money should not be poured out to unemployed persons without the application of a means test to the resources of the household. We did that between 1920 and 1931.
On the basis of a contractual obligation.

The hon. Member is an authority on some subjects, but not on this. Unemployment benefit has always been divided into two parts, into standard benefit and uncovenanted benefit—uncovenanted, extended and transitional benefit, afterwards called transitional payment. In the mining industry, particularly in South Wales and on the North-East coast, many miners have never had a chance to be under any other category than that of extended benefit. They were unable to make sufficient contributions to the scheme to qualify for permanent standard benefit. For all that time they were receiving standard payment from the State without the application of this principle. I understand that it is to be assumed that we have made such progress that now a great moral illumination has broken in upon us—it broke in upon us in 1931—and that was that the State could not possibly remain intact unless the means test was applied to the unemployed. I was here in 1931. On no single occasion was the application
of a means test justified on any other ground than the financial necessities of the time.
Was it not one of the recommendations of the Royal Commission before the financial crisis?

I am coming back to that. It was produced by the National Government of 1931 as part of the general economy scheme. Under that scheme the Government intended to save every year £10,000,000. They have actually saved on that account alone over £22,500,000 a year. I come now to my original charge, that what the hon. Member suggested was that, although the policemen might have their cuts restored, the Services as a whole, the teachers, the judges, Cabinet Ministers, people under Part I and Members of Parliament, the only class of British subjects who should still suffer the economy cuts are those who have been unlucky enough to be idle the longest. It is argued that they must still make their contribution to armaments. The hon. Member said, "Would it not be better that they should suffer and the nation be armed than that they should be paid more and the nation be disarmed? So on the shoulders of the weakest of the community you rest the heaviest burden. There would be some merit in his contention if he had linked together the other classes who had been cut in 1931 and said that the financial necessities of the case are still so considerable that the whole of the cuts must be maintained. But that is not the position. The position facing us is that of all the economy proposals made in 1931 this is the only one that remains. The hon. Member would justify it, as he attempted to do, by saying that, after all, two Elections have been fought and that he stood at the last Election on the means test. But when the Election was fought last year this was by no means the dominant issue, and he would not contend that it was the dominant issue in his constituency.
An attempt was made every night to shout me down on it.

The dominant issue at the last General Election was foreign policy. The people of the country were under the impression that we had shown our indignation so effectively against the Board's proposals last year that the
Board were now incubating other proposals. I have spoken to people from John o'Groat's to Land's End, and ordinary folk were really under the impression that, whatever test was to be made, the household means test would go. The Lord President of the Council made a categorical promise to that effect. Immediately before the last General Election the Government issued a statement about the future of unemployment assistance in the following terms: Arrangements under the Unemployment Assistance scheme have received prolonged and anxious consideration by the Government. As already stated in Parliament, no alteration will be made in the existing standstill arrangement before next spring at the earliest. The Government regard it as important to maintain the existing powers of the Unemployment Asistance Board, and the general framework of the system. They will, however, give effect to any recommendations by the Board for improved arrangements. The stand-still arrangements are, and were always intended to be, temporary. They must be replaced by a permanent arrangement. As regards the means test, the Government believe that no responsible person would seriously suggest that unemployment assistance, which is not insurance benefit, ought to be paid without regard to the resources probably available to the applicant. The question is not whether there should be a means test, but what that test should be. This is a matter which is now under close examination, but in any scheme great importance will be attached to maintaining the unity of family life and, in addition, provision will be made to meet any cases of proved hardship. Do hon. Members seriously suggest that the change that has been made in the calculation of family resources seriously modifies the test against which there was such exception taken last time? It was implied in the Government's own election manifesto that the application of a family means test impaired family life and that there should be a modification of the Regulations so that family unity would not be impaired. Is it seriously contended that this fulfils that promise?—[Interruption]—You can contend anything. First of all, we are informed by the right hon. Gentleman that officers of the Board will not regard the resources of distant relatives in the same way as the resources of near relatives, but we are informed that all the resources of the household will still be taken into account. Is not that the very condition which every student said impaired the unity of family life? To what was exception taken if not to that?
Personal requirements.

I am glad the right hon. Gentleman has mentioned that, because I want to know where Members stand. If a young man at work in the mining industry, earning £2 a week, has idle members of his family, you are saying that he is to work indefinitely for a standard of living represented by an expenditure of 28s. a week. Will anyone declare that that is a decent wage? Is it denied that that is in the Regulations? I will ask another question, because the difficulty about these Debates is that, because of the nature of the discussion and because of the general division that takes place, we cannot pin them down to anything concrete. They escape these things all the while. The Minister is usually very loquacious. Why does he not answer now? Take the father of a family who has idle sons at home. Is it seriously contended that he should continue to work for a wage represented by a sum which is 8s. more per week than the unemployment allowance? Is it considered that 8s. a week should remain the only inducement, the father should have to go on working? Answer!
The hon. Member is fond of asking questions. May I ask him—

No. If you were speaking, you would certainly not approve of that. These are standard cases. It is no good for the Minister to say the officers of the Board have discretion. Discretion does not exist in these cases. I challenge the hon. Member who spoke last. Does he contend that that is a reasonable proposition? He is a very strong man and a robust politician. He is so strong that he is prepared to withstand all the onslaughts of the weak and helpless. Does he declare that the wage that the father of a family should receive, working six days a week, should be represented by 8s. a week in addition to his unemployment allowance?
These questions are extremely foolish. Obviously we are all in favour of the greatest possible wage that the industry will pay.

It is obvious that the heat in the hon. Member's speech was out of all proportion to the understanding. At the moment under the Regula-
tions the father of a family is permitted to retain for his personal requirements a figure which is 8s. a week more than he would receive if he were idle. All the rest is taken. He is expected to continue to work on the inducement of a difference of 8s. a week between what he would have if he were idle and what he has when at work. Does the hon. Member approve of that? Does the Minister approve of it? But that is the centre of the case. That is what the household means test comes to when reduced to the standard unit. I am not speaking of exceptional cases and I do not want the Minister to try to run away on the plea that these are exceptional cases. Will hon. Members declare to-day that that is what they consider those two types of wage-earners should have to live on? The answer, of course, is that they are a lot of cowardly individuals who are sheltering behind the fact that they are not compelled to vote on the principle in the Lobby.

With the permission of Mr. Deputy-Speaker, I hope to take part briefly in the Debate later and I shall then as far as I can answer the questions put by the hon. Member, but I do not see why I should take up the time of the House in helping the hon. Member to make his speech.

I am not presenting the case in a false setting. I am not distorting the case. That is the standard case and the fact is that hon. Members cannot justify it and cannot answer my question. All they can do is to try to justify themselves to their constituents by saying that these Regulations give a little more than the last Regulations—an improvement that has been accomplished in spite of them. They have persisted in the cut, in defiance of the pledge made in 1931 and in defiance of every decent principle. It is not the case that the means test is necessary for the purity of our public life. That argument will not hold water because you did without it for years previously and our public life was not polluted as a result. You do without it now, in relation to a vast series of industries. You do not speak about a means test in relation to doles which you justify by saying that they assist in promoting industry and employment. You do not distinguish between those employers who need an inducement or a
stimulus and those who do not. You did not, when the Derating Act came into operation, leave out the rich employers and include only the poor employers. You gave the benefit indiscriminately. Hon. Members know very well that they have not a leg on which to stand in this matter.
The Minister stated as one of the justifications for these Regulations that his scales approximate to what is being paid by the most enlightened public assistance authorities. In passing, I notice that not one of the authorities mentioned is an authority with a Conservative administration. Then the right hon. Gentleman went on to say that even those scales approximated to the standard benefit rates. If we on this side have been indignant we have had every justification because I have never listened to more dishonest debating. I hope the Minister will not use this argument again. He made a statement about Monmouthshire County Council and used particular instances, but he has not yet furnished us with the name of the district or the name of the man.
I understood that in the one case the names were given to the hon. Member for Aberdare (Mr. G. Hall), and, in the other, the Glamorgan case, to the hon. Member for Pontypridd (Mr. D. Davies).

I am not speaking about Aberdare. I am speaking about Monmouthshire, and all we know is that the comparison which the right hon. Gentleman made was a comparison between what a man who is on sick pay receives from the public assistance committee and what an able-bodied man receives under the Board. Why does not the Minister compare like with like? Why does he compare what the public assistance committee pays to the sick poor with what the Board pays to the able-bodied? Because he was able to leave out of account the additional nourishment payment which the public assistance authorities give to the sick poor. That is the reason. The right hon. Gentleman was even "slimmer" than that. He was as "slim" as the Minister of Health. The Minister of Health used the same argument when he said that the standard benefit rates under the Board approximated to the scales of many
public assistance authorities, and the Noble Lord the Member for Lanark (Lord Dunglass) used the same arguments. They know very well that the public assistance authority is by law compelled to apply the family means test.
In the next place the Minister ought to know by now that if the public assistance authorities of Great Britain actually had scales of relief higher than the benefit rate, they would be all ruined in a fortnight, because every single person on standard benefit would be entitled to have his benefit supplemented from the local rates. If the local authority assessed the needs of an applicant for public assistance at a higher rate than the standard rates paid under Part I, then everybody under Part I could claim the difference, and 1,000,000 additional people would be on the register with all their dependants. The Minister of Health must know that he was putting up an entirely false case. The local authorities are limited. Indeed, the Monmouthshire County Council were compelled to reduce their scales of assistance in 1931, and having been compelled to reduce them, with the alternative of a surcharge, the very Minister whose Department is responsible then jeers at them in this House for not paying more. If there has been indignation on this side it has been well justified.
Why are the Government applying this test? Why are they continuing this procedure? Is it because they cannot afford any more? Do right hon. and hon. Gentlemen defend the Regulations and the scales on the ground that the country is too poor to pay more? The Chancellor of the Exchequer tells us that we are on the road to prosperity and I read in the "Evening Standard" on Tuesday night that it is expected that the 12th August will be better than ever this year and that the grouse moors of Scotland have let much better this year than at any time since the War. The "Evening Standard" adds with great pride that it is not to rich foreigners on this occasion but to Englishmen. It is not, therefore, because you cannot afford to pay more. The Government do not justify them because they cannot afford to pay more. On what ground then are they justified? Hon. Members opposite, in defending the Regulations, are defending low wage-rates. They are perpetuating this offence against the helpless poor
because it is a necessary provision for depressing wage rates.
Indeed, the right hon. Gentleman has shown his hand in what he considers to be an excellent new principle, the principle of linking up the allowances of the Board to standard benefit, so that the assessment of need under Part II becomes dependent upon the financial resources of the scheme under Part I. The right hon. Gentleman smiles. He had better look at his Memorandum again. It distinctly says that in certain instances the officers of the Board may bring the allowances up to the standard benefit rate and that that rate shall be the proper rate for the individual, so that it is lower in the agricultural areas than in the industrial areas. In order, therefore, that we should find out what is likely to be the fate of people under Part II, we have to examine the finance under Part I, because if anything happens to the financial resources of Part I, there is an automatic effect upon the payments made under Part II. The right hon. Gentleman does not do himself justice by shaking his head, because, even if that were not so, it is the guiding principle of the whole system that persons are not normally to be able to have under Part II more than under Part I. The right hon. Gentleman knows very well that if he did normally pay more under Part II than under Part I the whole insurance scheme would "go bust." If the right hon. Gentleman wants me to quote, I will, but I have not quoted the Memorandum because it is so well known.
The hon. Member leaves out the word "present" and constructs an entirely false argument.

Does the right hon. Gentleman suggest that if under the provisions of Part I of the scheme the standard rate of benefit were reduced, the Board would supplement the standard rate for all the standard benefit rate drawers by payments under Part II? Or does he suggest that they would normally go on paying more in the form of allowances than is received under Part I? I will make the right hon. Gentleman a present of this: When they do that, I will resign from Parliament. I want to ask the right hon. Gentleman to face the implications of the position.
Did the hon. Member hear the hon. Member for Chester-le-Street giving comparative average payments under Part I and Part II?

The comparison that has been made in that case is false, but the hon. Gentleman the Member for Chester-le-Street said he would make a bargain. I confirm his bargain. The hon. Member's contention is that the unemployed are now able to attract more money from the State per head under Part II than they would under Part I.
Does the hon. Member deny that the present rates are 17s. 7d. for standard benefit and 23s. 3d. for Part II?

The hon. Member knows very well that the ingredients that go to the making of his argument are not comparable. I want to reduce the thing to a simpler issue. It is contended that unemployed persons are able to attract higher rates of allowances under Part II than if they were under Part I. Why, therefore, have a means test? The right hon. Gentleman, in answering a question the other day, admitted that if they did away with the means test, if people were treated under Part I as under Part II, it would cost £39,000,000 a year instead of £38,000,000. I do not accept that figure, but even that is £1,000,000 more, so that the hon. Member's contention is wholly false. People are having less on the average as a consequence of there being a Board. So that we are driven back again to Part I. The hon. Member for Huddersfield (Mr. Mabane) claimed that by the genius of the Government the unemployed under Part I had been protected from the possibility of disaster, but what does Part I say? It says that the fund shall not be allowed to accumulate a surplus or have a deficit. Every year the fund must be balanced. If it has a surplus, representations must be made to the Minister to disperse it in some way. Recently there was a surplus of £6,000,000, and the Government reduced the contributions in order to give themselves £4,000,000 and the workers £2,000,000. If there is a deficit, it has to be met every year too, so that we have the most extraordinary insurance scheme that ever existed.
An ordinary insurance scheme is a way of saving up for the rainy day, but here is an insurance scheme that makes the
rainy day inevitable. It is an astonishing scheme, for it says that you can neither borrow nor lend, and if unemployment goes up, the scheme under Part I becomes bankrupt. If that happens, what will be done? Will the Government increase the contributions? They canont do that at the very time of financial difficulty and industrial depression. They cannot put up the contributions of the employer at a time when he needs to reduce the costs of production. They could contract the period of benefit, but if they did that they would throw more people on the means test. They might also reduce the scale of benefits, and that is precisely what they do, because by reducing the standards of Part I they automatically reduce the standards of the whole unemployed population. At the very moment when the rain starts and the worker needs the umbrella, the umbrella is taken from him. That is what the right hon. Gentleman really means by flexibility. They have devised an insurance system which is so flexible that the workers of Great Britain will be exposed to the worst effects of industrial depression at the time when the capitalists need a reduction in wages.

The hon. Gentleman is arguing on entirely false premises. It is not true that there is no possibility of having a surplus. There is at the moment, apart from the distribution of £6,500,000, £28,000,000 against bad times.
If the right hon. Gentleman looks at the Act again, he will see.
The hon. Member is quite wrong.
You have to dispose of a surplus, and if you do not, you defy the law.
The hon. Member does not know the law.

Do hon. Members suggest for a single moment that £24,000,000—you have just disposed of £6,500,000—is a surplus for an insurance fund organising 12,000,000? What you have prevented the fund from doing is to accumulate surpluses in the meantime, because if those surpluses were available, you would not have a case for reduced benefits under the scheme if
industrial depression occurred. It is not an insurance scheme, but a scheme deliberately devised to expose the workers of Great Britain to attacks on their wages at the moment when the employers need to make an attack, and the unemployment standards are reduced in order to lessen the workers' resistance to wage reductions. That is the secret of the whole scheme, and no other explanation can be found for it. Hon. Members who defend the means test do so on no other ground than that the wage rates which are paid in English industry are so abominably low that if the unemployed were paid decent benefits, without a means test, the unemployed would get more than the men at work. That is the position.
The Debate has been a very long one, and the arguments which have been used have been put forward over and over again, so that it is difficult to find anything fresh to say. I would like to conclude by saying that in this House, for the last six or seven years, we have been imploring the Government to tackle the problem of the depressed areas. The Government have now admitted that they have given up the task. They have admitted that all that they propose to do for the distressed areas is to disperse the aggregations of unemployed that are there. In its Memorandum, the Board says that within the first six months 60,000 people, very largely young men under 25 years of age, are to have immediate reductions. That is because the Government have given up hope of providing any employment for those young men in those areas, and the Secretary of State for War is waiting with open arms to receive them. He is ready to receive those 60,000 young men, most of whom are to receive reductions, in South Wales and in other parts of the country, from 17s. to 10s. a week, and less in many cases.
It is very difficult to try to make hon. Members envisage the situation that is likely to arise. South Wales is likely to be depopulated if this thing goes on for three or four years more. The Government have made up their minds that it ought to be depopulated, and they have made up their minds that there is no hope for those communities. They are increasing pressure so as to make it uncomfortable for people to stay there. They have accepted the proposals which
the Federation of British Industries made some years ago. Every proposal which the employers made has been carried out by the Government in their scheme. I will not read those proposals to the House, since they have already been read. Those young men will be leaving those areas and joining the Army. There are two principles that can govern a man's conduct in public life: one is pity and the other is hate. I do not believe in the use of the term "love," because I think it is inappropriate. It is impossible for us to move hon. Members opposite to pity. We have tried to do it, but all that they do is to shelter themselves behind meaningless generalisations, and put up an eminent lawyer to make a case on their behalf. We cannot move them to pity; if we could, we should not be here discussing these Regulations to-day.
My hon. Friends have mentioned case after case of homes where the deepest tragedy has occurred as a result of these Regulations. It is not that in the working-class homes there is no filial piety, but there is always a difference in a burden which is voluntarily undertaken and one which is legally imposed. The one which is voluntary cements the family, the one which is legally imposed dissolves it, and dissolves it in circumstances of the greatest possible acrimony. If hon. Members opposite had any really genuine experience of working-class households, they would not do what they are now doing. But their family life is not the family life of working-class homes. There is not as much family life in the well-to-do classes as in the poorer classes. There is not anything like the same closeness between them; many of them have independent incomes; they are attended by their nurses and spend most of their adolescent life away from the rest of the family. Hon. Members opposite do not realise the close association that exists in the industrial centres of Great Britain among members of the family who largely follow the same occupation.
Hon. Members opposite may say that if things are as I have stated, these proposals will not have the effect of destroying a family life which is so close and so intimate, but what they do not understand—and they will forgive me for saying this—is that the one who resents the situation is not the son or the brother who gives, but the son or the brother who receives. I have discovered one
thing in my public life, and it is that if I want to make a friend, I must get him to do something for me, and if I want to make an enemy, I must do something for him. The same thing applies to family life. The father or the brother or the sister who makes a contribution to the family is not so much aggrieved by it as the person who receives it. But where they all sit down at the same table, and the food is being measured out by the head of the family, usually the mother, the idle brother is in such a hypersensitive condition that he even sees himself getting a smaller share than he otherwise would. I have seen that happen. I have seen rows grow up in the home from the most trivial causes, because an idle brother is ready to take offence at anything. He is in such a neurotic state that he believes his brother who is working is using his superior position against him.
It is no use my going on. I cannot move hon. Members to pity; it is impossible. There is only one thing left, and that is hate. I believe in hate more than pity, myself. Thousands of young men in England, and particularly young men from the North East Coast, South Wales, and parts of Scotland, are now joining the Army and the Air Force, learning to defend the country which has given them these conditions. I hope that they will remember them. It will be my duty, at any rate, as I conceive it, to ask them to remember. Let hon. Members not be so complacent. Difficulties are growing up all round them now, and they will want these young men. When they want them, I hope these young men will remember what they are doing now, and I hope that, when the time comes that you are in difficulties and your backs are turned, you will remember that that is their opportunity. Now they are helpless and can do nothing to defend themselves. It may be that you will be helpless and can do nothing to defend yourselves. I hope that they will remember, and I hope that you will remember what you are doing now, because there never was a ruling class in the whole of history so stupid and so purblind as you are. At the cost of £10,000,000 a year at the outside, you could make all these people into loyal supporters of yours, and, for the sake of saving £10,000,000 a year, you are making them all bitter, cynical enemies of the State you represent. I
hope that when the opportunity comes they will take advantage of it, and I hope I shall be there to see your faces at the time they do so.

The hon. Member for Ebbw Vale (Mr. Bevan) is an ingenious and forcible debater, and I am glad he is here to enliven our councils and take part in our discussions, though I must confess I rather deplore the closing observations of what I thought was a very powerful speech. He poked mild and friendly fun at those people whose good fortune it would be in the coming summer to go to Scotland, which is my native country. Certainly he is right in saying that that exodus to the North once more is a sign of gradually returning national prosperity, but certainly he is wrong in giving the impression that that prosperity is confined to the wealthy sections of the community. Among the 1,400,000 people in the United Kingdom where there is now a regular wage instead of unemployment insurance benefit, there is gratitude for the policy which has made that happy result possible. Indeed, in that part of South Wales which enjoys the representation of the hon. Member, in Ebbw Vale itself, they are, I think I am right in saying, looking forward with great expectation to the opening, a few months ahead, perhaps even during that summer season itself, of the new steelworks in Ebbw Vale, undoubtedly as a result of the Government's protective policy.
The hon. Member must know that there is grave anxiety in other parts of South Wales lest the opening of that steelworks in Ebbw Vale should close down all the works in other parts of South Wales.

Bearing in mind the agitation that has taken place in the North with regard to the question of erecting steelworks at Jarrow, there need be little fear that the Ebbw Vale steelworks will drive any other works out of production.
I should like to make a brief passing reference to two most excellent speeches from different benches of the Liberal party, namely, the speeches of the hon. Member for West Middlesbrough (Mr. K. Griffith) and of the hon. Member for
North Bristol (Mr. Bernays). I quite agree with them that it is singularly unfortunate that Parliamentary procedure makes it impossible for us to criticise certain aspects of these Regulations, and to move Amendments in order to make them the more or less perfect thing that everyone in the House would like to see them become. That is unfortunate, but it is inevitable, and I accept the view of the Government that it would have been impossible, in complicated and detailed Regulations of this kind, to have allowed Amendments to be moved and carried from different parts of the House. But I join with my hon. Friend the Member for North Bristol in agreeing that these Regulations ought to be given a trial.
I know quite well that it is easy for me to speak with extreme calmness and moderation. It is my great good fortune to come from a prosperous home, and from a constituency that is very prosperous compared with those of many hon. Members opposite. In my county of Bedfordshire there is, I believe, at the present moment, a lower rate of unemployment than in any other part of the United Kingdom. This throws upon me a two-fold obligation—in the first place, to be grateful to those whose policy has made possible a slight return of prosperity in my own county; and, secondly, to be very sensible of my obligation to try to do something of value in national discussions when the problems of less happy areas are before the House of Commons. I take it that hon. Members opposite would not chide me with being a wrong person to intervene in this discussion merely because I come from prosperous political surroundings, because quite often, when our agricultural problems have been discussed, we have welcomed the active and sometimes vigorous intervention of hon. Members who do not come from agricultural areas, recognising that this is a Council of State, in which every section of the nation ought to play its part.
If these Regulations were the sum total of the Government's policy for the distressed areas, then, whatever hardship it might involve, I should certainly be obliged to oppose them. But, of course, they are nothing of the kind. They are Regulations to tide over what we all hope is a temporary period of unemployment before the prosperity for which we
are all anxious to work is spread more evenly over the nation as a whole. I fully concede that the distressed areas in many parts of the country have been virtually untouched by the vigorous industrial tariff and Imperial programme of the present Government, and I hope very much that in the coming year the energy and enterprise that have been devoted to other important subjects will be enlisted in a vigorous attack on this crying national evil. About 100 years ago last week, Mr. Joseph Chamberlain was born in Camberwell. He went to Birmingham, and, after a few years, became Lord Mayor of that city; and seeing in the rich city of Birmingham, great hardship and poverty in certain parts of the town, he uttered this proud boast, which he carried out: By God's grace, in 12 months the City of Birmingham shall not know itself. We all hope that, under the vigorous Chancellorship of his son, the same boast may be made in regard to the distressed areas and carried out with the same triumphant success. Most certainly the present Administration are setting about it in the right way, and I am sure that the Minister of Labour and his colleagues in the Government are fully appreciative of the fact that, when we give them, as we do, whole-hearted and sincere endorsement of these Regulations, we give them also our urgent entreaty to tackle that problem with courage and with vigour. Twenty-five million more gallons of liquid milk were sold last year than were sold the year before in England as a whole. That is the sort of way in which to tackle a problem of this kind, and hon. Members opposite, who allowed agriculture to go down the slippery slope to destruction and at the same time did nothing to convey its products to the poorer homes, ought not to chide the Government for failure in an initial attack on this problem.
I would like to refer to one or two points raised by the hon. Member for Ebbw Vale in his singularly interesting speech. He spoke as if in 1931 different sections of the country were asked to undergo hardship in order, as he rightly said, to tide over what people hoped was a temporary period of grave financial emergency. He said that since then nearly every section in the State had had their cuts restored, but the unemployed,
the poorest and therefore the most needy, were ignored. That is the sort of generalisation that he deplores in some of the speeches from this side, and it would be very unfortunate if it went out to the country as the real, sober truth. The truth is that all the cuts have been restored, even the cuts in unemployment benefit. They were restored by 50 per cent. and then in full. At the present time the cuts are fully restored and the benefits are as high as they have ever been.
The hon. Member also used the argument that the mere retention of the means test after the emergency legislation of 1931 was asking the unemployed alone to continue to bear the emergency cut. It is nothing of the kind. The Insurance Committee, which was set up by the party represented by hon. Members opposite, recommended the means test, but that it not really the point that I want to make, although I am prepared to develop it if necessary. My point is that the very fact that there is a means test now and that there was not a means test when hon. Members opposite were in charge of the Ministry of Labour, is an indication that the money now being paid out is going to the most needy homes. There is no criticism now, after the reply of the Home Secretary, of the statement that in actual fact the average payment going to-day into the homes of the unemployed is more than it was when the Socialist Government were in power. Whether or not it is more by 3s. people may quarrel, but that it is more, substantially more, is generally accepted. There was no means test then, but there is now. In addition, the cost of living was five per cent. higher then. The fact that there was no means test then, though the average was also lower shows that more money was going into homes that did not need it than is going now, when the means test ensures, as far as the wit of man can ensure, that the money goes to those who are in the greatest need.
One of the reasons why there was some slight excitement this afternoon, if I may be bold enough to refer to it, has been that certain hon. Members have been rather disappointed at the failure to arouse any mass movement of opposition in the country as a whole. Those of us who enjoy political quietude in rural
constituencies spend a considerable amount of time in going to the industrial areas to find out what is being said. There was undoubtedly deep disquietude over the old Regulations. It was not confined to one section of the House. It was summed up in a statement by the then Minister of Labour that, "there was a tendency to have rigidity leading to unnecessary hardship." There was no need then to engineer opposition in the country, because one of those spontaneous feelings that in justice might be done, naturally arose, and Parliament, as is right and proper as the forum of the nation, gave expression to that fear by the Standstill Agreement.
Since then a great deal has happened. There has been a considerable increase in the number of people employed. In addition, there has been 18 months experience of the working of the Board, which has shown itself not to be the hard-hearted and inhumanitarian organisation which we were told it was going to be. The real reason, however, why, despite the vigorous efforts of hon. Members opposite, there has not been the mass movement and the "trouble outside" that we were told there would be, is that people want a period in which to ponder over these new Regulations and to see whether or not some of the legitimate grievances against the old Regulations have been met. In regard to the main tenor of the Opposition charge, I should like to make one brief reference to the operation of the means test. We do not know even now just exactly where responsible Labour leaders stand on this question. The National Council of Labour issued a statement a short time ago in which they spoke of their policy as being: An adequate system that shall not penalise the relations of the unemployed man and woman. That is one of those generalisations that hon. Members deplore when used from these benches, and it justifies the statement of the hon. Member for Gorbals (Mr. Buchanan), now temporarily out of the House, with regard to the attitude of the Labour party towards the means test, when he accused them of misleading many thousands of very poor people by clothing their language and using vague phrases, that people wonder what they
mean, and that later on they could say that something else was meant.
When did he say that?
About three years ago.
Did he not say that when the present Lord President of the Council was the Leader of the Labour party?

He may have said it with some justice in regard to some aspects of the Labour party's policy, but if the hon. Member will ask the hon. Member for Gorbals he will find that he holds the same view to-day. As for the hon. Member for Dumbarton Burghs (Mr. Kirkwood), I would remind him of what he said after the Scarborough Conference in regard to the official policy of the Labour party on the means test. In the country there is a growing realisation that some of the real grievances under the old Regulations have been substantially met. People realise that more money is going into the needy homes than before. They recognise also that the new grouping for the household means test meets a number of the fair comments that were advanced in criticism 18 months ago. They believe that the rent rule and the scope for discretion in individual cases, the abolition of the super-cut, the attitude towards charitable gifts, and the general discretion of the Board, the advisory committees and the appeal tribunals may well, if worked by men and women of good will and good intentions, meet the fears entertained with regard to the original proposals.
As to the original opposition to the working of the household means test, it has now been generally accepted that there are varying degrees of responsibility that exist in the family and that they differ according to the different relationships. The hon. Member for Hemsworth (Mr. G. Griffiths), in the course of a very moving and courageous speech, to which everybody listened with appreciation and interest, as they always do to his speeches, cited a base of a man in his constituency who, owing to the working of the original Regulations or some similar proposals, was driven into a lunatic asylum. That very case—I have taken steps to verify it—is one of the
cases where a brother-in-law is concerned and it will be met by the new Regulations, because that particular relationship will fall into the fourth group of people who cannot be obliged to have quite the same obligation as unmarried children or the parents of the applicant.
They told us that on the last occasion and they backed it in the Lobby, but it did not work out that way.

I am prepared to concede that the prophecies of some people as to the way in which the original Regulations would work might not have been justified, but after 18 months' hard survey, a nation-wide survey, we are assured, in so far as anyone can reasonably be assured, that the new Regulations will carry out the intentions of Parliament. As to the applicant, there has been considerable improvement from the point of view of those people who want to see the average applicant encouraged to take up small jobs and not to be penalised by the reduction of one-sixth of whatever he may earn, as under the other Regulations. With regard to the rent rule, the provision is that if the actual rent exceeds one-fourth of the total scale rates of the household there can be an increase in allowance. But it is also provided that this may be granted, if necessary, if it exceeds one-fifth or one-sixth. This should meet the fears of many people.
There has been very little reference to the wide discretionary powers which the Board are going to enjoy. That fact, taken in conjunction with local advice, is the real reason why the country as a whole are content to give these new Regulations a trial. They believe that the rates of allowances in which discretion shall exist, to meet such circumstances as needs consequent on prolonged unemployment, or in respect of rent divergence, and the general local flexibility to which we now look forward, may well meet the legitimate fears of those who are naturally anxious and concerned. If they do not, there is the procedure for removing those defects.
I can assure hon. Members opposite that they have no monopoly to speak for the working class or for the hardly-hit members of the working class. We on
this side of the House were elected by many working-class votes, and take pride in the fact that we have as much right to speak for British working-class people as any hon. Member opposite. It would surprise some hon. Members opposite if they could come into other working-class districts, which may not be so polite as they may be in the Hemsworth Division, to hear what some of the working class think of intellectual Socialists who push the working-class Socialists on from behind and collar all the good jobs when Socialist Governments come into office. Many hon. Members will agree with me that the welfare of the hardly-hit members of the working class is safe in the hands of the Government, who have a record of increased employment of which they can be proud.
The hon. Member has just said that he comes from an area which he considers to be one of the most prosperous in the whole of the British Isles.

May I interrupt the hon. Member? If that statement goes to my constituency, it may seem as though I had said they have nothing to worry about in that division, whereas what I said was that we were relatively prosperous and that we had the lowest rate of unemployment.

I am glad to hear that correction. I happen to come from a part of the country which has one of the highest unemployment rates in the North-Western area. It is rather strange that I should speak after the remarks of the hon. Member. During the last 12 months, in the area that I represent in the Western districts of Cumberland, the Whitehaven district in particular, nearly £350,000 has been paid out in standard benefit and transitional payments. Having regard to that fact, we are more than ordinarily interested in the effect that the new Regulations are likely to have in our district. May I say, in passing, that, in the county of Cumberland, which has not a Labour majority but a Tory majority, only in one instance are the new Regulations an improvement upon the present benefits which are paid in the area? Some young men will be dropping money to the tune of 7s. per week.
Is that a fair thing to do? Is it fair to say to any single man, "From such and such a date, your benefit will be reduced by 7s. per week"? I ask hon. Members opposite to come into the area where that will actually take place, and to speak to the men who are affected by the new Regulations. The Regulations as drawn up are brutal and inhuman, and they are unchristian in their direct incidence. We have not yet found out why the datum line has been fixed on these levels. Is any hon. Member prepared to get up on the other side and say that the mere pittance which is to be received by the people who have been unemployed for many years should be sufficient to keep them in decency and comfort while they are unemployed? Hon. Members get up who represent prosperous districts and talk about what the Regulations are; let them come into some of these districts—and I invite them to do so—and put the matter to men who have suffered many years of acute unemployment. I have no doubt what the answer would be. When hon. Members speak about the Regulations and about the means test, I suggest to them that the best way to discover the truth is to come on to the doorsteps in those areas. I have visited no fewer than 350 homes in my constituency, during the operation of the damnable and despicable means test. The tragedy which lies behind it all cannot adequately be expressed in words.
That is my answer to those who say that one kind of action should be meted out to the working class in some circumstances, and another kind of action under other circumstances. I tell hon. Members who talk of prosperity that I am not aware of one new industry having been established in my district during the time of the National Government. The position has become worse during that time. That is my reply to those who say that the National Government's programme and policy have brought prosperity. They have certainly not brought prosperity to the district from which I come.
Nor in the district from which the hon. Member for Mid Bedford (Mr. Lennox-Boyd) comes.

I cannot speak of his district, because I have no knowledge
of it. I cannot speak about a district with which I am not familiar. I want to ask hon. Members opposite, especially those of the younger generation, whether they submit that the amounts to be allowed under the Regulations will be sufficient to keep people in reasonable comfort and decency. Let me give one illustration. A fortnight ago a man came into the office of my party in my division, and said he had to go to the Midlands to do coal-mining work, but he had not a pair of clogs in which to go. Is that prosperity? Have those scales, which have been in operation as one of the highest of the scales operated by a Tory majority in the whole of this country, done justice? Why should a man be penalised if he is unfortunately unemployed as against the person who is fortunately employed? What answer to that have hon. Members on the other side? Why should we seek to degrade a man by the actions that we take because he is unemployed?
Let me put another point. The collieries in my area have been closed for a matter of 10 months. They may reopen at any time; I do not know. But what will be the difficulty when they are reopened? There will be thousands of men who will have no clothing with which to go down the pits to start work. They will not even have clogs. They have to have a clog fund in order that those men who go down the pit are suitably shod. What answer to that have the people who have talked about the usefulness of the new scales? It was no mere sentiment that the hon. Lady gave utterance to this morning, but actual facts and actual experience. Not only that, but we have had in my area the actual experience, time and time again, of young women who have not sufficient clothes to come to London for the purpose of going into domestic service. Is it right? Is it fair? Is it just? Is it, as the Home Secretary said, common sense to say to these people, "Because you are unemployed you cannot have the necessary food and the necessary clothing to keep you in decency and comfort"?
The hon. Member for Mid-Bedford (Mr. Lennox-Boyd) a few moments ago talked about what these Regulations would do. Let me put it another way round. I happen to be a railway man. We all know that railway men from time
to time are called upon, owing to weather conditions, on many occasions to work unbounded overtime. There is no alternative. Take a goods guards or an engine driver. You will say to that engine driver or goods guard by your Regulations that if he works 20 hours overtime, he does so for nothing if he has a son or daughter on transitional benefit. What have you to say to that? Has that been taken into consideration in any of these new clauses? Certainly not. Then there is another side to the question of the application of the means test. It is said that it will take into account rent, and that consideration will be given to other matters. Let me put this as a question: Suppose you have a newly married couple, and they have had to buy their furniture on the mortgage system. Is any account taken of the difficulty that they have to pay out instalments week by week and month by month? None at all. The objections which have been made against these Regulations are unanswerable from our point of view.
Let us take another aspect. We know that, owing to slum clearances and other clearances, people have to pay increased transport costs. If they apply a means test, why should not they have the proper allowance made for those extra transport costs which they have to pay now in order to get to their jobs? That is not taken into account. Then take, for instance, other costs, such as light and heating costs, which are not equal in all districts. I submit that the means test is an anomaly from the very beginning. It is an anomaly of a character that breeds other anomalies due to its own application. Consequently, we feel that it is much better to sweep away the test, and to see that justice and fair play are done to those people who are unfortunately unemployed.
The next point that I want to make is with regard to the single man. I have in mind the fact that the Commissioner for the Special Areas said that he thought that for men to join the Army was a very useful occupation for them. Is this the back road, the subterranean way, which the Government have adopted in order to compel and coerce single men to join the Army, the Navy, or the Air Force, as the case may be? Is this reduction per week which is coming to these single men, the back road which
is being adopted to get these men to join the various Forces? I venture to suggest that the campaign which will be carried on against the operation, not only of the means test, but of the Regulations, dividing the working class as against the working class, will be of a character that will compel this Government, with their huge power and their huge majority, to recant these Regulations as quickly as they brought them in.

There is no denying the gravity and seriousness of the problem which we have been discussing during the last three days. My own position is that I support the draft Regulations with far more confidence and assurance than I supported the Regulations in December, 1934, for the very definite reason that at the end of 1934 we were on the eve of a huge experiment in looking after the able-bodied poor; but now we have had 18 months' experience of the working of the Board, and it is because of that that I have far more confidence that these new Regulations will work out much more smoothly and much more efficiently.
I want to repeat one point on which there is misunderstanding in this House and on which there is misunderstanding outside it, namely, that the original Regulations were not withdrawn in February last year but were only in part superseded, the consequence being that 41 per cent. of the existing applicants are assessed under the existing Regulations. My time is limited, and we have had individual cases and details ad nauseam. I wish to summarise my reasons for supporting these Regulations. Firstly, there are a number of points on which we have definite improvement over the old Regulations. The Home Secretary enumerated no fewer than seven. I make the number eight, if you include the abolition of the family super-cut.
Another reason why I support the draft Regulations is that there is this new rent rule. That is a particular rule which will effect the most improvement in Scotland. The flexibility and discretion at which hon. Members opposite may sneer is undoubtedly a great improvement in the revised Regulations, because during the first few weeks of the operation of the existing Regulations, before the stand-still, it was manifest that there was un-
due rigidity and no opportunity for discretion to be applied. The flexibility and discretion on the advice of the advisory committee, which I do not over-rate but which will be valuable, will tend to smoother working. On the question of finance there is still some misunderstanding. The estimated increased cost of operating the new scale is £750,000 net. Hon. Members opposite have said that there was a serious miscalculation before and therefore we cannot rely on this new estimate.
