They are mistaken, for the reason that we have had 18 months' experience, and the Board and the Minister are in a far better position now to make an accurate estimate than they were previously. When the new Regulations appeared in the Press I noticed that the "Daily Herald" published an extravagant figure of the cuts which had been operated when the existing Regulations came into effect. The figure stated was £5,500,000. That sum has been repeatedly contested. I make the figure to be only £400,000 a year.
None of us wishes to see any reductions but they are inevitable if, in some cases, an applicant is getting a higher assessment than is given in other similar circumstances. That is one of the strong points of the new Regulations, that they will apply uniformity of treatment where the circumstances are similar. I would like to give my right hon. Friend a warning as regards the second appointed day next April. In my area a considerable number of those who have been unemployed will be taken over, and most of them have not been in Unemployment Insurance. I am informed that many of them live in low rented houses, and I want to give a warning that there, and possibly in other areas, unless there is special advice by the advisory committee and a special low rent formula adopted there may be a large number of cases of special hardship. I have made my own position clear and the position of my hon. Friends has also been made clear during the Debate. We are defending these Regulations. We accept them because they are a great improvement on the existing ones, and we believe they will work satisfactorily and reasonably.
I have been disappointed with the position of the party opposite. They have put down an Amendment but they have
avoided the duty which rests on them, if they wish to make their position clear—a duty which has been carried out by the now attentuated party below the Gangway and the party represented by the hon. Member for West Fife (Mr. Gallacher). They make it clear that they desire an extension of insurance benefit without any means test. That would mean the end of Unemployment Insurance. But the position of the Labour party is not so clear, and they will have to make up their minds what their position is. They are definitely committed to a distinction between insurance and those who are outside insurance, because it was they who set up the Royal Commission in 1930, and who were responsible for its terms of reference, to make the insurance scheme solvent and to make provision for those outside the scheme. The clear indication was that they wished for recommendations to enable them to work out a separate scheme for those outside insurance. The operation of transitional payments began in October, 1931, and the final report of the Royal Commission came out in 1932, with the recommendations for the separate scheme under the means test.
My conclusion is that these Regulations, which I intend to support, constitute a definite and carefully considered scheme which will be a step forward towards a final and a just solution of the problem of the able-bodied poor. This is not to be regarded as the last word in the solution of this problem. We must keep in mind the cost of living, and if there is variation in that the whole of these scales will require to be revised in due course. It has been admitted on all sides that what the unemployed wish for more than anything else is work rather than any kind of assistance. If the Board operate these Regulations and do not forget their other duties—this is of the greatest importance and has not been mentioned during the course of this Debate—the welfare of the unemployed, I believe that in the next year or so the position of those who are unfortunately unemployed will be very considerably ameliorated.

I am very glad indeed to have the opportunity of following the hon. Member for Central Edinburgh (Mr. Guy), who is one of the Members of this House who has tested the feeling of his
constituency on these Regulations, and I do not think that he will claim that they have received the Regulations with wild enthusiasm. I want to raise one or two points, because the time at my disposal is very limited and there are a number of other hon. Members who wish to speak. The hon. Gentleman the Member for Mid-Bedfordshire (Mr. Lennox-Boyd) was surprised that no mass agitation had yet arisen in the country over these Regulations. He seems to be in a bit of a hurry for a mass agitation. I would remind the House that the last agitation did not arise speedily. It did not arise in the country until the cuts were actually imposed. I had some hand in organising the mass agitation in my district at that time, and my experience was that it was exceedingly difficult to interest the unemployed until the cuts were actually imposed, but from the moment they were imposed there was no doubt what was going to happen, and it happened speedily, and the remedy came almost as speedily.
There is just a chance—as a matter of fact, there is a very strong probability—that when the cuts are imposed on the 16th November there will be such a mass agitation as will compel the Government to withdraw these Regulations, which in the main are the same as the old Regulations. They are framed upon the same lines, and are exactly what the Chancellor of the Exchequer said they were likely to be shortly after the stand-still Order was passed. I could turn to a speech of the right hon. Gentleman the Chancellor of the Exchequer and show that at that time, shortly after the standstill Order was made, he made a declaration that in principle the Regulations were sound—the Government still hold to that position—that all that was required was a slight modification here and there, and that with a little elasticity all would be well. There is no more in these Regulations than the Chancellor of the Exchequer hinted at months and months ago. Why they could not have had these Regulations long ere now is more than I can hope to understand.
I have promised to keep within a certain time because other hon. Members wish to take part in the Debate before it finishes, and I will therefore confine myself to one other point. The other day I asked the Minister of Labour for the number of local advisory committees to
be set up in Scotland and for the names of the chairmen, and the Minister of Labour has given me the answer. We are to have 22 local advisory committees in Scotland covering the whole of Scotland, and I have the names of the chairmen of these committees. If the local advisory committees which are to be set up are to be manned as they are being manned in respect of the chairmen, I am not sure that the unemployed would not be a great deal better off at the hands of the Board's officers than they will be under the local advisory committees. I would like the Minister to tell me whether there is a chairman of a local advisory committee in Scotland who is not a supporter of the National Government, and why the chairmanship of a local advisory committee cannot be entrusted to anyone who has Labour or Socialist sympathies. Are we always to assume that those who can take an impartial view of the needs of the unemployed must be supporters of the National Government, and that it is absolutely impossible for anyone holding Labour sympathies to be a chairman of a local advisory committee? If the membership of the Minister's local advisory committees is to be no better than the chairmanship, it would be very much better to leave the matter in the hands of the Board's officials and to trust to their good sense. Those officials do know something about the unemployed and their conditions, but many of those who have been appointed as chairmen of local advisory committees know absolutely nothing about the conditions of the unemployed.
We have had a good deal of discussion during these Debates upon the conditions in South Wales, and in Durham, and on the North-East coast generally, but we have heard comparatively little of the conditions existing in Scotland. The conditions in Scotland, and particularly in the West of Scotland, are as bad as, if not worse than, those in any other part of Great Britain, with perhaps the single exception of Jarrow. We have in the West of Scotland a most serious industrial situation. We have a huge mass of unemployment upon which nothing is making much impression. The schemes of the Government are making practically no impression on the mass of unemployed in that part of Scotland. I am not supposed to be in a distressed area, but in my constituency there are
something like 3,000 unemployed for whom there is evidently to be no amelioration or betterment, and certainly no chance of employment. Perhaps this is not an occasion on which to begin to discuss remedies for that situation, but the Minister need not be surprised if he finds that, even before the cuts are actually imposed on this occasion, there will be a sufficiently strong mass agitation to compel the Government to reconsider these Regulations.
I wish to join with those who have protested against these Regulations. I was against the last Regulations. I was not privileged to be here at that time, but outside I took up the line that they were not such as would be of advantage to the unemployed. There is little or no improvement as far as these Regulations are concerned. The elasticity which is supposed to be introduced may be subject to the advice of these local advisory committees, and I tell the Minister frankly that I shall have no confidence whatever in the local advisory committees advising the Board's representatives as to how they should deal with the unemployed in these particular areas. I shall join heartily with the rest of my party in opposing these Regulations, not only here to-night but throughout the length and breadth of the country.

We are nearing the end of this Debate, and those of us who listened to it as I did, during the whole of last night have heard many speeches from the Opposition benches. Many were sincere speeches, but in a number of cases they were unfortunately spoiled by ending with what sounded very much like a threat to stir up the country against the means test. It is a mistaken idea of hon. Members opposite to think that they are any more interested in or concerned with the unemployed than many of us, at any rate, if not all of us, on this side of the House. We are intimately associated with them and are every bit as sympathetic; in fact, I venture to say that some of us are more sincere than hon. Members opposite in our genuine desire to do good and to see their conditions improved. The means test, though it has to be kept on, is to be operated less harshly, which was a point we put forward at the last Elec-
tion. It is obvious that a great deal of time and trouble has been spent on these Regulations and that a great effort has been made to improve them, and with some considerable success. They may not be all that one would like them to be, but they are a great improvement on the previous Regulations. I notice that not many Members who represent Lancashire divisions have spoken.
We were not permitted to do so. We have tried day and night.

I have also been trying for two whole days to get an opportunity to speak. I was not proposing to make anything of that point, but Lancashire is one part of the country which will benefit under these Regulations. In the Lancashire county area, of which I am talking, we benefited under the last set of Regulations, and we shall benefit still more by these Regulations.
Not in the boroughs.

The need for uniformity was exceptionally great in Lancashire, more so, probably, than in any other part of the country, and that is why we welcome the Board taking over the administration. I want to refer to the Manchester second district, in which my constituency is situated. That district covers no less an area than 500 square miles, and it is described as being relatively compact. Formerly 10 public assistance authorities administered transitional payments in that area, and there were 65 relief committees. The variations in the allowances were very great. They varied very much in the case of a man and wife with a son, aged 18, earning 17s. a week, and a daughter, aged 17, earning 15s. a week. The allowance in such a case was as low as 7s. 6d. in one area, it was 10s. 6d. in another area, in a third area was 21s. 3d., and in still another area it was 26s. There was very great dissatisfaction with these variations; and no wonder, when a man living on one side of a street who had only 7s. 6d. a week coming into the house looked across the street and saw a house where no less than 26s. was coming in. That actually happened—one side of the street being in the county area and the other side in a certain county borough. There is a case of a man assessed on a borough scale who was found, afterwards, to be in the county, and his allowance
was reduced by no less than 12s. 6d. It is an excellent thing that such cases will no longer be possible.
I wish to refer to one or two instances in which I think the present Regulations are a great improvement. A man and wife with no resources but with dependants will receive the equivalent of the full benefit rate, 26s. a week. That is an excellent thing. Then there is the position of the head of the household in certain cases under paragraph 39 of the Board's explanatory Memorandum. From time to time, when visiting houses, I have been met at the door by the head of the house, who has complained to me that he never had 6d. in his pocket at the end of the week, or at any time, with which to buy a packet of cigarettes. In scores of cases I have been met by that remark; in fact, it has been the remark made to me more frequently than any other in connection with the means test. Therefore, I am pleased to see that something is to be done for the head of the household in a case where, owing to earnings coming into the home, he has not been able to have anything he could call his own. I hope the Board will construe paragraph 39 in the most favourable way possible. I do not propose to read it all, but it deals with the case of an applicant who is an elderly man with a long industrial record in the past and poor prospects for the future, and where the wages coming in are sufficient to support him but do not leave a large margin for the sons and daughters. In such cases a small allowance is to be secured to the applicant for his personal requirements, so that he will not be completely dependent on the earnings of his children. That was scoffed at very much by the junior Member for Dundee (Mr. Foot) yesterday afternoon, but I think it is a genuine attempt to improve conditions, and I do hope that use will be made of the paragraph.
Another improvement is that there is fairer provision for the earning members of a family, and we trust and believe that that will help to prevent sons and daughters from leaving home, which has been one of the tragedies of the means test. There is no doubt that the numbers who have left home have been greatly exaggerated, but, nevertheless, this has been a very serious point, and it has resulted in some cases in the breaking up
of homes. On page 21 of the Regulations it states: It is proper that an applicant should be better off if he obtains some work than if he has none. That, of course, is the case. I should like to say that as regards Lancashire the wages are very low in some branches of the cotton industry. That is no fault of the Government; they do not control wages. Nor is it due to the great profits which are being made in the industry. It is simply due to the slump which has been created by the competition which has been going on for so many years. I have received complaints from men who are working full time in the cotton industry that people on transitional payment are better off than those earning full wages. That, I know, is perfectly true. Complaint has also been made of the six days waiting period for those who are in and out of work, as compared with the people on transitional payments who have no waiting period at all. The time must come when wages will have to be supplemented in some way. I know it is a difficult matter, but they are so low in some branches of the cotton industry that the position undoubtedly is becoming somewhat serious.
In my opinion the personal factor is going to count a tremendous lot in the administration of these Regulations. There must be area officers and other officials of the Board who will fit into their job as to the manner born, because it is going to be very difficult work. If anyone does not look like being a success, I suggest that he should be transferred somewhere else and his position filled by one who will make a success of it. I do not think that there are many like that, but there may be one here and there. It is not always possible to get the best man for a job straight away. During the last 18 months the Board has done most excellent work, and it would appear that it is doing well as regards the officers who are in the various positions. There must not be too much red tape or rule of thumb in this administration. That is a vitally important point, to my mind, because upon it will depend the success or non-success of the Regulations. Are they going to be administered in a sympathetic way? I think they will be so administered, but it cannot be too highly stressed. On page 29 of the Regulations it says:
The Board are anxious that applicants should not only be fairly treated but should feel that they are fairly treated; they believe that in the end this will depend upon the relations between the Board's officers and the applicants. That is true and bears out what I have said. A great deal of discretion is to be used by the officers. I read on page 170 in connection with the Manchester second district, in the report of last year: Area officers have come to feel that an arithmetical calculation is merely a background for the exercise of discretion in a number of ways. Imagination and experience have enabled them to evolve a welfare service which has done a great deal to restore the self respect of our people. From what I have seen of the area officers in Lancashire, I know that they are carrying out this job very well. I have seen letters of grateful thanks which they have received for the help they have given in individual cases. In that way this work is going to be a success. They are the go-betweens between the advisory committees and the Board. Also, the great voluntary social services are doing a great deal in various parts of the country in voluntary work of one sort and another. On them rests a tremendous responsibility, and I feel sure, from what I know, that they will carry out their duties well. I support these Regulations. I think the Minister of Labour and the Board have done their best in a very trying and difficult situation. It has taken a long time, but I think it has been worth while taking that time. They have done their work, as far as we can see, well. Time alone will show how the Regulations will work out. This, of course, is not the final word. We shall have to see how they work and how they can be improved. Meanwhile I hope that hon. Members on this side of the House and hon. Members of the Liberal party—I suppose it is too much to hope that hon. Members in the whole House—will give their support to these Regulations.
rose—

On a point of Order. I should like to ask whether it will be possible for some of us to put questions which have been in our minds for 33 hours, waiting for the Parliamentary Secretary. I want to warn him now that I want to put them, and I
expect to get a reply before the Vote is taken.

We have had a very prolonged Debate on subjects of most vital importance, which stir the emotions of hon. Members, and we are discussing them under conditions in which it is not possible for us to amend the Regulations. The choice before us is either to approve or to reject them. Therefore it is useless for hon. Members to suggest that speeches should have been full of practical suggestions for alterations. Under the Act we only have the option of acceptance or rejection. Everyone will agree that the speeches in the Debate have reached and kept a very high level. It will be agreed by everybody that the speeches from this side of the House have been made by men and women who know what they are talking about. When I say that, I am not referring only to the question of knowing figures, of knowing what is in the White Paper, or knowing the details of administration. They know the human beings with whom we are concerned. These figures in the White Paper of tens and hundreds of thousands are to Members on these benches men, women and children whom they know, whom they have been brought up with and worked with, and that lends a quality of emotion to the Debate.
Secondly, the sums of money that we hear discussed, the 14s. or 24s., or whatever it may be, are not just figures in a ledger. Members on this side know exactly what they mean in terms of housing accommodation, in terms of food, clothing and boots, in terms, in fact, of human beings. I am not suggesting that there is a lack of sympathy on the other side, but there is necessarily greater knowledge on this side of what these Regulations really mean. I think the essential difference between speeches made from these benches and speeches of Ministers is that the speakers have a different sense of values. It seems to me that it is just this that made the Home Secretary's speech so unimpressive and so irritating to Members on these benches. With all his grasp of the subject, with all his mental ability, it was quite clear that he did not really know his subject.
I do not propose to deal with details, to make comparisons between different
scales and different sets of figures, or to weigh up exactly the changes that have been made and how they operate in this or that part of the country. I want to remind the House again that these are Regulations made under the law, and that law embodies the household means test, and it has not been amended. Whatever Regulations are made under it, the law remains the same, the law that requires the whole resources of the household to be taken into consideration. We claim that the Election speeches that were made on the subject of the means test have not been redeemed by these changes, because the essentials of the law remain, and all that we have here are certain interpretations. In these interpretations there is left the widest scope for discretion. The discretion of an official may work in one way or it may work in another way. This discretion is exercised by officials of a Board over which this House has no control. When we pass these Regulations the matter passes into the hands of the Board. Remember what is behind that Board after all, and what is behind these Regulations. There is one figure which has not appeared in these discussions but which is really the master figure of all, and that is the Chancellor of the Exchequer. In the long run the amount that is to be given to this section of the community is not decided by the weighing-up of need, but by the Chancellor of the Exchequer. At the back of the Board's officials, as time goes on, in the use of their discretion there will always be that steady financial pressure which is necessarily exercised.
I want to deal with the principle embodied in these Regulations. The Act of 1934, under which they are made, does not embody any new principle at all. It is a return to the principle of the 1834 Poor Law. That is essentially what the Act does. The 1834 Poor Law is embodied in these Regulations, with all the difficulties of 1834 and with the whole doctrine of less eligibility. Reference has been made to the difficulty that wages are so low in Lancashire that they may well be below the scale that is laid down. The Secretary of State for Scotland, in dealing with the fixing of these figures, said that they had regard to the needs of the people, the cost of living, and the rate of wages, but what happens where the rates of wages are not sufficient to provide for the needs of the people?
It is the needs of the people that give way. Any one who has any experience of Poor Law administration knows that the difficulty that faces the Poor Law throughout is the fact that, with wages at their level in many industries, you are bound, if you want to keep your people in health and strength, to provide them with Poor Law relief or public assistance on a scale actually higher than the wages that they are getting. That was the thing on which the 1834 Poor Law broke down, and every Poor Law has broken down, and these Regulations will break down.
The fact is that to give assistance, having regard to rates of wages, is incompatible with providing for the proper needs of people in a civilised country. The 1834 Poor Law principle is brought in again and it looks anomalous to-day, because this is an age in which we have departed from the idea that every individual or every group should stand by itself. The old Victorian idea that wages and profits should be governed by some kind of self-regulating medium of competition has gone. In this House almost every week, by legislation, we alter the distribution of the national wealth. We determined the allocation of purchasing power. We were doing it only last Friday in the case of the cattle industry. By quotas and subsidies of one kind and another we have altered the distribution of wealth. We say that a certain section of the community shall be entitled to take more than it could get in free competition from the pockets of the rest of the community. Almost every week we do that in Orders that come to us from the Import Duties Advisory Committee. I wonder whether it has ever struck hon. Members opposite that the Import Duties Advisory Committee is the Unemployment Assistance Board of the well-to-do.
But no means test.

That is the point to which I was coming. There is no means test. That point was admirably put some time ago by the hon. Member for North Paddington (Mr. Bracken), who said that this House had become an almshouse for shareholders. But there is no inquiry, no means test. Shareholders do not work as shareholders, landlords do not work as landlords, but they are recipients of Government bounty and they are held to be entitled to have their standard of
life made up from the rest of the community without any inquiry at all. What becomes then of the special pleading of the Home Secretary? Who has ever inquired into the income of the wife of a cattle dealer, for instance, or the wife of a shipowner? Who knows what their sons get or what their daughters get? Who knows the composition of their households? The principle put forward so eloquently by the Home Secretary may be all right, but why does he not apply it all round?
The fact is that this is, frankly, class legislation. One measure is meted out to one section of the community and another measure to another section of the community. It is not openly avowed except occasionally by accident. For instance, the hon. and learned Member for the West Derby Division of Liverpool (Mr. Fyfe) let it slip out in the course of this Debate when he said that special arrangements should be made for the black-coated workers who are unemployed. I have every sympathy with the black-coated worker, but merely because he is a black-coated worker, why should the application of the principle in his case be different from what it is in the case of anybody else? What you are really doing here is to put a huge section of the community on a very low standard of life. That is what the decision as to these figures means. It means that this represents what the House considers to be right for this huge section of the community. We, on this side, claim that you are wasting our national assets and restricting consumption, as well as inflicting extreme cruelty on masses of the people.
The truth about the means test is that you have to consider its application to actual conditions. It is no good having arguments as to the position of wife and husband and family and how much each contributes. You have to consider the people who will come under the means test. You have to consider the actual conditions in Jarrow, in South Wales, in Durham, in Lanark, in Lancashire. You are not dealing here merely with sporadic poverty due to the defects of the individual, but with deep-seated mass poverty. This is no temporary deprivation of work with which we have to deal. It is endemic unemployment. What you do by these proposals is to say, first,
that the relief to the unemployed shall be by families. You have all these families grouped together where there is 75 per cent. or 80 per cent. of unemployment, and by these Regulations you are going to spread the level of poverty all round. No one can rise above that level. With all our belief in individual initiative, there is no chance for anyone to rise. The individual cannot escape. Families have become a prison, and the links of national affection have become economic fetters. The result is bitterness, shame, and hatred in place of pride and love in the family.
That is perhaps the most serious effect of all of these Regulations applied throughout the country to areas which everybody admits have been suffering, not through the fault of individual workers there, but through economic conditions; and to those areas, where the Government have failed to do anything substantial to provide work, you are refusing adequate maintenance. The people will not rest while these conditions obtain. You may say that these Regulations are necessary because you have to have regard to wages. You may say that you cannot do anything better under your system. Then your system must go. I do not believe that the clever device of the gradual introduction of cuts will stop the deep-seated wrath of an outraged people. Sooner or later the Government will pay for these Regulations, just as they paid for the last Regulations.

speech.speakername: The PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY to the MINISTRY of LABOUR (Lieut.-Colonel Muirhead)
speech.p: rose—

Will the hon. Gentleman permit me to put two questions? First, how is it expected that a person owning a house in which he does not live will realise the 11s. per week which he is expected to do? Second, how is the man to fare who is an injured workman in receipt of 5s. or 10s. per week compensation, and is forced into commutation by an insurance company and realises £350?

The number of questions which have been put in the Debate by hon. Members has been very considerable, and in the time at my disposal I can deal with only a certain number. One of the questions was
put by the hon. Member himself in the Debate, but I really cannot guarantee to give it consideration in place of other questions which were put. Twelve hours ago the hon. Member for Aberdare (Mr. G. Hall) said it was a very remarkable Debate. The same thought had occurred to me, and in order to help political statisticians I got out a few figures. I found that in the course of the first two days of the Debate, for which I have the authority of the OFFICIAL REPORT, there were 29 speeches and 216 points of Order, interruptions and interjections. After 11.30 p.m. on Wednesday, I think the average fell a certain amount, but at all events it gained in variety, because one hon. Lady and one Noble Lady put what I may call points of ventilation. In these days, when, undoubtedly, Parliamentary business is crowded, to give three days to a Debate is a significant thing, particularly when that Debate is simply going to finish conclusively with an "Aye" or a "No"; and it does show the very important issues which that "Aye" or that "No" involve.
My right hon. Friend, in his opening speech, said that the matter which we are discussing to-night is not a departmental matter, but one of the widest social and political importance. That is quite true. To-night's Debate is only a stage in a long history. The hon. Member for Kingswinford (Mr. A. Henderson) took us back to Elizabethan times, when the State began to assist those in need; he then referred to Queen Anne; and the right hon. Gentleman the Leader of the Opposition has dealt with the year 1834. That shows the length of history with which we are dealing, and I think that the period of 18 months which has elapsed since the Bill became law—18 months which some hon. Members said were so unnecessarily long—when we take a perspective of the history of the whole, is really a very short period. Having heard the hon. Member for Dunfermline (Mr. Watson) ask why we had not brought the Regulations forward before, it disappointed me when a little later I heard that now we have brought them forward he is going to vote against them.
Now, it is true that on this subject, as on any subject discussed in this House, whether it be agriculture, shipping, coal or education, there are hon. Members who are specially interested in the sub-
ject and specially qualified to speak on it, hon. Members who, in the homely language of the Leader of the Opposition, know particularly well what they are talking about; but that does not in the least mean that this subject is the close preserve of those who have a particularly large number of unemployed in their constituencies or happen to have suffered unemployment themselves. This subject cannot be dealt with sectionally, but has to be dealt with nationally, for its roots go down far too deep; and it is because I am convinced that we have handled this subject, as we handle many other subjects, more from a national point of view and less from a sectional point of view than hon. Members opposite, that it is we and not they who are handling this particular problem to-day.
There have been a great many points put and answered from both of the back benches. Hon. Members on this side who have answered points and made their speeches—it has been insinuated sometimes, as representatives of a class—have made those speeches as a tangible result of the vote of a democratic electorate of 30,000,000 in this country. What are our political grounds for bringing forward these Regulations? At the end of 1934 and the beginning of 1935, we embarked on a big enterprise, We tried to run this system on centralised lines. Though a lot of people might not agree with the particular form which those centralised lines took, undoubtedly there had been a considerable demand from many quarters for a greater centralisation of this problem. We got into difficulties, and to use partly the theatrical and partly the homely language of the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Wakefield (Mr. Greenwood), the Government had to come to the House in sackcloth and ashes and say that they were very sorry, and would try again. I am going to take his remark. Undoubtedly, the best thing of all is to succeed in the first place, but, if you do not, there is nothing derogatory in trying again. But when one starts to try again, the question is, will one be given a chance of trying again? That is the question which was asked at the General Election, and which was answered decisively in our favour. The hon. Member for East Wolverhampton (Mr. Mander) said that
The Government were in the difficulty that they were facing a General Election, and they did not know how to get over the Election safely, with the means test question. Then came a God-sent League of Nations stunt, since abandoned, and that got them over the General Election. From the point of view of the Deity and of that organisation which the hon. Member has made so peculiarly his own in this House, I think the remark was hardly in good taste, but I am sure that hon. Members opposite who have stressed, and rightly stressed, the tremendous importance of the subject, must agree that it is so important domestically that it could not be, and in fact was not, completely overshadowed at the General Election by anything else. We got our chance of trying again by stating frankly and fearlessly to the country the lines on which we proposed to proceed. One of the things that we laid down in our Election manifesto was that we proposed to maintain the framework of the Act of 1934—that meets the point made by the Leader of the Opposition—and we stated perfectly clearly that we intended to maintain the means test. Consequently, the nation gave us another chance to try again, and we are trying again to-night. After all, when the Labour party got into its last big set of governmental difficulties, in 1931, it was just because it did not show any signs of being sorry or of appreciating the need to be sorry that the country has not up to now given the Labour party another chance. Our success at the General Election is all the more remarkable from the fact that, leaving aside the Election of 1918, which, I think it will be agreed, was quite exceptional, this is the first time in 25 years that a Government in this country has been returned for a second time running. Consequently, we not only got a definite mandate, at the last Election, but in point of fact, if we did not proceed with these Regulations, we should be false to the mandate that we obtained. We have heard a great deal about the means test. Many points of view have been put to-day. My right hon. Friend the Home Secretary has dealt with the subject from an extremely practical point of view. I do not want to touch on the controversial points of comparatively recent history, namely, the question whether the means test started in 1931
or it did not, or what was the nature of a particular circular. They are important points but they do not happen to be the points with which I wish to deal to-night. I want to say a few words about my conception of family means because the means test in the new Regulations is no more than a family means test. No one who is not a blood relation is treated other than a boarder; in point of fact, some people of blood relationship, like married sons, are going to be treated as boarders too.
One would think from the way hon. Members opposite talk that the whole idea of mutual family support started in 1931. The conception of the family is one of the oldest in history and the idea of mutual family support has been most general in point of fact in all parts of the world. In the realm of human nature the principle of mutual family support holds a very high place. Hon. Members are always talking about making this problem a human problem. That is what I want to do. Not all human nature is good and society has set itself in many places to limit or abolish certain objectionable features of human nature but that does not in the least imply that legislation and human nature have always to be antagonistic. In many cases legislation come forward and supports, assists and confirms very good features of human nature. Who would suggest that mutual family support is a bad thing?
In the past before there were social services the family had to maintain itself mutually and I see no reason now that legislation has come, so to speak, to the aid of that aspect of human nature why we should proceed to reverse our whole conception of it. Because legislation has come to the aid of the family I do not see why against legislation there should be put all the movements perhaps unfortunate movements, which may take place in family life. The hon. Member for Leigh (Mr. Tinker) said that every man likes to feel that at least he can keep himself and that he does not like to think that he has to go to the other members of the household for relief. If a man thinks that now he surely ought always to have thought it. It is not merely legislation that has done that: Therefore hon. Members opposite are entirely wrong in thinking that the desire to keep themselves, and not to depend on
other members of the family, feelings that they must have had throughout the course of human nature, are going to be changed merely because of legislation. Just because legislation has stepped in to make the conditions of the family much easier, there is no reason why certain things which have always happened to be so should be laid at the door of legislation. I stress that important difference because I am convinced, and I can see it by the attitude of hon. Members opposite, that this conception of legislation with regard to human society is one of the gulfs which separate hon. Members on the opposite side from hon. Members on this side.
Now I want to say a word on the question of administration. The problem which the Government have faced is that of grafting a central system of administration on to a wide range of local and personal inequality. That is the problem which we have been set. We might have put down a simple hard-and-fast scale, a rigid scale, and said that local and personal inequalities could look after themselves. We might have put down a very complicated scale by trying to deal specifically with all the detailed conditions and thus stereotype the inequalities for all time. The third alternative was to have what my hon. and learned Friend the Lord Advocate said was a background of uniformity—a very good phrase—by which we could gradually bring the central scale and the local inequalities into touch with each other. In the matter of administration of this scale it is really pace, just as much as policy, which is the important thing.
A further point about the human problem: Granted that you must have a scale, and granted that you must have rules; they have either to be rigid or flexible. If you have great rigidity, you reduce the human element to a minimum. The hon. Member for East Wolverhampton (Mr. Mander) would reduce the officers of the Board simply to calculating machines. If you have a flexible scale, flexibility implies discretion and discretion implies trust in someone; you cannot get away from that ultmately. In this case, we propose to trust the Board's officers. They are to have the assistance of the local advisory committees. Hon. Members seem to have been in unnecessary difficulties as to whether these committees were merely to be advisory or
not. We have said over and over again that they are to be only advisory. That is why we call them advisory committees. [Interruption.] I would hardly have thought it necessary to make that kindergarten remark, but for the fact that hon. Members opposite appear to have been, for the greater part of the Debate, under the impression that the committees were to have an executive function.
Hon. Members are not prepared to trust that discretion. I do not know whether they are not prepared to trust the particular individuals who compose the Board, or the Board's staff. At all events we have laid down a method by which discretion is to be administered and the particular points in which it is to be exercised; and in the Board's White Paper there is on record, a record which they could not disregard even if they wanted to, the sort of terms on which they are supposed to exercise that discretion in certain instances. You can do away with discretion, but do not say then that you are in favour of making this a human problem.
Now, if I may, I will deal with a variety of points which have been raised in the Debate, but I am afraid, as is usual at the end of a long Debate, the answers are bound to be scrappy and disconnected. The hon. Member for Dundee (Mr. Foot) and the hon. Member for Stretford (Mr. Crossley) both asked to what extent the local advisory committees would wish to hold their meetings in public. The question to what extent their meetings will be held in public will be for the committees themselves to decide in consultation with the Board. The hon. Member for Dundee made, if I may say so, an extremely good and well-reasoned speech, and I say at once that the points he raised could form the subject of a speech in themselves. Perhaps he will allow me to say that he wins on one or two, and that on others I think he has only to credit the Board with the exercise of common sense. The question, for instance, of a man having only 6d. or 1s. due to him being allowed to have it if he thinks it is worth collecting. The answer is where it is a small sum in relation to big resources, one cannot really say that the case is in particular need.
Then the hon. Member inquired whether the allowance for special circumstances
would be added to the ordinary assessment. What happens is that you first of all make the assessment on the basis of the Regulations, taking into consideration the allowance for special circumstances. If that happens to come to more than the benefit fall back, then you take the Regulations scale. If it does not happen to come to more than the benefit fall back, then you take the benefit fall back. It is wrong to imagine that the benefit fall back is the upper limit. It is merely something which the applicant can take if it happens to be more favourable than the full assessment under the Regulations.
Then we come to one of his winners—where the wife is earning 24s., will the man and wife therefore suffer a reduction? On the figures he quoted that undoubtedly is the case. The same thing happens in the case of a boy of 18; there will be a reduction. The hon. Member will agree that I have answered the substance of his questions. At the end he said that this was a cheese-paring, small amount that might be left out of account without damaging anybody. But he cannot have it both ways. The hon. Member for Chester-le-Street (Mr. Lawson) and other hon. Members had the idea that there was a sum of 10s. which was the limit set to the discretionary allowances which the Board's officers might make. That is a misconception. The area officers have a limit of 5s. above which they cannot exercise their discretion, but if they think there should be a bigger sum, application can be made to the district officer, and within his discretion he can add to it.
Does the district officer have to report to the Board?

No. The hon. Member for Chester-le-Street said there was going to be 400,000 reductions. I shall not forget that figure, and I shall not forget to remind him of it and of any other figure which may prove that he is wrong. Both he and the hon. Member for Abertillery (Mr. Daggar) are under a misapprehension that all the people at present getting transitional payments will receive cuts. That is not so. I know cases on transitional payments now which will receive more under the new Regulations. There was some misunderstanding between the hon. Member for
Chester-le-Street and the Home Secretary regarding the question of the proportion of applicants with and without resources. It is clear that there is a difference between those people with resources and those people with available resources, and this I think led to the misunderstanding. The hon. Member for Rhondda (Mr. Mainwaring) asked whether the special circumstances allowance would apply to all the 12,000 people in his district. The question of living in a particular district would not generally be a justification for special allowances.
I did not refer to 12,000 people living there, but to a body of men who have been uniformly idle for 12 years, and I asked whether that would constitute for them a special circumstance.

I cannot possibly adjudicate on specific cases put to me on the spur of the moment. The hon. Member for Hemsworth (Mr. G. Griffiths), whose speech I am sorry I did not hear, raised the point about the Memorandum for the officers regarding the manner in which the normal earnings should be ascertained of persons working on short time. The instruction is not put into the Regulations because it is an instruction and not a Regulation, but the instruction has not been withdrawn. Exactly the same principles are carried out as in the past.
It is not in now.
I thought that the hon. Member liked it so.
I say that it is not in now.
But it has been operated, and there will be no change in that particular operation. It is not in the Regulations.
Why did not you leave it in?

It is in its proper place. It is not in the Regulations because it is an instruction and not a regulation. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for Bow and Bromley (Mr. Lansbury) raised a variety of points, and in fact, judging by my question list,
he was actually the most inquisitive Member of the House taking part in the Debate to-day. He asked about the verification of earnings and what steps were being taken on that matter. Whenever possible the Board's investigating officers ask for the production of pay lists. Where these are not forthcoming, a confidential inquiry is made from the applicant's employer, and as a general rule those confidential inquiries, once made, are not repeated for a matter of six months. Naturally, the Board takes into consideration very carefully the desirability of not doing anything to injure the applicant, and in point of fact only a few complaints are received in that respect.

Would the hon. and gallant Gentleman be able to get us a return of the number of the investigations that have been made and of the number of complaints during the period it has operated? I know of a considerable number of people complaining of the application to their employer for verification of wages because the parent or someone is in receipt of relief or public assistance.

I will certainly look into that matter and see whether the information which the right right hon. Gentleman wants can be obtained. The right hon. Gentleman asked what is the Treasury official doing on the Board; what is he there for? He is there to be Vice-Chairman of the Board, and he is no more representative of the Treasury on the Board than, say, Lord Rushcliffe is a representative of another place.
Oh, no, that will not do.

Another question was as to the position of a son and daughter living in the house but apart from the family. Those questions have to be decided actually on the facts as laid down in the Regulations. It is a question of fact. Undoubtedly in those circumstances a son and daughter would be presumed to be living as part of the household.

I am sorry to interrupt the hon. and gallant Gentleman, but this is rather important. If any of the relatives who are liable are living in
rooms in the same house apart from the household, is it right to make them part of the household when they are not actually living as part of the household?
It would be a question of fact which would have to be decided on the merits of the case.

This point is of immense importance to South Wales. Up to the present the policy pursued by the Board has been to recognise apartments as separate households, whether the inhabitants of the apartments were sons or daughters or other people. Is there any intention to depart from that policy.
No, I should say that in the particular circumtances which the hon. Member outlined, probably there is no intention to do so.
Now what does that mean?
It means what I have said. I am not an officer of the Board and therefore I have not got the specific case in front of me.

I want—[HON. MEMBERS: "Order!"] What the deuce is the matter with you? On a point of Order? Is not this House, which is asked to vote on these Regulations, entitled to an understanding of what the Regulations mean? Nobody on the Government side can tell us, not a single one. It is one big lot of treachery and deceit.
The hon. Member may shout at me as much as he likes, but he is not going to get me to give a decision on a case which I have not in front of me.
Will it not be possible and legal under the Regulations for the family to subdivide itself into separate rooms and live under the one roof and be entitled to the fullest allowance?

I have already said that these are cases which have to be decided on their merits. The hon. Member for Caerphilly (Mr. Morgan Jones) and one or two other Members raised the question of why such a high rate of interest as 9½ per cent. is presumed on capital investments. It is not merely a question of considering
what interest could be obtained from that particular amount of capital, but there is the presumption that a certain amount of the capital itself will be used. That is why, when hon. Members translate the whole thing into a rate of interest, which it is not intended to be, it does undoubtedly appear to be rather high.

On a point of Order. Are we not entitled to get a reply? [HON. MEMBERS: "NO."] I am addressing the Speaker, and not you. Here is a Regulation which states that if I am the owner of a house valued at £300 it is assumed, in the words of the hon. and gallant Member, that 11s. per week of that house is available for my consumption. How can I get that 11s. a week? The Regulations do not explain it, nor has the Minister explained it, and nobody seems to know.

I have answered questions put to me in debate and answered one of the hon. Member's questions which he put in an interruption of some other speaker, and I think I have treated the hon. Member extremely well.
Is it in order for us, since the Parliamentary Secretary admits his complete ignorance of the Regulation, to appeal to the Minister of Labour to explain it?
That is not a point of Order.

The other hon. Member for Dundee and the hon. Member for Paisley (Mr. Maclay) raised the question as to whether women who had to go to work and had to incur expense in the care of their children would receive any consideration—whether the expense of looking after their children would be taken into consideration. No doubt such expenditure would come within the range of special circumstances. The hon. Member for Normanton (Mr. T. Smith) asked how the wages of men at the pits would be averaged. They will be averaged for a period of four weeks.
These people have been out of work for a considerable time, and I want to know whether the average will be taken on the wages they last earned or on the wages paid for the class of work.
Where it is a question of wages it is the rate which the worker may be presumed to be earning when he was in full employment, averaged on a four weeks' period.

This point affects a large number of people. A man falls out of work; he is out of work for some time, and he comes under the Regulations, which say that he must not receive an allowance equal to the amount he would have received if he had been in normal work. Will the average be based on the last four weeks he was in work or on the amount he would have earned at that time?

It would be based on the amount which he would be presumed to have earned if he had been in full employment. There is one other question raised by the hon. Member for the English Universities (Miss Rathbone).

I put a point in my speech last night which has not been answered, in reference to the amount which will be taken from compensation payments. I instanced a case which unfortunately is not uncommon in coalmining areas, where an unfortunate man suffered a fracture of the spine. He is kept in bed and must have someone to look after him. In that sort of case will half the compensation be taken or will the advisory committees be entitled to make recommendations?

It is laid down that one-half of any weekly amount under workmen's compensation shall be disregarded, and there is always provision for special circumstances or exceptional need, two categories in which the Board's officers have the greatest scope for exercising discretion.
Would the advisory committees be entitled to recommend that in view of the special circumstances no amount should be taken away?
Local advisory committees were specifically enjoined to give advice on certain subjects, but it is hoped that they will be available for consultation on a great many other points.

I am sorry to persist, but cannot we have a straight, definite reply? Do I gather that the advisory committees have no power to deal with this rule and in the case of a man with a broken spine half the compensation will be taken away and put into the family pool?
I have explained that local advisory committees have no executive powers in any respect. We have never suggested that they have. They are simply advisory.
Then I am right in saying the Regulations will take half the compensation?
The hon. Gentleman is not necessarily right in saying anything of the sort.
Is he right or wrong?
The hon. Member must really give the Minister a chance of answering.
On a point of Order. Is it right, when a simple answer "Yes" or "No" can be given to the question, that the Minister should reply in that way?
There are very few questions to which such an answer can be given.

I think I have already dealt with all the questions which have been put to me. [HON. MEMBERS: "No!"] I ask the House what are the foundations on which these Regulations are based? The late Lord Balfour, I believe, once said, "We are so sure of our foundations that we can afford to differ." What Lord Balfour meant was that when we are sure of our foundations, we can afford to discuss the detailed methods which are based on those foundations. On what is our system of unemployment insurance and these Regulations based? On what is this sum of money, involved in unemployment insurance, based—this sum which hon. Members opposite are always so anxious to compare, first with one item of national expenditure and then with another? On what is the whole structure of our social services based? Many hon. Members in the course of the Debate have referred, and rightly referred, to
the question of financial stability. Today, 23rd July, is a notable date because 23rd July marked the end of a period. Five years ago to-morrow there was signed one of the most notable public documents of the post-war period, the report of the May Committee.
We all know what that report disclosed—bad trade, unemployment, a drain on the social services, financial stringency and lack of confidence, all leading to destruction. The hon. Member for Bridgeton (Mr. Maxton) asked us whether we say that the sum spent on unemployment insurance had brought about the financial crisis of 1934. No, it was not the actual sum of money—it was the tendency it disclosed. We all know the result of the May Committee Report. We all know how hon. Members opposite shirked the task and how we undertook it. We all know how in the past five years a democratic electorate of 30,000,000 people has twice confirmed this Government's policy at General Elections. We commend these Regulations to the House to-night, not merely because they are good Regulations, but because, under the present Government, their foundations are secure.
rose—
Divide!

I beg to move, "That the Debate be now adjourned."
I do this to give the Minister an opportunity to enlighten hon. Members as to the nature of the Regulations. The action of the Government in submitting the Regulations is unprecedented and a treachery upon the workers. They have during three days endeavoured to console themselves that these Regulations are vastly different and an improvement on those of 18 months ago. [Interruption.] If hon. Members want another few hours in the House, I am prepared to keep them here. I have been here since 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and I do not mind remaining until 10 o'clock tomorrow if that will chasten the rowdy souls on the other side. What I am concerned about is whether they understand the Regulations. There are only three things they have endeavoured to do. They have tried to claim to be as sincere as we are. My reply is that a cannibal consumes his victim with sincerity also.
That is the sort of sincerity of hon. Members opposite.
They have endeavoured to prove contradictory actions of this party. We are not concerned with that. What really matters is the future of the people under these Regulations. They have tried to prove that these Regulations are a vast improvement on the old ones. If they were examined by eminent lawyers on the Front Bench, they would be compelled to say that the Regulations were very much the same. The Minister of Labour took over a thankless job from his predecessor, who honourably withdrew the old Regulations and then threw in his cards. The present Minister brings in Regulations which the other Minister withdrew rather than impose them on the country. How is anybody going to benefit from the Regulations? Do children up to 16 benefit? Great play is made of the fact that children from 16–18 will get an increase of 2s. per week. If the Minister of Labour cared to enlighten the House about the number of children in this country during these two years, it would be a very interesting fact for hon.

Members. I stand here to-night representing one of the most distressed divisions in this country. There is not in this country a division like Rhondda, East. Rhondda, West, and Rhondda, East, together, out of a population of 135,000, have 25,000 men unemployed.
The hon. Member is entitled only to give his reasons for moving to adjourn the Debate.

I am doing that, Sir. These Regulations have been submitted as a vast improvement in the condition of the people. Not a single Member on the opposite side of the House has advanced evidence indicating that improvement. They cannot even explain how the Regulations are to be applied. We on this side have every reason to believe that they will be used to the considerable injury of the present unemployed population of this country. It is for those reasons that I have moved the adjournment of the Debate.
Question put, "That the Debate be now adjourned."
The House divided: Ayes, 162; Noes, 372.

publicwhip.major-heading: Orders of the Day — UNEMPLOYMENT ASSISTANCE (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS) ACT, 1935.

speech.p:
Motion made and Question proposed: That the Unemployment Assistance (Temporary Provisions) Act, 1935 (Termination) Order, 1936, dated the fifteenth day of July, nineteen hundred and thirty-six, made by the Minister of Labour under the
Unemployment Assistance (Temporary Provisions) Act, 1935, a copy of which was presented to this House on the said fifteenth day of July, be confirmed."—[Mr. E. Brown.]

I desire to ask the Minister of Labour whether he is prepared to withdraw the statement he made which was equal to a slur upon the government of the city of Glasgow. If the statement was true there would not have been one case such as that in existence. It would have been a general rule. The Minister knows that his officials were out, not to see that nothing was wrong, but always in the hope that they would see something wrong to catch up the Labour government in Glasgow. I want to ask whether he will withdraw
the slur he has cast on the fair name of Glasgow?
I have nothing to withdraw. I stand by every word I said in that respect.
It was Mr. Leonard on the Board who framed up that case and
took you to it. You did not know anything about it. You have been taken in. I will deal with you in Glasgow.
Question put.
The House divided: Ayes, 339; Noes, 146.

publicwhip.major-heading: Orders of the Day — EDUCATION BILL.

speech.p: Order for Consideration of Lords Amendments read.
Motion made, and Question, "that the Lords Amendments be now considered," put, and agreed to.—[Mr. Stanley.]
Lords Amendments considered accordingly.

publicwhip.minor-heading: CLAUSE 3.—(Employment certificates to cease to have effect in certain cases.)

speech.p: Lords Amendment: In page 4, line 14, leave out "and", and insert "or".

speech.speakername: The PRESIDENT of the BOARD of EDUCATION (Mr. Oliver Stanley)
speech.p: I beg to move, "That this House doth agree with the Lords in the said Amendment".
This is purely drafting.

publicwhip.minor-heading: CLAUSE 7.—(Provisions with respect to byelaws made before the appointed day.)

speech.p: Lords Amendment: In page 6, line 22, at the end, insert: Provided that the grant of a certificate relating to employment in the area of an authority other than the issuing authority shall not be subject to the provisions of subsection (6) of the said section two unless the said sections two to six have been applied in that area.

I beg to move, "That this House doth agree with the Lords in the said Amendment."
This is merely a matter of machinery. It obviates the necessity in the case of an area which has adopted the by-law procedure before the appointed day to go through the usual procedure.

publicwhip.minor-heading: CLAUSE 8.—(Power of local education authority to make grants for enlarging, etc., non-provided schools.)

speech.p: Lords Amendment, in page 7, line 23, after the word last inserted, insert "whether directly or indirectly".
I would point out that this Amendment raises a question of Privilege.

I beg to move, "That this House doth disagree with the Lords in the said Amendment."
This Amendment is the only one which raises a point of substance. It is one about which I must say a few words even at this late hour. The effect of this Amendment is to extend the possibility of grants, which are at present confined entirely to schools for senior children, to schools for the education of junior
children. The mover of this Amendment in another place put it forward on the ground that it was restricted in its application. I must warn the House that a court would hold that in fact this Amendment might not be construed in such a limited sense.
But really the point which is the decisive point is not that but the question of Privilege, to which Mr. Speaker has referred, because an Amendment exactly similar to this was ruled out of order by the Chairman of Committee upstairs on the ground that it was outside the Financial Resolution. The words of the Financial Resolution were "for the education of senior children". It was held that this was in conflict with the Resolution. In fairness to myself, and in view of the strong feeling this House has about Financial Resolutions being drawn so as to exclude legitimate Amendments, I would say that the Financial Resolution was in simple form; that no one took any exception to it and that the words "for the education of senior children" expressed the feeling intended. To have omitted these words from the Resolution would have given no idea of what the scheme attempted to do.
The examination of this Amendment would raise the great question of privilege and, even if privilege were waived, it would be doubtful whether it would be possible to accept this in the Bill. It would be doubtful whether we could accept it without withdrawing the Financial Resolution and substituting another. That, of course, the Government are not prepared to accept. Even if it were not for this, I should not be able to advise the House to agree with the Lords. The mover of this Amendment was misled into telling another place that this was an Amendment which other interests in this controversy would regard as quite acceptable.
Under the rules of the House is it in Order for the right hon. Gentleman to criticise a speech made in another place?

In the case of statements of policy made in another place you are allowed to refer to them but criticism of speeches in another place or references to them with a view to influencing the Debate in this House is not allowed.
Is not the rule against any quotation of a speech, but not against a reference to it?
I have been checked by the Chair on more than one occasion in the past on the ground that it was out of order.

I am sure I can avoid any difficulty by simply saying that if this House were to accept this Amendment we should find it would arouse bitter feelings among many sections of opinion, and entirely destroy the basis upon which the whole of this part of the Bill rests.
I think the right hon. Gentleman has accurately stated what occurred on the Committee, and that he has taken the best possible course.

I wonder if anyone has been as unwise as I have been in remaining here 33 hours in order to make a speech a half a minute? The Minister has most thoroughly adhered to the position he took up in Committee upstairs, both in the letter and the spirit, and I think that is wise. If he had accepted the Amendment, the whole basis of our assent to the concessions that were made from the denominational point of view would have been upset, and I would like humbly to support him very heartily in the attitude he has taken up, that it is impossible within the understanding arrived at in the House of Commons to accept the Amendment.
Lords Amendment, in page 7, line 41, after "required," insert "wholly or mainly."

I beg to move, "That this House doth agree with the Lords in the said Amendment."
This is purely a clarifying Amendment. A particular point was brought to my notice which I had always believed was covered by the drafting of the Bill, but this Amendment makes that doubly sure.
Remaining Lords Amendments agreed to.
Committee appointed to draw up a Reason to be assigned to the Lords for disagreeing with one of their Amendments to the Bill.
Committee nominated of Mr. Lees-Smith, Sir Percy Harris, Mr. Annesley Somerville, the Attorney-General and Mr. Stanley.
Three to be the quorum.—[Mr. Stanley.]
To withdraw immediately.
Reason for disagreeing with one of the Lords Amendments reported, and agreed to.
To be communicated to the Lords.—[Mr. Stanley.]

speech.p: Order read for resuming Adjourned Debate on Question [13th July]: That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, in pursuance of the provisions of Sections 309 of the Government of India Act, 1935, praying that the Aden Colony Order, 1936, be made in the form of the draft laid before Parliament.
Question again proposed.
1 a.m.

speech.speakername: The UNDER-SECRETARY of STATE for INDIA (Mr. Butler)
speech.p:
I beg to move in line 4, at the end, to add, subject, however, to the following amendments:—
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 5, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 6, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 8, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'"
These are drafting Amendments to substitute the words "the Colony" for the word "Aden". Aden is a Colony and
these Amendments are to correct a drafting mistake.
Amendment agreed to.

Resolved: That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, in pursuance of the provisions of Section 309 of the Government of India Act, 1935, praying that the Aden Colony Order, 1936, be made in the form of the draft laid before Parliament, subject, however, to the following amendments:—
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 5, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 6, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'
In paragraph 21, page 7, line 8, leave out 'Aden,' and insert 'the Colony.'"
To be presented by Privy Councillors or Members of His Majesty's Household.
